articles.trailText: Plan to connect nuclear plant to Russian grid was foiled and it has now been reconnected to Ukrainian power
articles.summary: In early October, Russian occupiers planned to link Zaporizhzhia NPP to the Russian grid as a birthday gift for Putin, but Ukrainian partisans sabotaged a new high-voltage connection on 6 October. After 30 days relying on diesel generators to cool its six cold-shutdown reactors, engineers on 23 October restored external power via a repaired 750 kV line to Ukrainian territory under an IAEA-brokered ceasefire. The IAEA confirmed reconnection, averting a slow-motion Fukushima-style crisis, while Ukraine accuses Russia of self-sabotage to force a switch to its grid.

articles.title: Louvre thieves’ slow-motion getaway using furniture lift was caught on video
articles.trailText: Footage showing two men appears to have been filmed from nearby window in museum
articles.summary: A verified 36-second clip shows two men in black—one in a yellow hi-vis vest and one in a motorcycle helmet—descending on a stolen furniture lift from the Louvre’s Apollo gallery and fleeing on scooters with €88 million (£76 million) of crown jewels, including Napoleon I’s emerald-diamond necklace and Empress Eugénie’s diadem. The raid began at 9.30 am via a smashed window and disc cutters and lasted under seven minutes. Interior minister Laurent Nuñez has deployed over 100 investigators after museum director Laurence des Cars admitted “highly insufficient” external camera coverage.

articles.title: Palestine rights group seeks prosecution of UK citizens who fought for Israel
articles.trailText: Highly unusual court application alleges more than 10 individuals breached foreign enlistment laws
articles.summary: International Centre for Justice for Palestinians has filed a private prosecution under section 4 of the Foreign Enlistment Act 1870, alleging that over ten British nationals voluntarily enlisted in the Israel Defense Forces to fight a state (Palestine) at peace with the UK. The ICJP lodged a summons against one named individual in a magistrates’ court while withholding other names to avoid prejudicing evidence. It contends Israel’s military operations in Gaza and the West Bank constitute a war against all Palestinians, claims Palestine is a UK-recognized state, and argues waging such a war breaches UK enlistment laws. The group cites recent International Court of Justice advisory opinions on Israel’s occupation of East Jerusalem, the West Bank and Gaza to bolster its case. The prosecution must prove UK nationality, IDF engagement, a state of war between Israel and Palestine, and Palestine’s peace with the UK.

articles.title: Irish police brace for more unrest at Dublin hotel housing asylum seekers
articles.trailText: Gardaí deployed at Citywest facility as police issue statement urging people to stay away from violent standoff
articles.summary: Irish police at Citywest hotel in Saggart, SW Dublin, braced for renewed clashes as anti-immigration activists threw fireworks, missiles and set a police vehicle ablaze this week after an alleged sexual assault by an asylum seeker. A heavy Garda presence—300 officers, riot squads, dogs, horses and water cannon—remained on standby. Authorities arrested sixteen and urged community leaders to steer youths away from violence. Taoiseach Micheál Martin condemned the disorder as part of a rising trend of anti-refugee protests across Ireland and Britain.

articles.title: Colombia urges US to halt strikes on alleged drug-smuggling boats: ‘It is murder’
articles.trailText: Plea comes after Pete Hegseth announced two new strikes that left at least five people dead
articles.summary: Colombian foreign ministry and President Gustavo Petro condemned US airstrikes on vessels alleged to traffic drugs in the Pacific and Caribbean—the first Pacific strikes killed at least five and bring nine strikes since September with 37 dead—to cease operations they call illegal “murder.” The US, framing the campaign as counternarcotics against Venezuelan cartels, has deployed destroyers, F-35s, a submarine and troops in the Caribbean. Mexico’s president also criticised the raids. Experts warn the strikes, hitting low-level smugglers, won’t dent drug flows, and Trump has threatened land strikes next.

articles.title: Brazilian president will seek fourth term at age 80: ‘I’ve got as much energy as when I was 30’
articles.trailText: Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva, who first ran for elected office in 1982, announced he will run again in next year’s election
articles.summary: President Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva, about to turn 80, has declared he’ll seek a historic fourth term in Brazil’s October 2026 election, which could extend his tenure to 16 years. First elected in 2002 after earlier unsuccessful bids—he first ran in 1982—Lula’s stamina and sharpness are touted by his biographer amid comparisons with aging leaders elsewhere. With Jair Bolsonaro jailed and the right in disarray, polls show Lula leading contenders like São Paulo governor Tarcísio de Freitas. Failed US tariffs under Trump even strengthened his position ahead of looming Lula-Trump talks.

articles.title: Will US sanctions on Russian oil companies be effective, and why is Trump imposing them now?
articles.trailText: Measures against Rosneft and Lukoil mark first time US has imposed sanctions on Russia since Trump’s return to office
articles.summary: On 23 Oct, the Trump administration imposed its first Russia sanctions of his second term, targeting Rosneft and Lukoil—responsible for nearly half of Russia’s crude exports—by freezing their US assets, banning US dealings, and threatening secondary sanctions on banks handling Russian oil in China, India and Turkey. The US Treasury cites funding for Putin’s war in Ukraine; EU and UK have imposed parallel measures. Early reports show India and China halting imports, but experts doubt Moscow can’t reroute trade. Impact hinges on enforcement. Debates rage over seizing frozen Russian assets to fund Ukraine and approving allies’ long-range missiles, while Putin endures economic pain.

articles.title: ‘Quiet as a whisper’: German firm  launches ad campaign after lift used in Louvre heist
articles.trailText: After watching the news about the Paris robbery, managers at Böcker decided to make the most of the publicity
articles.summary: Family-owned German firm Böcker turned the notoriety of its Agilo furniture lift—used by thieves to scale a Louvre window, steal €88m (£76m) of Napoleonic jewels and flee in under 10 minutes—into a cheeky ad campaign on Facebook and Instagram. With the tagline “When you need to move fast…as quiet as a whisper,” the campaign launched within 24 hours, boosting reach from 20,000 to 1.7 million and drawing largely positive feedback. Böcker sold the lift in 2020 to a Paris rental outfit, which reported it stolen during a demo. Founded 1958, 600 staff.

articles.title: A rift that took 500 years to repair: King Charles prays with the pope
articles.trailText: Joint prayer in Sistine Chapel is symbolic act of rapprochement between Catholic church and Church of England after centuries of division
articles.summary: King Charles III joined Pope Leo XIV in prayer beneath the Sistine Chapel frescoes, symbolising a historic rapprochement between the Church of England and Roman Catholicism almost 500 years after Henry VIII’s break in 1534. The act, hailed by Westminster Abbey theologian Jamie Hawkey and historian Catherine Pepinster, follows decades of thawing ties—royal visits to Rome, the 2013 Succession to the Crown Act easing, and Charles’s attendance at Catholic ceremonies—and marks the first time a British monarch has knelt with the pope, signaling a healing of centuries-old mutual suspicion despite enduring doctrinal differences.

articles.title: Donald Trump says Australia will get the Aukus submarines – but the decision won’t be his to make
articles.trailText: If the US navy needs the subs, they cannot be sold to Australia, regardless of how much the president might wish it
articles.summary: Donald Trump’s vow that “they’re getting” Virginia-class nuclear-powered submarines under the AUKUS pact overlooks constitutional and statutory constraints: presidents limited to two terms (Trump leaves in 2029), and by law any sale in 2032 must be certified at least 270 days beforehand that US undersea capabilities won’t be degraded. With the US fleet at 49 of a 66-boat goal and Virginia-class build rates at 1.13/year (vs 2.33 needed for Australia), the navy will likely retain boats. Australia also lacks infrastructure—crewing, maintenance, nuclear-waste storage—and must demonstrate domestic capacity before transfer. Political pledges belie AUKUS’s substantial strategic, industrial and legal hurdles.

articles.title: French coastguards demand halt to ‘deadly plans’ to intercept small boats
articles.trailText: Union says UK-French Channel deal is inhumane and contravenes international conventions
articles.summary: French coastguards’ union Solidaires Douanes has urged the suspension of a UK-France Channel plan to intercept small boats up to 300m off the French coast, calling it “deadly” and in breach of international conventions. In a letter to customs chief Florian Colas, they warned interceptions risk shipwrecks and deaths. The Home Office confirms France is reviewing its new “maritime doctrine,” while UK officials, including border security chief Martin Hewitt, express frustration at delays. Observers say the tactic may never be implemented, and a police union says it’s on hold. Meanwhile, the UK’s “one in, one out” repatriation already suffered setbacks after an Iranian asylum seeker returned by small boat.

articles.title: EU has a plan to use frozen Russian assets to fund Ukraine – how will it work?
articles.trailText: What are the legal implications, and why does Belgium fear being left alone with the bill?
articles.summary: The EU plans to lend Ukraine up to €140 bn over three years, secured on roughly €200 bn of Russian central-bank assets frozen in Euroclear, without outright confiscation. Ukraine would repay via future Russian reparations. Member states must address legal hurdles: maintaining asset freezes (currently requiring six-month unanimity renewals, with Article 31(2) under debate), sharing guarantee risks (Belgium’s concern), and gaining approvals from Hungary and Slovakia. Brussels hopes to finalize the framework by year-end, disbursing funds from April 2026, earmarked mostly for European-made weapons but partly for Kyiv’s budget.

articles.title: Latest EU sanctions against Russia target liquefied natural gas
articles.trailText: Measures also add 117 shadow fleet vessels to list of those suspected of illegal oil shipments and banned from ports
articles.summary: The EU's 19th sanctions package against Russia introduces, for the first time, a phased ban on Russian liquefied natural gas imports, aiming to halt all LNG trade by January 2027. It also blacklists 117 additional ‘shadow fleet’ vessels—bringing the total to 558 ships barred from EU ports and insurance—to enforce the G7 oil price cap. New rules restrict Russian diplomats’ intra-EU travel. Adopted after Slovakia lifted its veto and alongside US sanctions on Rosneft and Lukoil, the measures underscore EU solidarity with Ukraine, even as debates continue over using €140bn of frozen Russian assets to fund Kyiv.

articles.title: Catherine Connolly: the outspoken leftwinger set to be Ireland’s next president
articles.trailText: Independent candidate’s smooth campaign has enthused younger voters but views on Nato and Hamas may concern European allies
articles.summary: Independent leftwinger Catherine Connolly, a former barrister and clinical psychologist turned independent TD, is poised to become Ireland’s next president, leading Heather Humphreys by wide margins. Her campaign, fueled by youth anger over housing and cost-of-living crises, deft social-media outreach and backing from Labour, Sinn Féin and other left parties, has resonated at Vicar Street rallies. Yet her radical stances—opposing NATO, criticizing EU treaties and describing Hamas as part of Palestinian identity—alarm some European allies, and low turnout and spoilt-ballot rates threaten legitimacy despite the presidency’s largely ceremonial role.

articles.title: Is Shell to blame for a ‘super typhoon’? Philippines survivors to sue oil giant in legal first
articles.trailText: Typhoon Rai killed more than 400, displaced nearly 3.2 million, and destroyed more than a million homes in 2021
articles.summary: Trixy Elle and 66 fellow survivors of 2021’s Super Typhoon Rai (Odette), which killed 400+, displaced 3.2 million and wrecked over 1 million homes in the Philippines, have issued a letter before action to Shell in the UK, demanding compensation and injunctive relief. In a global first, they’ll file a UK high court suit in December, alleging Shell’s decades-long CO₂ emissions and climate disinformation intensified Rai’s impact, violating their constitutional right to a healthy environment. Backed by attribution science from Imperial College and a Philippine Human Rights probe, the case argues Shell knew fossil fuels’ harms yet expanded operations and concealed risks, seeking accountability for past injuries.

articles.title: Thursday briefing: While the ceasefire holds, Gaza continues to starve
articles.trailText: In today’s newsletter: With most border crossings remaining closed and aid deliveries falling catastrophically short, will the International Court of Justice’s ruling force change for those left behind?
articles.summary: After the ICJ ruled Israel the occupying power in Gaza and the West Bank, it ordered cooperation with UN aid agencies and warned against using starvation as a weapon. A fragile ceasefire has enabled hostage exchanges and modest aid increases—but with only two crossings open, deliveries remain far below the 2,000-tonne daily target. Gaza faces a man-made famine: soaring food prices, widespread malnutrition, water shortages and a power vacuum driven by Israeli restrictions. Eyad Amawi reports desperate needs for nourishment, heavy machinery to clear rubble and tents for the displaced.

articles.title: Wildfires have consumed vast chunks of Ukraine. Is Russia deliberately fuelling the flames?
articles.trailText: In 2024, nearly a million hectares of Ukraine’s land burned. Heat, mines and shelling contributed, but footage of drones targeting firefighters has raised the question of war crimes
articles.summary: In 2024 nearly a million hectares of Ukraine burned—more than twice the EU’s total—mainly along frontline forests in Kharkiv, Donetsk and Zaporizhzhia. Hot, dry conditions, stray mines and unexploded ordnance from Russia’s invasion sparked hundreds of low-intensity fires. Satellite and video analysis shows Russian drones deliberately targeting firefighters and using ‘double-tap’ strikes. Prosecutors are probing these attacks as potential war crimes. Ecologists warn the combined effects of shelling, mines and climate change could delay forest and agricultural recovery by decades.

articles.title: Tens of thousands to attend rival rallies as Hungary’s election campaign kicks off
articles.trailText: Budapest marches by ruling Fidesz party and opposition Tisza will take place in a highly polarised political climate
articles.summary: As Hungary’s election campaign begins for April 2025 polls, Fidesz’s Viktor Orbán and opposition newcomer Péter Magyar will each lead tens-of-thousands-strong rival rallies in Budapest on the 1956 uprising anniversary. Orbán presents a “peace march” amid record inflation, deepening Kremlin ties after a scrapped Trump–Putin meeting and nationalist pledges on migration and Ukraine neutrality. Magyar’s Tisza, neck-and-neck with Fidesz in polls (37% vs 27%), accuses Orbán of state-funded voter shuttles, corruption and media bias, pledges anti-corruption, pro-Ukraine energy diversification after touring 158 towns. Analysts deem the race “free but unfair,” with 25% undecided voters making the outcome unpredictable.

articles.title: New Zealand ‘mega strike’: 100,000 public sector workers demand better conditions
articles.trailText: Teachers, nurses and public service staff among those walking off job and pressing for more government investment in health and education
articles.summary: About 100,000 New Zealand public sector workers—including 60,000 teachers, 40,000 nurses and 15,000 public servants—launched a “mega strike” after collective bargaining stalled, demanding urgent government investment to address pay inequity, unsafe staffing levels and worsening service cuts in health and education. Despite severe weather, nationwide rallies warned of patient harm from hospital overcapacity, long wait times and teacher exodus to Australia. The coalition government dismissed the strike as “politically motivated,” but a Talbot Mills poll showed 65% public support, with opposition parties backing the action.

articles.title: Ukraine war briefing: Ukrainians may get Gripen fighter jets bought with Russian money
articles.trailText: Double dose of Russian oil sanctions from EU and US; freezing war at current frontlines is ‘good compromise’, says Zelenskyy. What we know on day 1,338
articles.summary: Ukraine has agreed to buy up to 150 Swedish Gripen E fighters—built to operate from roads as well as airfields—financed by frozen Russian assets and allied contributions. President Zelenskyy aims to field them next year to complement F-16s and Mirages; analysts highlight Gripen’s advanced radar, electronic-warfare systems and long-range Meteor missiles. In parallel, the EU and US announced fresh oil sanctions on Rosneft, Lukoil and Moscow’s shadow tanker fleet, accelerating an LNG ban to 2027. EU leaders will pledge €140 billion in loans from frozen Russian funds. Zelenskyy favors freezing frontlines as a ‘good compromise’ while Russia’s drones and missiles continue striking Kyiv.

articles.title: What is South Korea’s ‘monster missile’, and what does it mean for relations with the North?
articles.trailText: The Hyunmoo-5 ‘bunker buster’ missile can reportedly carry an eight-tonne warhead and will be ready for deployment at the end of the year
articles.summary: South Korea will deploy at year-end its largest conventional missile, the Hyunmoo-5 “monster missile,” a 36-tonne, 16m long surface-to-surface “bunker buster” capable of carrying an 8-ton warhead and striking targets 600–5,000km away. Developed after 2010 North Korean attacks and enabled by lifted US payload limits, it aims to achieve a “balance of terror” under the NPT and bolster self-reliant defense under President Lee. The move follows North Korea’s Hwasong-20 ICBM unveiling, may deter but risk further regional escalation. Seoul spends 1.4 times North Korea’s GDP on defense yearly and ranks fifth globally, with arms exports surging post-Ukraine war.

articles.title: ICJ orders Israel to allow aid into Gaza and says restrictions breached international obligations
articles.trailText: UN’s top court also finds Israel failed to justify blocking Unrwa and other relief agencies
articles.summary: The ICJ advisory opinion found Israel’s two-year blockade on Gaza violated the UN Charter and Geneva Conventions, ordering unimpeded humanitarian access via UNRWA and NGOs, deeming starvation as a prohibited method of warfare, and requiring respect for UN immunities and property. It dismissed Israeli claims that UNRWA was compromised, highlighted catastrophic civilian casualties and deaths of aid workers, and ruled Israel must cooperate in good faith. Israel rejected the findings. Norway plans a UN General Assembly resolution; some states may seek damages for breaches of UN immunities.

articles.title: Louvre director acknowledges ‘terrible failure’ after €88m jewel heist
articles.trailText: Laurence des Cars questioned by senators about daring daytime break-in at Paris museum
articles.summary: Laurence des Cars, director of Paris’s Louvre, called the €88m daytime jewel heist a “terrible failure” after four men used a truck-mounted ladder and hoist to enter the Apollo gallery via a balcony, cut a window, and steal gems in seven minutes. She admitted “highly insufficient” security camera coverage on exterior walls before senators criticized perimeter vulnerabilities and slow response. Although alarms triggered and guards prevented the escape van’s destruction—preserving evidence—a diamond-and-emerald crown was damaged. Des Cars offered her resignation, which was refused, and defended the museum’s €80m security plan. President Macron has ordered faster installation of full façade video surveillance and an internal police post.

articles.title: ‘Hogwash’ that Israel is a US client state, says Netanyahu
articles.trailText: Israeli PM dismisses claim despite Washington providing estimated 68% of country’s foreign-sourced weapons
articles.summary: Israel’s PM Benjamin Netanyahu on Oct 22 rejected as “hogwash” suggestions that Israel is a US client state despite Washington supplying 68% of its foreign arms, asserting an alliance of equals during talks with US VP J.D. Vance in Jerusalem. Vance echoed this, rejecting vassal-state claims amid a fragile Gaza ceasefire. The US is pushing to disarm Hamas and rebuild Gaza, debating Turkey’s role. Meanwhile, the ICJ urged Israel to readmit UNRWA in Gaza and the Knesset preliminarily approved a West Bank sovereignty bill, risking US red lines. Ceasefire violations and hostage-body exchanges highlight ongoing tensions.

articles.title: Zelenskyy calls Trump’s proposal to freeze war at current frontlines ‘good compromise’
articles.trailText: US president’s remark seen as modest win for Ukrainian leader, who acknowledges Russia will not accept proposal
articles.summary: Ukrainian president Volodymyr Zelenskyy backed former US president Donald Trump’s plan to freeze the war at current frontlines, calling it “a good compromise,” while warning Moscow would reject it. Trump, who has fluctuated on ceasefires and peace negotiations, floated the proposal before postponing a potential summit with Vladimir Putin. Russia’s hardline leadership, represented by Foreign Minister Sergei Lavrov, swiftly dismissed the idea, reiterating demands to control the Donbas and reshape Ukraine’s sovereignty. Meanwhile, Russian forces have intensified missile and drone strikes on Ukrainian cities and conducted strategic nuclear drills.

articles.title: As the US flip-flops on the path to peace, Europe’s ‘coalition of the willing’ rallies round Ukraine
articles.trailText: From unanimity on a reparations loan to the unpredictability of Trump, EU leaders will gather this week with agreement on ending the war still fraught with hurdles
articles.summary: Amid President Trump’s oscillating Ukraine policy—first endorsing Kyiv’s territorial recovery, then urging Zelenskyy to cede land after consulting Putin—Ukraine and ten EU states have formed a “coalition of the willing.” Ahead of Brussels and London summits, they backed an immediate ceasefire along current lines, a 12-point peace roadmap and an interest-free €140 billion reparations loan sourced from Russian frozen assets. Persisting hurdles include the need for unanimous EU sanctions renewals (blocked by Hungary and Slovakia) and stalled EU accession talks due to Orbán’s veto.

articles.title: The Louvre’s new must-see? The broken window smashed by thieves in €88m jewel heist
articles.trailText: Visitors flock to visit Paris museum as it reopens, but some are more interested in evidence of Sunday’s dramatic robbery than the art works inside
articles.summary: The Louvre reopened after Sunday’s €88 m Napoleonic jewellery heist in its Apollo gallery, but visitors queueing for the Mona Lisa detoured to inspect the smashed window thieves—disguised in hi-vis vests—used with an extendable ladder and disc cutters. In under four minutes they fled on motorbikes with eight pieces, including Marie-Louise’s emerald-diamond necklace and Empress Eugénie’s diadem. With 100 investigators probing possible security lapses amid staff cuts, Interior Minister Laurent Nuñez vows swift progress and President Macron orders reinforced protections.

articles.title: Letter: Jenny Cox obituary
articles.trailText: Stephen Cox writes: I discovered that my mother was not allowed to do her botany research on South Georgia because of a letter from Vivian Fuchs
articles.summary: Stephen Cox reveals that in a newly released letter dated 7 October 1959, Sir Vivian Fuchs barred his mother, botanist Jenny Cox, from conducting her PhD field research on South Georgia solely because she was a woman. Fuchs offered UK-based laboratory work on existing Antarctic specimens but insisted no women could endure the island’s harsh conditions or lodging. That gender-biased policy, common among mid-20th-century Antarctic explorers, effectively ended Cox’s career in polar botany. Despite this setback, Jenny Cox persevered, building a legacy of resilience and demonstrating how to forge new paths when institutional barriers arise.

articles.title: Louvre jewel heist: other daring art thefts from the museum
articles.trailText: How the Guardian reported the stealing of art works from the Paris museum including the Mona Lisa in 1911
articles.summary: From the 1911 theft of da Vinci’s Mona Lisa—purloined by Louvre handyman Vincenzo Peruggia and recovered in Florence in 1913—to the 1939 disappearance of Watteau’s L’Indifférent, the 1946 burglary of Second Empire jewels, the twin 1990 daylight raids that saw a Renoir and a Hebert portrait cut from their frames, and the 1998 Corot heist of Le chemin de Sèvres, the Louvre has weathered repeated breaches. Each incident exposed security lapses—from hoax theories and guard shortages to failed alarms—and spurred major overhauls in surveillance, staffing and artifact protection.

articles.title: Children among six killed in Kyiv after Russian missile and drone attack
articles.trailText: Strikes, involving over 400 drones and 28 missiles, launched hours after Putin-Trump meeting in Budapest cancelled
articles.summary: Overnight Russian forces unleashed a sustained barrage—more than 400 Shahed drones and 28 missiles—on Kyiv and other Ukrainian cities hours after a planned Putin–Trump meeting in Budapest was abruptly cancelled. The attack killed six civilians, including a six-month-old baby and a 12-year-old girl, and struck a Kharkiv kindergarten, a hospital and multiple high-rise residential blocks. Key energy facilities were damaged, triggering rolling blackouts and leaving thousands without heat or power. President Zelenskyy condemned the strikes as terrorism, while Ukraine reported retaliatory Storm Shadow missile and drone raids on Bryansk and Mordovia in Russia.

articles.title: Jewish figures across the globe call on UN and world leaders to sanction Israel
articles.trailText: Exclusive: In an open letter, Israeli ex-officials, artists and intellectuals say ‘unconscionable’ actions in Gaza amount to genocide
articles.summary: Over 450 Jewish figures worldwide—former Israeli officials (Avraham Burg, Daniel Levy), artists (Michael Rosen, Naomi Klein, Ilana Glazer), Oscar and Pulitzer winners—have penned an open letter to the UN and world leaders urging targeted sanctions, arms‐embargoes, and enforcement of ICJ/ICC rulings against Israel, accusing its Gaza, West Bank and East Jerusalem operations of genocide. They call for humanitarian aid, reject antisemitism charges, cite US and EU polling on war crimes perceptions, and demand an end to occupation and apartheid. They highlight Gaza’s toll (65,000+ killed, 167,000 injured, 90% displaced) and urge world to uphold safeguards born from Holocaust lessons.

articles.title: Wednesday briefing: Making sense of the Maccabi Tel Aviv saga, where law and disorder fumbled with fandom
articles.trailText: In today’s newsletter: Inside a tortuous political saga where fandom and antisemitism once again became a political football
articles.summary: In a protracted saga, Birmingham’s safety advisory group, backed by West Midlands police, banned Maccabi Tel Aviv fans from attending their away match at Aston Villa after citing the club’s history of football violence—including 2023 Amsterdam clashes—and fears of extremist opportunism, notably Tommy Robinson supporters. UK politicians condemned the ban as antisemitic, but Maccabi ultimately declined any ticket allocation, citing “hate-filled falsehoods” and unacceptable risks to fan safety. The episode spotlights tensions between hazard-based policing decisions, political interference, and debates over antisemitism versus legitimate security assessments.

articles.title: ‘They can’t dismiss Leo so easily’: how the pope has confounded conservatives
articles.trailText: As pontiff prepares for visit of King Charles, the contours of his papacy are slowly becoming apparent
articles.summary: First North American pope Leo XIV, ahead of King Charles’s Vatican visit, is consolidating his predecessor Francis’s priorities on migration, climate and poverty. Though he has adopted traditional papal formalities—red mozzetta, Latin Mass—and held private meetings with conservative cardinals, his measured pronouncements urge US bishops to oppose inhuman migration policies, denounce hunger as a weapon of war and endorse bold climate action. His inaugural exhortation Dilexi te decries inequality and economic “dictatorship,” prompting conservative Catholics to label him the “woke pope.”

articles.title: JD Vance expresses ‘great optimism’ over Gaza ceasefire deal during Israel visit
articles.trailText: US vice-president to visit Netanyahu while Hamas joins talks in Cairo meant to iron out differences
articles.summary: US VP JD Vance toured southern Israel, met envoys Steve Witkoff and Jared Kushner, and held talks with PM Netanyahu, declaring “great optimism” that the 10-October Gaza ceasefire is “durable” despite 80 Israeli breaches, 26 Palestinian and two Israeli combatant deaths. Concurrent Cairo negotiations with Hamas target disarmament clauses and formation of a technocratic Gaza authority. Sticking points include return of 13 remaining hostage bodies, stalled aid—986 of 6,600 trucks delivered—and Israel’s insistence on full Hamas demilitarisation before reconstruction. Qatar’s emir condemned settlement expansion, while aid agencies warn deliveries remain below a third of needs, risking famine in northern Gaza.

articles.title: Ukraine war briefing: Storm Shadow missiles ‘hit gunpowder plant in Russia’
articles.trailText: Russians confirm attack on Bryansk region home to explosives factory; Trump-Putin talks shelved, US diplomacy ‘going in circles’. What we know on day 1,337
articles.summary: Ukraine's military said Britain-France Storm Shadow cruise missiles breached Russian air defenses to strike a gunpowder, explosives and rocket-fuel plant in Bryansk region, confirmed by Moscow. Concurrent Russian drone and missile raids on Kyiv killed two, damaged infrastructure and spurred secondary drone waves; Zaporizhzhia, Dnipro and Izmail were also hit. Diplomatic efforts stalled: a planned Trump-Putin Budapest summit was shelved after fruitless Rubio-Lavrov talks, while U.S. and European mediators draw up a ceasefire along current frontlines with a proposed Trump-chaired peace board. In Ukraine's north, Russian kamikaze drones killed four in Novhorod-Siverskyi and strikes plunged Chernihiv region into power outages.

articles.title: ‘A perfect coincidence’: rare red lightning captured in New Zealand skies
articles.trailText: The extremely unusual phenomenon – also known as red lightning – lasts for a millisecond and is rarely visible to the naked eye
articles.summary: On 11 October, New Zealand photographer Tom Rae and Spanish colleagues Dan Zafra and José Cantabrana unexpectedly captured rare ‘red sprites’ – millisecond-long crimson lightning flashes shooting upward from thunderstorms – while aiming to photograph the Milky Way over South Island’s Ōmārama Clay cliffs. Red sprites, first accidentally recorded in 1989, form carrot- or jellyfish-like columns high in the upper atmosphere and are invisible to the naked eye. This marks perhaps the only frame combining southern-hemisphere Milky Way panoramas with a red sprite display, a feat requiring split-second timing and expert astrophotography.

articles.title: Dublin police condemn ‘thuggery’ after protest outside hotel housing asylum seekers turns violent
articles.trailText: Six arrests made after crowd hurled fireworks and other missiles at officers during protests following alleged sexual assault on a young girl
articles.summary: Up to 2,000 people gathered outside the Citywest hotel in south-west Dublin—used to house asylum seekers—on Tuesday night, following news that a 26-year-old asylum seeker was charged with allegedly sexually assaulting a 10-year-old girl. Protesters burned a Garda van and hurled bricks, bottles, fireworks and traffic cones at officers, prompting six arrests. Commissioner Justin Kelly called it ‘thuggery,’ while Justice Minister Jim O’Callaghan and Taoiseach Micheál Martin condemned the violence. Tusla said the victim, in state care, had absconded earlier. The unrest reflects growing far-right anti-immigrant sentiment.

articles.title: Kosovo offers to become first country to accept Britain’s refused asylum seekers
articles.trailText: However, Kosovo is an outlier in the region, whose other leaders say ‘looking for places to dump immigrants’ is evidence the UK is in ‘a very dark place’
articles.summary: Kosovo prime minister Albin Kurti has offered to host refused UK asylum seekers in ‘return hubs’ abroad, holding talks with British officials to transfer failed claimants once appeals are exhausted. In exchange, Kosovo seeks security assistance, strategic agreements and equipment. Balkan neighbours are divided: Albania’s PM Edi Rama condemned Britain for ‘dumping immigrants’, Bosnia and Herzegovina rejected the idea, Montenegro is open only with significant UK infrastructure investment. Ahead of a London summit, Labour leader Keir Starmer proposes a western Balkans migration taskforce deploying drones to curb illegal crossings. Refugee charities warn of punitive detention’s ineffectiveness and fear-driven compliance.

articles.title: US shelves plans for Trump-Putin talks in Budapest
articles.trailText: White House says there are now no plans for summit ‘in the immediate future’ as latest efforts to end Ukraine war falter
articles.summary: Washington shelved a planned Trump–Putin summit in Budapest after last week’s diplomacy produced no breakthrough on Ukraine. The White House said there are “no plans” for an immediate meeting following stalled talks between Secretary of State Rubio and Foreign Minister Lavrov, who reaffirmed Russia’s demand for unchanged territorial terms. Trump, unwilling to risk a “wasted meeting,” rejected ceding Donetsk. Kyiv and its Western allies, including the UK, France and Germany, now push a ceasefire on existing frontlines, back a 12-point proposal and eye using frozen Russian assets (€140 bn) to fund Ukraine’s defence from 2026.

articles.title: Black History Month now year-round event at Fulham Palace as it addresses its past
articles.trailText: Museum wants to confront history of ‘bishops of the colonies’ and their involvement in slavery
articles.summary: At Fulham Palace Trust, CEO Siân Harrington turned Black History Month into a year-round initiative, confronting the colonial and slavery roles of the bishops of London. After George Floyd’s death, the museum joined Black History 365 and reconfigured permanent displays with the Resistance exhibition on anti-slavery movements. It applied to be an anti-racist museum and plans a permanent show on how plant collecting facilitated land seizures. Recently it hosted tapestry panels on Black Britons, freely exhibited then set to tour, and will commission new tapestries on Roman Africans and the 60th Notting Hill Carnival.

articles.title: Louvre heist losses put at almost €90m as museum’s head prepares to face senators
articles.trailText: Police continue to search for the criminal gang behind the brazen robbery targeting France’s crown jewels
articles.summary: France’s Louvre estimates the Oct 19 brazen seven-minute heist of eight Napoleonic jewels at €88m–€90m. Museum president Laurence des Cars will face the senate’s culture committee over security flaws—window breach, display-case quality, absence of rapid-response unit—while culture minister Rachida Dati defends CCTV and plans further security upgrades. Investigators from the Paris prosecutor’s BRB and the central agency for trafficking in cultural property recovered DNA from a hi-vis vest, a stolen crown and other trace evidence. The museum has remained closed for three days, and its reopening remains uncertain. With no external insurer, the French state self-insures the national museum’s losses.

articles.title: Nicolas Sarkozy enters prison to begin five-year sentence over criminal conspiracy
articles.trailText: Former president organised stage-managed departure from his Paris home before becoming first French postwar leader to be jailed
articles.summary: Nicolas Sarkozy, France's rightwing president from 2007–12, began a five-year prison term for criminal conspiracy in a scheme to secure Gaddafi regime funds, becoming the first French postwar head of state jailed. He staged a departure from his Paris home with wife Carla Bruni and children, has appealed the verdict and awaits an appeals court decision that could grant supervised release. Held in solitary at La Santé with basic amenities, Sarkozy plans to write and denounces his sentence as a “judicial scandal.”

articles.title: Case of a single ballot that decided a vote in Canada sparks uproar
articles.trailText: Legal teams are midway through a hearing over whether one vote truly swayed a federal election in a Montreal suburb
articles.summary: Quebec courts are hearing arguments on whether a single miscounted ballot should void the April federal result in Terrebonne, north of Montreal. After an administrative error and recount, Liberal Tatiana Auguste was declared winner over incumbent Bloc Québécois MP Nathalie Sinclair-Desgagné by one vote. Voter Emmanuelle Bossé’s mailed ballot was rejected due to a postal code issue. Sinclair-Desgagné’s lawyer claims the mishandling violated Charter rights and urges a new vote to preserve public confidence, citing Opitz v Wrzesnewskyj guidance.

articles.title: Welfare cuts have fuelled rise of far right and populism, top UN expert says
articles.trailText: Exclusive: Poverty rapporteur says governments must rethink welfare state as essential to fabric of society
articles.summary: UN poverty rapporteur Olivier De Schutter warns that decades of welfare cuts by mainstream centre-right and centre-left governments have stoked scarcity fears, anti-migrant sentiment and a surge in far-right and populist support—from Reform UK in Britain to AfD in Germany and France’s National Rally. His forthcoming UN report urges a shift to universal, rights-based social protection as an investment in social cohesion. He cites studies linking higher inequality to populism and shows welfare boosts voting restraint and migrant net contributions.

articles.title: The Louvre raid was audacious - but nothing compared to the heist France's political leadership just pulled off | Rokhaya Diallo
articles.trailText: The theft of the crown jewels is another blow to national prestige, but far greater is the threat of a monarchical president hoarding power against voters’ wishes, says Guardian Europe columnist Rokhaya Diallo
articles.summary: Rokhaya Diallo likens the Louvre crown jewels theft to president Macron’s farcical political heist: within a month, PM Sébastien Lecornu resigned after failing to pass a budget, then was reinstated by Macron, reproducing the same government despite a hung parliament. Macron’s snap election gamble in 2024 backfired, leaving him unable to command a majority, yet he persists in stacking his Cabinet with loyalists and a fragile Socialist pact that merely suspends, not revokes, pension reforms. This hyper-presidential maneuver undermines the popular will and erodes trust in the Fifth Republic.

articles.title: Sanae Takaichi appoints just two women to cabinet after becoming Japan’s first female PM
articles.trailText: New leader had promised levels of female representation comparable to those in Iceland, where six of cabinet of 11 are women
articles.summary: Sanae Takaichi became Japan’s first female prime minister but appointed just two women—Satsuki Katayama as finance minister and Kimi Onoda as economic security minister—to her 19-member cabinet, falling short of her pledge to match female representation in Iceland and Finland. An ultra-conservative LDP leader in coalition with a hawkish minor party, Takaichi has championed women’s health yet opposes maiden names, imperial succession changes and same-sex marriage. With women holding only 15.7% of lower-house seats and Japan ranking 118th in the WEF gender gap index, reactions range from guarded optimism to skepticism.

articles.title: Sanae Takaichi: Japan’s first female PM, who cites Thatcher as an influence
articles.trailText: Takaichi is a rightwing China critic who opposes same-sex marriage and led a migration-focused election campaign
articles.summary: Rightwing LDP veteran Sanae Takaichi, 64, won the leadership runoff on 4 October with 237 votes and became Japan’s first female prime minister, eight decades after WWII. Her LDP formed a coalition with radical Nippon Ishin. A self-styled “Thatcher disciple,” she cites Margaret Thatcher and aligns with Shinzo Abe’s revisionist legacy, criticizes China, and worships at Yasukuni shrine. She opposes same-sex marriage, separate surnames and reigning empresses, touts migration restrictions and non-Japanese property bans, and backs aggressive fiscal stimulus after dropping US trade renegotiation.

articles.title: What can Sarkozy expect in La Santé prison and what has he taken with him?
articles.trailText: Former French president will reportedly be held in isolation and has a copy of The Count of Monte Cristo for company
articles.summary: Nicolas Sarkozy begins a five-year term at Paris’s La Santé prison, held in solitary “VIP” isolation in a 10 m2 cell (bed, desk, shower, toilet, limited-view window, landline) with separate exercise yard, gym, library and canteen; can rent a fridge (€7.50/month) and TV (€14.15) and will receive regular meals. He’ll take a Jesus biography, Dumas’s Count of Monte Cristo, earplugs and sweaters. Facing overcrowding (1 100 inmates vs. 657 capacity), he plans to write a book. Lawyers have filed for early release—experts say he could be free within a month.

articles.title: A Trump visit, a creaking coalition and a cost of living crisis: Japan’s new PM needs a fast start
articles.trailText: Sanae Takaichi has made history but will have little time to settle in before negotiating the pitfalls of rising prices, power struggles and a mercurial US president
articles.summary: Sanae Takaichi, Japan’s first female prime minister, inherits a deeply fractured LDP, a cost-of-living crisis and demographic challenges. She formed a pragmatic coalition with the reformist Nippon Ishin party pledging tougher immigration limits, higher defence spending and constitutional reform, while resisting full acceptance of Ishin’s demands on consumption tax cuts and parliamentary seat reductions. Takaichi, pledged to boost women in cabinet, faces scrutiny over just two female ministers, will host Donald Trump in Tokyo and make her international debut at next week’s Apec summit amid pressure to secure non-coalition votes to pass key budgets.

articles.title: Delhi awakes to a toxic haze after Diwali as pollution season begins
articles.trailText: Air breathed by people in the city categorised as ‘severe’ in quality after fireworks contribute to thick smog
articles.summary: Delhi awoke to severe smog as Diwali fireworks pushed its AQI above 500—10 times WHO’s healthy limit—with PM2.5/PM10 spikes reaching 1,800, marking the start of the annual pollution season and the worst Diwali surge in three years. After a 2020 ban, the BJP-led government won court approval to use ‘green crackers’ within time windows, but restrictions were largely flouted. Seasonal haze from vehicles, dust, construction and stubble burning in Punjab/Haryana traps toxic air. Pakistan’s Punjab accused cross-border pollution. The chronic smog inflicts neurological, cardiovascular and respiratory diseases and about 10,000 premature deaths annually among 33 million residents.

articles.title: Death of British overseas territories citizen prompts calls for reform of UK rules
articles.trailText: Family of Robert Baker call for change of healthcare policies that limit NHS access to 10 BOT citizens a year
articles.summary: Robert Baker, a 63-year-old Jamaican-Montserrat BOT dual citizen, died after the UK refused NHS treatment and Montserrat lacked facilities. His family and former Montserrat premier Donaldson Romeo decried UK policies allowing only five to ten BOT citizens per territory annual NHS referrals, requiring territory-led referrals and covering costs. Baker endured inadequate care in Jamaica, including weeks on chairs and unpaid meds. Campaigners urge UK reform, equal NHS access for Montserratians, citing deep healthcare inequalities decades after volcanic devastation.

articles.title: Tuesday briefing: What the sidelining of Prince Andrew says about the future of the royal family
articles.trailText: In today’s newsletter: Prince Andrew has relinquished his royal titles, but what does his stepping aside really mean for the royal family?
articles.summary: After renewed allegations in Virginia Giuffre’s posthumous memoir and reports that Prince Andrew enlisted aides to dig up dirt on her, King Charles announced Andrew would relinquish his Duke of York title but remains legally a prince. MPs and campaigners demand a parliamentary act to strip him of all honours amid fresh police inquiries. Royal expert Stephen Bates traces Andrew’s fall from Falklands war hero and trade envoy to pariah, stressing the scandal undermines the monarchy’s credibility. Charles timed the move ahead of his Vatican visit, while William pushes for a sleeker, more accountable institution to secure the succession.

articles.title: EU criticised for pausing sanctions on Israel in response to Trump Gaza efforts
articles.trailText: Pause on move to freeze preferential trade pact comes amid scramble to shore up fragile ceasefire
articles.summary: EU foreign policy chief Kaja Kallas paused moves to suspend Israel’s preferential trade pact and impose sanctions over Gaza amid a fragile ceasefire tied to Donald Trump’s peace plan. Critics including former senior EU envoys and Human Rights Watch warn this sidelines legal accountability for rights breaches, breaches of the EU-Israel association agreement and an ICJ opinion on occupation. They urge maintaining pressure through restrictive measures, shaping Trump’s plan to address West Bank settlements and committing to a two-state solution in upcoming EU summit talks.

articles.title: ‘Ask your daughters’: Merz defends his call for large-scale deportations
articles.trailText: German chancellor is accused of taking a page from extremist parties with ‘dangerous’ rhetoric on immigration
articles.summary: Chancellor Friedrich Merz’s proposal for “very large scale” migrant deportations—justified by his claim that parents of daughters would back his stance—sparked criticism from his own CDU MEP Dennis Radtke, SPD’s Natalie Pawlik, and Greens MPs Ricarda Lang and Clemens Rostock for echoing far-right AfD rhetoric and stoking racial prejudice. Merz defended the measures as essential for public safety and pledged strict migration controls, while reaffirming the CDU/CSU’s refusal to cooperate with the AfD amid polls showing the far right gaining ground.

articles.title: Ukraine war briefing: Zelenskyy paints Trump meeting as ‘positive’, with Patriot missile deal in works
articles.trailText: Zelenskyy’s comments are in contrast to reports that Trump berated the Ukrainian leader and pushed him to concede territory to Russia. What we know on day 1,336
articles.summary: Ukrainian president Volodymyr Zelenskyy described his White House meeting with Donald Trump as positive, securing a draft contract to purchase 25 Patriot air-defence systems but not Tomahawk missiles. He dismissed reports Trump pressured him to cede territory. Ahead of summits in London and Brussels, Zelenskyy seeks fresh security guarantees. Trump said Ukraine “could” but probably will not defeat Russia, while endorsing calls to freeze front-lines. Meanwhile, Ukraine’s Chernihiv region suffered power losses after a new Russian attack, and the EU advances a €140bn frozen-asset loan plan.

articles.title: ‘Moment of national pride’ as Peter ToRot becomes Papua New Guinea’s first saint
articles.trailText: Thousands celebrate across the country and in Rome after Pope Leo canonised Peter ToRot in what the prime minister called a ‘historic moment of pride, faith and inspiration’
articles.summary: Papua New Guinea celebrated the canonisation of Peter ToRot, its first saint, at ceremonies in St Peter’s Square and communities nationwide, hailed by PM James Marape as a ‘historic moment of pride, faith and inspiration.’ Born in 1912 in Rakunai, ToRot served as a Catholic catechist under Japanese occupation, secretly leading services at a “bush church” and championing monogamous marriage. Imprisoned and killed by lethal injection in 1945, he was canonised by Pope Leo in one of Pope Francis’s final acts. More than 90% of PNG is Christian. Clergy and devotees across Port Moresby and villages honoured his legacy of courage, devotion and moral leadership, viewing him as a model for family unity and spiritual resilience.

articles.title: Zelenskyy to visit London for talks before expected Trump-Putin summit
articles.trailText: Ukrainian president will seek to win security guarantees at ‘coalition of the willing’ meeting before any US-Russia talks
articles.summary: Volodymyr Zelenskiy travels to London Friday to rally a “coalition of the willing” for binding security guarantees ahead of an anticipated Trump–Putin summit in Budapest. Frustrated by Trump’s Washington rebuff of Tomahawk missiles and echoing Kremlin demands—citing pressure to cede Donbas—Zelenskiy will press for additional US Patriot air-defence batteries funded from frozen Russian assets. EU foreign affairs chief Kaja Kallas and leaders including Macron insist Ukraine must be at any peace table. Brussels ministers will debate a €140 bn “reparation loan” using Russian reserves to sustain Kyiv.

articles.title: Louvre heist puts pressure on French government over museum security
articles.trailText: Justice minister says ‘we have failed’ after thieves take seven minutes to steal priceless jewels from museum
articles.summary: The French government faces criticism after four thieves stole eight priceless 19th-century imperial jewels from the Louvre in seven minutes, using a furniture hoist to access the Apollo gallery. A state audit revealed persistent security delays, with video surveillance covering only a third of rooms. Justice Minister Darmanin admitted failure; Interior Minister Nuñez ordered nationwide security reviews. A parliamentary inquiry was proposed. Investigators track evidence left at the scene; President Macron vowed capture. Unions warn chronic underinvestment in museum security jeopardises collections and staff.

articles.title: Israel will disarm Hamas and demilitarise Gaza, says Netanyahu
articles.trailText: US seeks to downplay seriousness of attacks over weekend as Palestinian officials arrive in Cairo for further peace talks
articles.summary: Benjamin Netanyahu told the Knesset he will disarm Hamas, demilitarise Gaza and win hostages’ return as part of a US-brokered deal giving Israel control over Gaza. Jared Kushner and VP Vance flew in after a Hamas attack killed two Israeli soldiers and Israeli strikes killed 44 Palestinians, breaching the ceasefire. Palestinian officials are in Cairo to negotiate a technocratic authority over Gaza opposed by Hamas; crossings remain open for aid except Rafah, but deliveries stay far below the 600-truck target. Hamas denies involvement in some breaches, rejects full disarmament and risks unilateral Israeli action if it fails to comply.

articles.title: Mirosław Chojecki obituary
articles.trailText: Dissident publisher who smuggled presses, dollars, broadcasting equipment, books and audio cassettes into communist Poland
articles.summary: Mirosław Chojecki (1949–2025), Polish dissident publisher, co-founded the underground Independent Publishing House NOWa in 1977 to print uncensored literature by blacklisted authors and foreign writers. A KOR activist, he backed the 1980 Gdańsk shipyard strikes that birthed Solidarity. After martial law in 1981, from Paris—as Solidarity’s smuggling minister (cryptonym QRGUIDE)—he secretly shipped presses, funds, broadcasting gear, books and cassettes into Poland. Returning in 1990, he launched Media Kontakt, founded the Jewish Motifs festival, advised the culture minister, and was awarded the Order of the White Eagle in 2022.

articles.title: Colombia recalls US ambassador amid spat with Trump over strikes on alleged drug boats
articles.trailText: Feud casts doubt on future of counter-narcotics and security cooperation between two countries, analysts warn
articles.summary: Colombia’s president Gustavo Petro recalled his ambassador from Washington after Donald Trump branded him an “illegal drug dealer,” vowed to cut aid, impose new tariffs and even threaten military intervention over US strikes on suspected narcotics boats that killed a Colombian fisherman in territorial waters. Analysts warn the dispute—coming amid Colombia’s worst security crisis in a decade and sharply reduced US counter-narcotics funding—marks a serious rupture, jeopardizing joint operations and intelligence sharing.

articles.title: ‘Smash, grab, melt it down’: how material value likely motivated the Louvre heist
articles.trailText: Experts say thieves would struggle to find a buyer if the stolen goods remained intact
articles.summary: In a daring daylight raid, eight Napoleonic jewellery pieces were stolen from the Louvre by masked thieves on scooters. Experts say material value, not notoriety, drove the smash-and-grab, with weaker museum security compared with fortified jewelry stores. They anticipate melting down or recutting gems to erase provenance, since intact pieces are unsellable. A leaked audit flags outdated cameras, upgrade delays and architectural constraints in the 232-year-old building. As post-Covid budget cuts hamper cultural security, institutions remain exposed to repeat smash-and-grab tactics without fortress-style, layered defenses.

articles.title: At least 135 mutilated bodies of Palestinians had been held at notorious Israeli jail, say Gaza officials
articles.trailText: Documents indicate they came from Sde Teiman, which already faces allegations of torture and unlawful deaths
articles.summary: Gaza’s health ministry reports that 135 mutilated Palestinian bodies returned by Israel were held at Sde Teiman military detention center in the Negev, where previous testimonies cited torture, shackling, blindfolding, and unlawful deaths. Tags on body bags, written in Hebrew, indicate DNA tests and origin at Sde Teiman. Examinations reveal blindfolds, bound limbs, gunshot wounds at point-blank range, tank‐track crushing and signs of hanging. Health officials and human rights groups demand an independent international investigation into systematic torture, summary executions and accountability, while the Israeli army has opened limited probes.

articles.title: ‘It hasn’t inspired’: turnout concerns grow close to Ireland’s presidential election
articles.trailText: High rate of spoilt ballots also probable as poll shows 49% of voters do not feel represented by either candidate
articles.summary: With four days before Ireland’s Oct 24 presidential vote, polls show independent left-wing candidate Catherine Connolly leading with 38% versus Fine Gael’s Heather Humphreys on 20% and Fianna Fáil’s Jim Gavin on 5% (still on the ballot). Yet 49% of voters feel unrepresented, 12% plan to abstain and 6% expect to spoil their ballots amid a lacklustre campaign deemed “uninspiring” by political scientists. Connolly has energised young supporters via podcasts but faces scrutiny over a 2018 Syria trip and past legal work; Humphreys touts unity and Protestant heritage but is criticised as anodyne after 12 years in government.

articles.title: ‘I wanted to do something more meaningful’: the Chinese nationals fighting for Ukraine
articles.trailText: Volunteers defy their government and public opinion in China to risk their lives for an adversary of Beijing’s main geopolitical partner
articles.summary: The 8 July 2024 Russian strike on Kyiv’s Okhmatdyt children’s hospital killed 43, spurring Tim, a 43-year-old Chinese volunteer, from delivering aid to enlisting in Ukraine’s army, where he now engineers drones. Like dozens of other Chinese nationals driven by sympathy for Ukraine and disillusionment with China’s censorship, economic woes and state propaganda, they navigate indirect routes and legal risk to serve. Fan, a 39-year-old former entrepreneur, used VPNs and ChatGPT to find Ukraine, becoming a drone operator and guard. Despite Beijing’s neutrality and pro-Russia media sway, these volunteers face possible retribution at home as they fight for a new life and to change perceptions of China.

articles.title: How the Louvre museum robbery happened in video, photographs and maps
articles.trailText: Eight pieces stolen, but crown of Napoleon III’s wife dropped by the fleeing thieves
articles.summary: On 20 October, four balaclava-clad thieves executed a seven-minute daylight raid on the Louvre’s Apollo gallery, using a ladder and power tools to smash cases and steal eight Napoleonic jewels—necklaces, tiaras, earrings and a brooch from Empresses Marie-Louise, Eugénie and Marie-Amelie—before fleeing on motorbikes. They dropped Eugénie’s diamond-and-emerald crown but left the $60m Regent diamond. The museum closed as 60 investigators probed the professional raid, reigniting debate over France’s museum security and prompting a multimillion-euro overhaul.

articles.title: Sanae Takaichi on course to become Japan’s first female PM after new coalition deal
articles.trailText: Officials confirm reports that Takaichi’s Liberal Democratic party will join forces with rightwing Nippon Ishin
articles.summary: Sanae Takaichi is set to become Japan's first female prime minister after the LDP formalized a coalition with rightwing Nippon Ishin, overcoming Komeito's defection. With 231 lower-house seats, she's all but assured victory in Tuesday's vote. The pact advances her hawkish China stance, plans to tighten immigration, revise the pacifist constitution, and reshape security. Ishin demands Osaka as a secondary emergency capital, social-security reform, a food-tax suspension and a ban on corporate party donations. Takaichi's minority government faces friction over spending, tax cuts and policy reforms as she prepares for Trump's visit and the Apec summit.

articles.title: Tensions mount as Alassane Ouattara seeks fourth term in Ivory Coast vote
articles.trailText: Protests have been banned and opposition figures sidelined as 83-year-old president ignores calls to step down
articles.summary: Ivory Coast president Alassane Ouattara, 83, is seeking a fourth term on 25 October amid banned protests. Critics decry sidelining of opponents—Simone Gbagbo faces repression, Laurent Gbagbo’s legal woes bar his run, and ex-banker Tidjane Thiam was disqualified over nationality. Supporters laud Ouattara’s infrastructure boom—Abidjan bridges, rural electrification—and economic gains: poverty fell from 55% in 2011 to 37% in 2024. Dissenters cite soaring living costs, inequality and free-speech crackdowns. Pro-Russia, anti-France disinformation campaigns fuel unrest. With over 44,000 security forces deployed, voters fear a foregone Ouattara victory amid “democratic fatigue.”

articles.title: British troops to get powers to shoot down drones near military bases
articles.trailText: Defence secretary will announce measures to combat threat of unmanned aircraft after incursions in Europe
articles.summary: Defence Secretary John Healey will introduce measures in the armed forces bill granting UK troops authority to shoot down unidentified drones over military sites—and potentially civilian airports—after recent incursions: 21 unarmed Russian drones forced airport closures in Poland, sightings over Danish and Nordic bases, and unexplained UAVs at RAF Lakenheath and Fairford. Risks to civilians are high, exemplified by a Polish F-16 missile hitting a house. Healey also warns Russia has launched over 5,500 attack drones into Ukraine this year—3,000 in October alone—targeting energy infrastructure and expanding aggression into Europe via airspace violations and election interference.

articles.title: Hong Kong: two killed after cargo plane veers off runway into sea while landing
articles.trailText: Authorities say plane collided with patrol vehicle, taking it with it as it ditched in sea
articles.summary: An Emirates Boeing 747 cargo flight (wet-leased from Turkey’s ACT Airlines) arriving from Dubai veered off Hong Kong’s north runway at 4am on Oct. 20, crashed through a perimeter fence, and struck a security patrol car before ditching into 7m-deep water. Airport staff dispatched over 200 rescuers to retrieve two men from the submerged vehicle—both later died (aged 30 and 41)—while the four crew were evacuated uninjured. Authorities, deeming weather and runway conditions normal, have launched an investigation (including possible criminal inquiries). The runway was briefly closed; no cargo was aboard.

articles.title: Monday briefing: ‘New levels of misery’ for Ukraine’s soldiers as diplomatic wrangling drags on
articles.trailText: In today’s newsletter: Trump’s stance on the war continues to oscillate while Zelenskyy’s infantry face gruelling stints at the ‘zero line’ amid increasingly lethal Russian attacks
articles.summary: In today’s briefing Donald Trump’s stance on the Russia-Ukraine war oscillates—hinting at Tomahawk missile support for Kyiv, then echoing Putin after a tense White House meeting—while Ukraine’s infantry at the ‘zero line’ face unprecedented misery. Soldiers endure months in cramped dugouts under high-precision drone and glide-bomb attacks, and constant small-unit infiltration. Despite frozen frontlines and heavy casualties, neither side has achieved a strategic breakthrough. The war remains a brutal attritional fight, where diplomatic wrangling in DC and Moscow matters, but ultimate leverage lies with whoever can hold the frozen front.

articles.title: ‘You can learn a lot by losing’: meet Don Manuel, the 104-year-old chess player
articles.trailText: Manuel Álvarez Escudero, from Spain, describes how the board game has provided him with a lifetime of fun and friendship
articles.summary: Manuel Álvarez Escudero, 104, is Spain’s oldest active registered chess player, who learned the game at 16 amid Spain’s civil war. He meets weekly at his Valdebernardo chess club in Madrid, where homemade walker in tow he enjoys matches, sharpens his mind and forges friendships of diverse ages and backgrounds. An engineer by training, Álvarez credits chess with mental acuity and social bonds, having survived wartime hardships and family tragedies. He avoids smoking and drinking, indulges only in football pools and cards, and believes both winning and learning from losses define a long, rewarding life.

articles.title: European leaders near deal to use frozen Russian assets for Ukraine
articles.trailText: Plans to secure loan with Russian funds ‘moving to happy resolution’, says Polish foreign minister
articles.summary: European Commission has proposed a €140bn interest-free loan to Ukraine secured against €183bn of frozen Russian central bank assets held at Euroclear. G7 finance ministers, including the UK’s Rachel Reeves, discussed the plan in Washington, while EU leaders will debate it in Brussels in late October. The scheme, framed as a wartime reparations loan, is not confiscation and requires G7 underwriting—Belgium demands risk‐sharing guarantees to avoid legal claims. US participation remains uncertain. Germany and the UK now back using the assets to fund Ukraine’s defense from April 2026, with an agreement targeted by year‐end.

articles.title: Trump suggests carving up Ukraine’s Donbas region to end war after meeting with Zelenskyy
articles.trailText: Trump made the comments after a tense meeting with Zelenskyy in which the Ukraine leader failed to secure supplies of Tomahawk missiles
articles.summary: After a tense White House meeting, Donald Trump told reporters he favored carving up Ukraine’s Donbas region—leaving most territory under Russian control—and freezing current battle lines to stop the fighting. He urged both sides to “go home” and negotiate later, reversing his September stance that Ukraine could reclaim all land. Trump’s shift followed a phone call with Vladimir Putin and mirrored Putin’s proposed swap of Donetsk and Luhansk for parts of Zaporizhzhia and Kherson. Zelenskyy left Washington empty-handed, failing to secure long-range Tomahawk missiles, and appealed to Western allies for decisive support.

articles.title: Ukraine war briefing: Energy war continues with strikes on Russian oil and gas plants
articles.trailText: Russian attacks hit coal mine in Dnipropetrovsk region and Chernihiv power grid; Trump flips back to accommodating Putin. What we know on day 1,335
articles.summary: Ukrainian drones struck Russia’s Orenburg gas plant and Novokuibyshevsk oil refinery, igniting fires, suspending gas intake from Kazakhstan and damaging key refining units. Meanwhile, Russian forces bombarded Ukraine’s Dnipropetrovsk coal mine—evacuating 192 miners unharmed—and cut power to 55,000 homes in Chernihiv. Kyiv and Moscow exchange energy tit-for-tat as the EU readies its 19th sanctions package targeting Russia’s shadow tanker fleet and banning LNG imports by 2027, while the G7 aligns on inspection rules and penalties for evasion. In US politics, Donald Trump, after speaking with Putin, urged Zelenskiy to cede territory, retreating from prior pro-Ukraine rhetoric.

articles.title: Rodrigo Paz Pereira wins Bolivia’s presidential runoff marking a new shift to the right
articles.trailText: Sunday’s election marked the first time since 2005 that no candidate from Evo Morales’ Mas party was on the ballot
articles.summary: Centre-right senator Rodrigo Paz Pereira (PDC) won Bolivia’s presidential runoff with 54.6% over Jorge Quiroga’s 45.4%, ending 20 years of MAS rule. The preliminary count awaits official ratification within a week. Son of ex-president Jaime Paz Zamora, he campaigned as an outsider on “popular capitalism”: low-interest loans, debt forgiveness, tariff cuts, anti-corruption. His PDC holds the most seats but lacks a majority. His running mate Edman Lara leveraged TikTok fame as an anti-corruption crusader. Paz Pereira vows stronger ties with the US, job creation, legal security, and rule of law, including applying arrest warrants against Evo Morales equally.

articles.title: Scramble to shore up ceasefire as Israel hits Gaza with deadly raids
articles.trailText: IDF says attack followed Hamas forces killing two soldiers, but both sides say they are committed to ceasefire
articles.summary: Israel launched waves of airstrikes in Gaza after Hamas killed two soldiers in Rafah, killing at least 33 Palestinians, cutting off all aid and closing the Rafah crossing in a sharp escalation of the fragile ceasefire. Egypt and senior US officials, possibly including the vice-president, are rushing to prevent a full collapse of the Sharm-el-Sheikh truce, to which both sides still profess loyalty. Disputes over returning 28 hostages’ remains—Hamas has handed over 12—persist amid a worsening humanitarian crisis and soaring Gaza death toll.

articles.title: Landslide win for pro-EU Turkish Cypriot candidate raises hopes for peace
articles.trailText: Veteran leftwinger Tufan Erhürman wins after campaign on reviving stalled talks to reunify island
articles.summary: Veteran leftwing pro-EU leader Tufan Erhürman won a landslide victory with 62.8% over incumbent nationalist Ersin Tatar’s 35.8%, signaling a shift from Ankara-backed, isolationist policies. Campaigning on reviving UN-brokered reunification talks stalled since 2017, Erhürman promised confidence-building measures and a bi-communal, bi-zonal federation under EU norms. His win thrilled secular voters and younger Turkish settlers disillusioned by Turkey’s Islamist tilt, raising Greek Cypriot expectations for renewed negotiations. Analysts view this outcome as a potential breakthrough after decades of division post-1974 and a test of the south’s readiness to engage with a charismatic Turkish Cypriot leader committed to unity.

articles.title: Louvre heist: hunt on for thieves after eight ‘priceless’ jewellery pieces stolen
articles.trailText: Necklace given by Napoleon to his wife among items taken from Paris museum in highly professional daylight raid
articles.summary: On 19 October, four masked thieves staged a seven-minute daylight heist at the Louvre’s ornate Apollon gallery, using a truck, aerial lift and power tools to smash two glass cases. They absconded with eight historic jewels—including an emerald-and-diamond necklace Napoleon gifted Marie-Louise, a diadem of Empress Eugénie (1,354 diamonds, 56 emeralds, later found broken nearby) and sapphire pieces tied to Queen Hortense. Alarms sounded and gear was abandoned. Prosecutors have opened an inquiry, reviewing CCTV as police hunt the experienced gang. President Macron vowed recovery and justice.

articles.title: Palestinians in Gaza fear ceasefire ‘could collapse at any moment’
articles.trailText: Wave of Israeli airstrikes leaves nine-day truce teetering as residents recall previous dashed peace hopes
articles.summary: After nine days of truce between Israel and Hamas, a sudden wave of Israeli airstrikes—allegedly in response to Hamas fire at troops in southern Gaza—has shattered Gaza residents’ relief. Displaced father of four Ismail Baba recalls dashed hopes from past ceasefires as civilians fear full-scale war’s return. Recent shelling killed 11 members of the Abu Shaaban family, including seven children, when their car strayed past a poorly marked withdrawal line. Despite ongoing violence and uncertainty over phase-two terms of the U.S.-drafted plan, Gazans cling to fragile optimism that a lasting truce could restore safety, aid and future reconstruction.

articles.title: Gaza war has caused huge shifts in Middle East – and that may just be the beginning
articles.trailText: Trump’s 20-point plan is forcing Middle East rivals to set aside differences and collaborate after years of competition
articles.summary: Gaza war’s ceasefire and Trump’s 20-point plan have reset regional politics: US leverage, Qatar and Turkey’s pressure on Hamas produced a roadmap, elevating Erdoğan and Qatar in Washington’s good books. Egypt, Turkey, possibly Jordan—and even Iraq under PM al-Sudani—offer troops for a Gaza stabilization force, signaling a drift from Iran. Tehran’s proxies are weakened. Tony Blair’s role in a Palestinian peace council sparks debate. The truce unlocks prospects for Gulf-Mediterranean land connections and expanded Abraham Accords, potentially including Saudi Arabia.

articles.title: Chinese embassy approval could be unlawful if UK ministers gave advance assurances
articles.trailText: Exclusive: If Keir Starmer made promises to China it could constitute ‘predetermination’, Lord Banner legal opinion concludes
articles.summary: Legal opinion by Lord Banner warns that approving China’s proposed 20,000 m² embassy near Tower Bridge could be unlawful if UK ministers, including PM Keir Starmer or housing secretary Steve Reed, gave pre-application assurances—constituting predetermination. The Guardian-obtained advice, commissioned by local opponents, urges preservation of any records and warns of a judicial-review challenge. China, which refiled permission after Labour’s 2024 election, has protested delays, but Downing Street denies promises were made. IPAC’s Luke de Pulford cautions that unlawful guarantees risk a “catastrophic” court defeat. Govt also denies political interference in a related espionage case.

articles.title: Nicolas Sarkozy to enter prison for criminal conspiracy over Libyan funding
articles.trailText: Former French president set to start five-year sentence for scheme to obtain campaign funds from Muammar Gaddafi’s regime
articles.summary: Nicolas Sarkozy, France’s centre-right president from 2007 to 2012 and the first postwar French head of state jailed, will report to La Santé prison on Tuesday to begin his five-year sentence for criminal conspiracy over a secret pact with Muammar Gaddafi’s regime to fund his 2007 campaign. Held in an individual cell in solitary for security, he’ll forgo a mobile phone, have limited TV, one hour daily yard time and two weekly visits. Having appealed, his lawyers will seek release under judicial supervision or home detention pending a new trial in six months.

articles.title: Martin Mansergh obituary
articles.trailText: Former political adviser to the Irish taoiseach who was at the heart of negotiations for the Good Friday agreement in 1998
articles.summary: Martin Mansergh, a British-educated historian and Irish civil servant, died aged 78 of a heart attack. As political adviser to taoiseachs Charles Haughey, Albert Reynolds and Bertie Ahern, he opened covert channels to the IRA from 1988, shaping the 1993 Downing Street Declaration and drafting the 1998 Good Friday Agreement. He later served in the Seanad (2002–07) and Dáil (2007–11), held junior ministerial portfolios and chaired the Decade of Centenaries committee. Author of essays on Anglo-Irish peace, he is survived by his wife Elizabeth, six children and 12 grandchildren.

articles.title: Western intelligence agencies eye neo-fascist fight clubs: ‘an international white supremacist movement’
articles.trailText: Security services are monitoring ‘active clubs’ as they move across borders to spread their extremist ideology
articles.summary: Five Eyes agencies are tracking 'Active Clubs,' transnational neo-Nazi fight gangs styled as mixed martial arts groups that use Telegram to coordinate propaganda, training and meet-ups across Canada and the U.S. Canadian chapter Nationalist-13’s low-production video features American Patriot Front affiliates pumping weights and sparring, underscoring expanding cross-border ties. CSIS briefings warn members travel between countries to train, echoing networks like Atomwaffen and The Base, boosting fears of coordinated extremist violence. Experts tie Active Clubs to Rob Rundo’s Rise Above Movement, highlighting their shared ideology and propaganda have expanded chapters in 27 countries, marking an escalating international white supremacist threat.

articles.title: How the west can stop the global south being strangled by debt | Heather Stewart
articles.trailText: Labour would do well to remember its manifesto promise to revive Britain’s global leadership on development
articles.summary: With rising borrowing costs and western aid cuts, global south governments spend an average 45% of revenues (up to 70% in low-income states) on debt service, far overshadowing education and health spending. Ethiopia’s failed $1bn debt restructure and threats of English-court suits exemplify private lenders’ stalling tactics. Advocates demand IMF debt-sustainability reform, G20 Common Framework overhaul (capping repayments at 10% of revenues), and legal changes to block creditor lawsuits and pari passu attacks. Despite UK and South Africa’s convening roles, Washington’s IMF/World Bank meetings yielded no binding solutions, prompting calls for Labour to leverage its future G20 presidency.

articles.title: Historic town founded by Black Colombians fleeing slavery eyes second ‘independence’
articles.trailText: San Basilio de Palenque calls itself ‘the first free Black territory in the Americas’ – a referendum next month could win its own local government
articles.summary: San Basilio de Palenque, founded circa 1603 by Benkos Biohó’s cimarrones and formally recognized in 1713 as the first free Black territory, will vote on 30 November to break from Mahates and become an autonomous municipality. Home to 4,000 residents, UNESCO-listed for its Drum and Cultural Expressions festival, it preserves the unique Palenquero language (Spanish, Portuguese, Bantu mix). Locals hope fiscal control will fund water, sanitation and paved roads, but fear community division, untested mayoral elections, tax authority and the fate of their ancestral justice system (Guardia Cimarrona).

articles.title: Bolivia to vote in presidential runoff that will turn it to the right
articles.trailText: End of almost two decades of leftist rule could revive ‘war on drugs’ in change of approach to coca cultivation
articles.summary: Bolivia’s first presidential runoff on Oct 19 ends nearly 20 years of leftist Movimiento al Socialismo rule, pitting centre-right senator Rodrigo Paz Pereira against rightwing ex-president Jorge "Tuto" Quiroga. Both vow closer US ties to tackle a 25% inflation crisis and fuel shortages, reinstating a "war on drugs" and possibly the DEA. A key issue is coca cultivation: candidates distinguish between traditional Yungas coca and trafficking-prone Chapare fields. Evo Morales, evading an arrest warrant for alleged rape in Chapare, is sheltered by coca unions like CSCIOB, which warn against criminalising growers. Whoever wins on Nov 8 confronts economic collapse and coca policy shifts.

articles.title: Ukraine war briefing: Repairs begin in bid to restore power to Zaporizhzhia nuclear plant
articles.trailText: UN watchdog says Russia and Ukraine have established special ceasefire zones to allow the repairs to be safely carried out. What we know on day 1,334
articles.summary: Repairs to off-site power lines at Ukraine’s Russia-occupied Zaporizhzhia nuclear plant commenced under IAEA-brokered local ceasefires after a 10th grid outage since 23 Sept, with restoration expected in about a week to safeguard cooling systems now on backup diesel. Meanwhile, Russia launched 3 missiles and 164 drones overnight, downing 136; two injured in Sumy. Zelenskyy’s White House meeting with Trump yielded no Tomahawk missiles, prompting Ukrainian disappointment. Exiled Belarusian leader Sviatlana Tsikhanouskaya warned Putin won’t negotiate and urged US support for Belarusian democracy.

articles.title: Israel has violated ceasefire 47 times and killed 38 Palestinians, says Gaza media office
articles.trailText: Authorities urge UN to intervene ‘to protect unarmed civilian populations’ after attack on bus that killed 11
articles.summary: Since the early October truce, Gaza’s media office says Israel has violated the ceasefire 47 times, killing 38 Palestinians and wounding 143, including 11 members of one family killed near Zeitoun after allegedly crossing the ‘yellow line’. Gaza authorities urged the UN to intervene.
