Greenpeace-commissioned satellite images analysed by McKenzie Intelligence Services found no shelling craters, contradicting Russian claims of Ukrainian fire. The IAEA warns generators have fuel for only ten days. Observers say Moscow’s political aim is to force a safety crisis and justify integrating the site into the Russian grid, raising meltdown risks if cooling fails.

articles.title: ‘A life of captivity’: Canada refuses marine park’s request to export its whales to China
articles.trailText: Fisheries minister says rehoming Marineland’s cetaceans in China would only ‘perpetuate the treatment’ the whales have endured
articles.summary: Canada has refused Marineland’s request to export its 30 beluga whales to China, citing potential mistreatment. Fisheries Minister Joanne Thompson denied the sale to Chimelong Ocean Kingdom, warning that continued captivity would harm the whales’ health. Marineland, home to one of the largest captive whale populations, has seen 20 cetacean deaths since 2019 and halted summer operations. A 2019 federal ban bars whale sales, breeding and captivity. Ontario inspectors made over 200 visits and issued 33 compliance orders. Critics, including former trainer Phil Demers, urge relocation under stricter welfare laws—possibly in the U.S.—and government custody to ensure proper care.

articles.title: French military detain two after boarding Russia-linked oil tanker suspected of launching drones
articles.trailText: Tanker, named on list of ‘shadow fleet’ vessels, may have been launchpad for drones that closed Denmark airports
articles.summary: French military boarded the Boracay, a Benin-flagged oil tanker tied to Russia’s “shadow fleet,” seizing two crew (captain and first mate) after they failed to justify the vessel’s nationality and refused cooperation. Carrying 750,000 barrels from Primorsk to India, the ship is suspected as a drone launchpad that closed Copenhagen and Aalborg airports on Sept 22 and 24. Now under investigation in Brest and diverted to Saint-Nazaire, it faces sanctions amid a wider European probe into Russia-linked drone incursions. President Macron backed the inquiry while the Kremlin denied awareness.

articles.title: A broader view of US Jews’ support for Israel | Letter
articles.trailText: Letter: Responding to an article by Mark Mazower, Roger Fisken writes that the six-day war led to a disastrous response from the Arab states
articles.summary: In this letter, Roger Fisken challenges Mark Mazower’s portrayal of US Jewish support for Israel as focused on redressing 1930s wrongs, arguing it stemmed from a far longer history of European antisemitic oppression—from Russian-empire pogroms to the 1929 Hebron massacre—and the Holocaust’s culmination of that suffering. He credits this legacy with Israel’s 1948 founding and defense against Arab assaults. While Mazower warns the 1967 Six-Day War victory risked being Pyrrhic, Fisken asserts the Arab states’ Khartoum resolution—no peace, negotiation or recognition—proved the true disaster, damaging both Palestinians and Israelis.

articles.title: Israel says ‘last opportunity’ for Gaza City residents to leave
articles.trailText: Defence minister issues warning, while Hamas reportedly considers seeking amendments to Trump plan
articles.summary: Israel’s military has issued its final evacuation order for Gaza City residents ahead of an intensified offensive, with Defence Minister Israel Katz warning those who stay will be deemed terrorists. At least 46 people were killed, including 36 in Gaza City, and the ICRC suspended operations amid heavy bombardment. International law experts say forced displacement orders don’t strip civilians of protection. Israel also closed the southern–northern route, effectively splitting Gaza. Meanwhile Hamas is reportedly considering amendments to Trump’s 20-point ceasefire plan—demanding disarmament, hostages release, and an Israeli withdrawal—while international mediators prepare talks in Doha.

articles.title: General strike against 13-hour work day brings Greece to a halt
articles.trailText: Transport systems, hospitals and schools hit, as workers say laws kill hopes of work-life balance
articles.summary: A 24-hour general strike paralysed Greece on Oct 1 as public- and private-sector workers, unions and civil servants protested government plans to legalise 13-hour workdays. Transport, hospitals, schools and ports came to a standstill as unions decried the measure—backed by PM Kyriakos Mitsotakis and labour minister Niki Kerameus—to boost “flexibility” by extending daily hours by up to five extra. Critics warn the change, set for passage this month, will exacerbate burnout, labour abuses and low wages (minimum €880/month) in a country already near the top of EU work hours. Union leaders liken it to “modern slavery.”

articles.title: Philippines earthquake death toll rises to at least 69 as Cebu hospitals struggle
articles.trailText: More than 700 aftershocks recorded while rescuers search for casualties in coastal city of Bogo
articles.summary: A magnitude-6.9 quake hit north Cebu near Bogo on Sept. 30, killing at least 69 people—30 in Bogo, 22 in San Remigio, 10 in Medellin, 5 in Tabogon and 1 each in Sogod and Tabuelan—and triggering over 700 aftershocks. Hospitals overflow under blue tents as rescuers drill through collapsed motels and landslide sites amid heavy rain and power cuts. Cebu authorities call for medical volunteers, impose price controls on essentials, and President Marcos pledges swift aid to quake-affected communities.

articles.title: Europe in ‘most dangerous situation’ since second world war, Danish PM warns
articles.trailText: Mette Frederiksen tells EU leaders all countries are affected by ‘Russian hybrid war’ via drones or sabotage
articles.summary: At an EU summit in Copenhagen, Danish prime minister Mette Frederiksen warned Europe faces its most dangerous security crisis since WWII amid a “Russian hybrid war” of drone incursions and sabotage across member states. She urged unity on defence by 2030, backed by proposals for a €800bn plan including a “drone wall,” eastern-flank surveillance, missile defences and a space shield. While Emmanuel Macron stressed cautious deterrence, leaders are split over a €140bn EU loan to Ukraine funded by frozen Russian assets—supported by Finland, Sweden and Ireland but opposed by France, Belgium and Luxembourg on legal and financial-risk grounds.

articles.title: The Moldova mandate: the former Soviet republic opted to defy Russia. Here’s why
articles.trailText: Voters have confirmed they want to be in the EU club. In standing up to Putin, they may have reminded Europe why its democracy is precious
articles.summary: Moldova’s recent vote delivered a decisive pro-EU mandate: President Maia Sandu’s PAS won an outright parliamentary majority, empowering reforms toward EU accession by 2030. Moscow’s campaign—spanning propaganda, cyber-attacks, vote-buying and leveraging the Orthodox Church and Transnistria—failed to sway a populace weary of energy shocks, double-digit inflation and a high refugee burden. With 24% still backing pro-Russia lists, Moldova remains vulnerable to hybrid meddling. Yet younger voters, fearing Russian expansion, see EU membership as existential. Observers warn interference will persist and note the EU’s slow decision-making, but Moldova’s resilience spotlights the bloc’s democratic appeal.

articles.title: UK government wins £122m pandemic case against Michelle Mone-linked firm over faulty PPE
articles.trailText: Trial heard 25m surgical gowns supplied by PPE Medpro to protect NHS staff were unusable and could ‘seriously harm or kill patients’
articles.summary: The UK high court has ordered PPE Medpro, linked to peer Michelle Mone and husband Doug Barrowman, to repay £122m for 25m surgical gowns supplied under a 2020 VIP-lane contract. Mrs Justice Cockerill ruled the gowns were unsterile and invalidly CE-marked, risking patient safety. PPE Medpro, now in administration with under £1m in funds, has until 15 October to repay. A separate £8m storage cost claim was dismissed. The National Crime Agency’s investigation into possible criminal wrongdoing continues amid Mone and Barrowman’s denials.

articles.title: Pope Leo criticizes Trump’s hardline immigration policies: ‘I don’t know if that’s pro-life’
articles.trailText: Pope questions what it means to be ‘pro-life’ amid the ‘inhuman treatment of immigrants’ in the US
articles.summary: Pope Leo, the first American pontiff, publicly challenged Donald Trump’s hardline immigration measures, questioning whether opposing abortion while endorsing the ‘inhuman treatment of immigrants’ aligns with Catholic ‘pro-life’ doctrine. Speaking at Castel Gandolfo, he emphasized life’s sanctity from conception to natural death and reiterated that support for the death penalty also contradicts pro-life teaching. Responding to the Chicago archdiocese’s decision to honor Democratic Senator Dick Durbin for his immigration advocacy—opposed by conservative bishops—Leo called for evaluating leaders’ broader service. Durbin ultimately declined the award, citing divisions within the Church over immigration policy.

articles.title: China replaces high-level diplomat after reported detention
articles.trailText: Liu Jianchao, previously tipped to be next foreign minister, has not been seen publicly in months
articles.summary: China’s ruling CCP quietly replaced Liu Jianchao as head of its International Department two months after he vanished during a July overseas trip and was reportedly detained on corruption and party-discipline charges. An Oxford-educated, English-fluent diplomat once tipped to become foreign minister, Liu’s personal profile was taken offline without announcement. His successor, Liu Haixing, former European Department director, now emerges as a potential future foreign minister. The unexplained purge follows the 2023 ouster of ex-FM Qin Gang and underscores Xi Jinping’s intensified graft crackdown, which has disciplined over six million officials since 2012.

articles.title: Pro-Palestine flotilla heading towards Gaza ‘harassed by Israeli naval boats’
articles.trailText: Account of ‘intimidatory operation’ comes as Italy and Greece repeat call for Israel to guarantee safety of flotilla
articles.summary: The Global Sumud Flotilla, carrying around 500 activists including Greta Thunberg and Ada Colau, reports that Israeli naval vessels circled its lead boat north of Egypt, jamming communications in an ‘intimidatory operation.’ Italy and Greece have urged Israel to guarantee participant safety and accept handover of its humanitarian cargo—offers the flotilla rejects, insisting its goal is to challenge the 2009 naval blockade of Gaza. Spain’s navy shadows the convoy after Italy withdrew its warship. Israel warns the mission risks undermining a US-brokered peace effort and has elite Shayetet 13 forces on standby.

articles.title: ‘This is strength’: stories of enslaved Africans in Grenada will be made into searchable archive
articles.trailText: Depths of Paradise project backed by British family and created by Stephen Lewis, a descendant of survivors
articles.summary: Stephen Lewis, a Grenadian descendant of enslaved survivors, is creating Depths of Paradise, the first searchable archive combining over 1,000 enslaved Africans’ narratives with records of British plantation owners compensated after the 1834 abolition. Supported by the Trevelyan family—who publicly apologized for their ancestors’ slaveholding and funded £100,000 in reparations—the database uses wills, letters and UCL’s Legacies of British Slavery to fill historical gaps. Aimed at schools, researchers and diaspora tracing genealogy, it features stories like Rebecca Ahmuty’s self-manumission. Backers hope it sparks wider digitisation of Caribbean archives ahead of the 2026 Commonwealth meeting and advances reparative justice.

articles.title: Taiwan now biggest importer of Russian naphtha despite being Ukraine ally
articles.trailText: Island imported $1.3bn of crude oil product in first half of 2025 despite joining sanctions against Moscow, report finds
articles.summary: Despite joining sanctions on Moscow and backing Ukraine, Taiwan imported $1.3 bn of Russian naphtha in H1 2025—six times its 2022 monthly average and 44 percent more than H1 2024. Naphtha derivatives are vital for Taiwan’s semiconductor sector, yet its reliance on Russian fuel—6.8 m tonnes worth $4.9 bn since February 2022, almost 20 percent of Russia’s exports—raises conflict and credibility risks. Experts warn this revenue aids the Kremlin, amid concerns over Taiwan’s 97 percent energy import dependency and potential China–Taiwan escalation, though some see it as petrochemical opportunism.

articles.title: Caribbean nations launch EU-style deal to let citizens work freely across borders
articles.trailText: Barbados, Belize, Dominica and St Vincent agree landmark pact letting citizens live and work freely across their borders
articles.summary: After decades of Caricom negotiations, Barbados, Belize, Dominica and St Vincent & the Grenadines launched an EU-style free movement agreement letting citizens reside, work and stay indefinitely without permits. This expansion of the Caricom Single Market & Economy aims to stem the exodus of skilled professionals in health, education and other sectors, foster economic and cultural integration, and pave the way for a unified Caribbean market. Officials plan to roll out the model to other members. Concerns include strain on social services and local job competition, though supporters view it as vital to retain talent.

articles.title: Jailed Georgian politicians allege links between ruling party and Iran in letter to UK
articles.trailText: Exclusive: Imprisoned opposition leaders call on foreign secretary to impose sanctions over ‘unprecedented expansion’ of Iranian influence
articles.summary: Seven jailed Georgian opposition leaders have written from Rustavi prisons to UK Foreign Secretary Yvette Cooper warning of an unprecedented expansion of Iranian influence via ties between the ruling Georgian Dream party and Tehran. They urge British sanctions on party officials, oligarch Bidzina Ivanishvili’s associates and owners of alleged propaganda outlets such as Imedi TV, accusing them of amplifying pro-government and pro-Russian messaging. Citing solidarity gestures by Georgia’s deputy FM at Iran’s embassy and PM Kobakhidze’s Tehran visit alongside Hamas and Hezbollah, they decry the regime’s autocratic frontal assault on democracy.

articles.title: Government ‘deeply concerned’ about safety of Australians aboard Gaza flotilla
articles.trailText: The Global Sumud Flotilla is aiming to break Israel’s blockade of Gaza and deliver aid
articles.summary: Australia’s Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade says it is deeply concerned for six Australians confirmed aboard the Global Sumud Flotilla—over 40 vessels carrying 500 people including Greta Thunberg—aiming to breach Israel’s Gaza blockade to deliver aid. Canberra has lobbied Israel, Spain, Italy and Greece over the risk of interception, drone fire and detention, urging all parties to respect international humanitarian law. Italy has halted its naval tracking, offering a Cyprus-port compromise. Canberra warns citizens to use official relief channels and stands ready to provide consular support.

articles.title: Wednesday briefing: The prime minister’s big conference speech promised renewal – can he deliver?
articles.trailText: In today’s newsletter: Subdued vibes on the floor, poor polls and teetering party politics stand in the way of Keir Starmer’s plan to take Britain to the promised land
articles.summary: At Labour’s 2025 conference Keir Starmer delivered a forceful speech likening his mission to post-war rebuilding and declaring a ‘battle for the soul of the country,’ with clear attacks on Nigel Farage and racism. Think-tanks praised a new progressive vision, but a subdued conference floor, a 40% collapse in youth membership and steep poll deficits exposed a waning grassroots base. With votes hemorrhaging to Reform UK, the Lib Dems and Greens, and unaddressed demands on benefits and local investment, Labour needs more than rallying rhetoric—it must mobilise activists and articulate an inspiring, unifying plan to turn its election fortunes around.

articles.title: ‘A steampunk Mr Tayto’: why Irish critics hate Netflix’s House of Guinness
articles.trailText: While US and UK reviewers have praised the series, in Ireland it has faced a barrage of withering put-downs
articles.summary: In Netflix’s eight-part drama House of Guinness, Steven Knight’s lavish retelling of 1860s Dublin—shot in Liverpool with James Norton and a contemporary Irish rock soundtrack—has earned 89% audience approval and rave US/UK reviews for its style and intrigue. Yet Irish critics panned its ‘rudimentary’ colonial lens, anachronistic costumes, dim lighting, clumsy dialogue and caricatured Fenians. The Irish Times condemned its historical inaccuracies, the Irish Independent decried clichés and over-swearing, and social media mocked its ‘steampunk Mr Tayto’ hero and Halloween-style rebels.

articles.title: Slovakia marks ‘dark day’ as LGBTQ+ rights rolled back in parliament
articles.trailText: Amendment to constitution stipulates that male and female are the only recognised sexes and makes adoption nearly impossible for same-sex couples
articles.summary: Slovakia’s parliament has enacted a constitutional amendment defining sex strictly as male/female, banning legal gender recognition, and effectively preventing same-sex couples from adopting. Campaigners call it a “dark day” and warn it erodes LGBTQ+ rights under populist PM Robert Fico, echoing Russia’s and Hungary’s anti-LGBTQ+ measures. Critics say it conflicts with EU and international human rights law, risks Slovakia’s EU standing, and strengthens state power over individual freedoms. Advocacy groups report widespread fear among LGBTQ+ people and urge legal protections instead of “draconian” rollbacks.

articles.title: Ukraine war briefing: Estonia warns of Putin distraction tactics as EU leaders meet to discuss ‘drone wall’
articles.trailText: Estonian leader Kristen Michal says Putin wants Europe ‘talking about ourselves, not Ukraine’ ahead of meeting in Copenhagen.
articles.summary: In Copenhagen ahead of a two-day EU summit, Estonia’s PM Kristen Michal warned that Putin’s recent airspace incursions and drone flights are designed to distract Europe from supporting Ukraine. EU leaders will debate boosting defences—including a proposed continent-wide “drone wall” to intercept Russian UAVs—and using €140bn in frozen Russian assets as a reparation loan for Kyiv. Ukraine’s Zaporizhzhia nuclear plant has been offline for seven days under shelling, raising meltdown fears. Romania plans joint production of defensive drones with Ukraine, while Princess Anne visited Kyiv to express British solidarity.

articles.title: Indonesia school collapse: 91 missing and three dead as rescuers search rubble for second day
articles.trailText: More than 90 people missing and at least three dead after building collapses as students held prayers at school in Sidoarjo
articles.summary: Authorities in Sidoarjo, East Java, report 91 people missing and three confirmed dead after the fourth-floor collapse of the Al Khoziny Islamic boarding school during late afternoon prayers. Rescuers, using cameras and listening devices, detected at least six survivors under concrete slabs. An excavator and crane assist, but heavy machinery is limited to avoid further collapse. Ninety-nine students and staff have been accounted for, with 26 injured still hospitalized. Investigators blame foundation pillar failure amid a nine-month expansion, prompting calls for stricter building safety standards.

articles.title: Trump gives Hamas ‘three or four days’ to respond to his peace plan for Gaza
articles.trailText: US president warns militant group will ‘pay in hell’ if it rejects the deal, which seeks to end two-year-long war
articles.summary: Trump gave Hamas just three to four days to accept his 20-point Gaza peace and reconstruction plan, warning they’ll “pay in hell” if they refuse and promising full US backing for Israel’s continued offensive. The deal calls for Hamas’s disarmament, release of the remaining 48 Israeli hostages within 72 hours of a ceasefire, freeing nearly 2,000 Palestinian prisoners, then a technocratic transitional authority headed by Trump overseeing Gaza. Netanyahu and many Arab states endorse it; Hamas is consulting internally and with allies. Some Palestinian factions and Israeli far-right ministers denounce its “impossible” conditions.

articles.title: Germany seeks to extradite Ukrainian over 2022 Nord Stream gas pipeline attack
articles.trailText: Man held in Poland on suspicion of causing explosions that damaged undersea pipelines between Russia and Germany
articles.summary: Germany seeks extradition of Ukrainian diver Volodymyr Z, arrested in Poland on a European arrest warrant for allegedly planting explosives on the Nord Stream 1 and 2 pipelines near Bornholm in September 2022. Investigators say he dove to the seabed from a rented yacht using forged documents. His lawyer contends Ukrainians can’t be criminally liable for attacking pipelines that funded Russia’s war, which Moscow also blames on Kyiv. If extradited, he’ll face trial in Karlsruhe, complicating German-Ukrainian wartime ties. A second Ukrainian suspect was arrested in Italy last month.

articles.title: ‘Fatal flaws’: analysts cast doubt on Tony Blair’s plan for future of Gaza
articles.trailText: Former PM seems a perfect fit for Trump’s new era but his track record in the Middle East is not reassuring
articles.summary: Tony Blair’s bid to join Donald Trump’s Gaza “peace board” as interim consul revives his Middle East ambitions but renews doubts over his record. Critics highlight his role in the Iraq invasion, his narrow focus on Islamist extremism and entanglement of personal business, and his toothless 2007–2015 Quartet envoy mission centered on economic development while sidelining Palestinian political rights. His 2006 rejection of Hamas election results and lobbying against Palestinian UN membership worsened Gaza’s crisis. Analysts warn his draft proposal prioritises economic over political progress and will be undercut by Israel’s “death by a thousand cuts.”

articles.title: Mass slaughter in Gaza stands apart from other genocides, Chris Sidoti says: ‘People cannot escape’
articles.trailText: Australian human rights expert who was on UN commission of inquiry labels Israel’s strategy a failure that ‘has not brought peace and has not destroyed Hamas’
articles.summary: Chris Sidoti, a former UN international crimes investigator, argues Israel’s Gaza operations constitute a unique genocide because Palestinians cannot flee. In a new UN commission report, Sidoti details mass slaughter, infrastructure destruction, imposed starvation and daily death rates of 75–300, with over 65,000 identified victims—half women and children. He cites direct incitement by Israeli leaders and systematic bombardment as evidence of genocidal intent under international law. He labels Israel’s post-7 October strategy a failure, criticizes Security Council inaction, and urges global legal and policy measures, including Australia suspending defence ties to Israel.

articles.title: Indonesia school collapse: three dead and over 90 missing as rescue effort continues
articles.trailText: Instability of building in East Java town hampers search but 99 boys and school staff known to have survived
articles.summary: At Al Khoziny Islamic boarding school in Sidoarjo, East Java, a four-storey building under construction collapsed as students gathered for prayers in a mosque on a lower floor, killing three and leaving 91 teenage boys and staff unaccounted for. Ninety-nine occupants survived; 26 injured are in local hospitals. Rescuers, fearing further collapse, rely on manual search alongside a crane and excavator. Families, clutching a whiteboard list of survivors, anxiously call missing names; one uncle still seeks nephew Rosi. Authorities suspect weak foundations couldn’t bear the added fourth-floor weight.

articles.title: Israel-backed militia groups potentially threaten new peace plan for Gaza
articles.trailText: Israeli military has been arming alternatives to Hamas, with up to a dozen new groups emerging
articles.summary: Israeli forces have armed and trained up to a dozen local militias in Gaza—most prominently Yasser abu Shabab’s Popular Forces and Hossam al-Astal’s new Khan Younis faction—to seize control of territory and oversee aid alongside the opaque Gaza Humanitarian Foundation. Rivalry with Hamas, extortion and looting by these groups have caused over 220 intra-Palestinian violent incidents since October 2023, killing roughly 400. This fragmentation deepens Gaza’s humanitarian crisis and risks derailing Trump’s 20-point Gaza plan—featuring a technocrat council and international stabilization force—by fostering criminality and lawlessness.

articles.title: US deports 120 Iranians back to Tehran in Trump immigration crackdown
articles.trailText: Uncommon instance of cooperation between the two countries reportedly came after months of talks
articles.summary: Under Trump’s immigration crackdown, the US plans to expel up to 400 Iranians and this week flew 120 detainees on a US-chartered flight from Louisiana via Qatar back to Tehran—a rare diplomatic cooperation after months of negotiation. Many returnees crossed from Mexico illegally or faced other immigration issues. Human rights advocates warn Iranian returnees, including activists, dissidents and LGBTQ+ individuals, risk persecution despite Tehran’s safety assurances, potentially breaching international non-refoulement obligations.

articles.title: AfD politician’s former aide convicted of spying for China
articles.trailText: Jian Guo jailed for five years after acting as agent for Chinese intelligence while working for Maximilian Krah
articles.summary: Jian Guo, a German national and former aide to AfD MP Maximilian Krah, was sentenced to 4 years 9 months for spying for Chinese intelligence from 2019–2024. He passed EU parliamentary documents, personal data on AfD leaders Alice Weidel and Tino Chrupalla, and monitored Chinese dissidents. Co-defendant Yaqi X, a Leipzig/Halle airport employee, received a suspended 1 year 9 months for supplying flight and military cargo details. Krah, who denies involvement, has had his immunity lifted amid a separate bribery and money-laundering probe into alleged Chinese payments. Beijing has dismissed European espionage claims as political smear.

articles.title: Men in wet clothes claiming to be Camino pilgrims arrested over alleged ‘narco-sub’ plot
articles.trailText: Three men had fled in taxi after allegedly piloting vessel carrying 3.65 tonnes of cocaine to Galicia, Spanish police say
articles.summary: Spanish National Police and the DEA arrested three men in Galicia suspected of piloting a semi-submersible carrying 3.65 tonnes of cocaine from South America. The probe began in August into a gang in Outes posing as a marine equipment company. On Sept 13, officers intercepted high-speed boats returning to port and seized bundles of cocaine—one tonne recovered after a trailer overturned; the rest found on a nearby beach. The alleged crew, a Colombian and two Ecuadorians, were captured by local police after fleeing in wet clothes in a taxi and posing as Camino de Santiago pilgrims. Authorities also detained 14 suspects, seized €54,680, two boats, five cars and a trailer.

articles.title: Afghanistan ‘blind without phones and internet’ on second day of telecoms blackout
articles.trailText: Taliban authorities cut fibre-optic network in nationwide shutdown of communications to prevent ‘vice’
articles.summary: On Sept 30, Taliban authorities, following orders from supreme leader Hibatullah Akhundzada, severed Afghanistan’s national fibre-optic network, plunging mobile and internet connectivity below 1% in a second day of nationwide blackout. Officially aimed at curbing “immorality” and online pornography, the shutdown halts banking, customs, commerce, education and healthcare—Najibullah, a Kabul shopkeeper, says the market is frozen without phones. Human Rights Watch and UNAMA warn the disconnection infringes fundamental rights, deepens the humanitarian crisis and suppresses dissent, particularly after bans on girls’ education and women’s work. Authorities say services will resume “when morality is restored.”

articles.title: ‘Not even animals escape the extreme barbarity’: wildlife caught in Rio’s rampant gun crime
articles.trailText: From capuchin monkeys to mantled hawks - Instituto Vida Livre has treated a myriad of shot animals in a city blighted by gun crime
articles.summary: At Rio’s Instituto Vida Livre wildlife hospital, medics have treated at least 69 animals shot in the past decade, from capuchin monkeys like Maria—paralysed and ultimately killed by a bullet in her spine—to mantled hawks, capybaras, parrots, alligators and a horse wounded during a police raid. This surge of gunshot wildlife injuries reflects Rio’s tangled biodiversity and rampant urban armed violence: 816 people suffered firearm wounds in six months. Activists blame Brazil’s pro-gun boom under Bolsonaro, noting pets and protected species alike fall victim to stray bullets, targeted cruelty and the city’s “banalisation” of firearms.

articles.title: ‘His drug is power’: Lukashenko reaches out to the west
articles.trailText: President of Belarus has been edging out of the diplomatic freeze, cautiously probing for space beyond Moscow
articles.summary: Belarus’s long-serving leader Alexander Lukashenko has begun to pry himself out of diplomatic isolation, leveraging a perceived opening with the Trump administration to secure personal meetings, symbolized by receiving White House cufflinks. While Europe debates if engaging him could reduce Russia’s sway, Lukashenko has cautiously offered gestures—such as releasing political prisoners and inviting US officers to observe Zapad-2025 drills—in hopes of sanctions relief. Economic strains, from shortages to stalled exports, have deepened his reliance on Russia, yet he continues a tightrope strategy of hedging between Moscow and the West to preserve power.

articles.title: Trump’s peace proposal welcomed by world leaders but Palestinians remain sceptical
articles.trailText: After being welcomed by Arab, Islamic and European leaders, experts say onus now rests on Hamas to accept plan
articles.summary: Donald Trump and Israel’s PM Benjamin Netanyahu unveiled a 20-point Gaza peace plan: immediate ceasefire, hostages-for-prisoners swap, phased Israeli military withdrawal, Hamas disarmament and an international-led transitional authority. While leaders in Saudi Arabia, UAE, Qatar, Jordan, Egypt, Turkey, Pakistan and EU governments including the UK, France and Germany welcomed it as the only US-backed roadmap to end genocide, Netanyahu has already backtracked on full withdrawal. Hamas, excluded from talks, remains sceptical and unlikely to concede power. Gaza residents and Palestinian figures warn the plan is unrealistic; US diplomatic veterans urge pressure on Hamas. Israelis and Gazans express cautious hope.

articles.title: Share your reaction to the Moldova election results
articles.trailText: We would like to hear from people in Moldova and what they think about Maia Sandu’s Action and Solidarity party (PAS) winning the election
articles.summary: Moldova’s pro-European Action and Solidarity party (PAS), led by President Maia Sandu, has narrowly retained its 101-seat parliamentary majority, winning 50.03% of votes with over 99.5% counted. Sandu deemed the vote the most consequential in Moldova’s history, casting it as a choice between continued Western integration and a return to Russia’s influence. A community callout (closed 23 Oct 2025) sought local perspectives on this pivotal result and its impact on Moldova’s future direction.

articles.title: Will pivotal election turn Czech Republic into another anti-EU agitator?
articles.trailText: ANO party, led by former PM Andrej Babiš, is leading polls and may form a Eurosceptic and pro-Russia coalition
articles.summary: Voters in the Czech Republic head to the polls on 3–4 October in a pivotal election that could see former PM Andrej Babiš’s populist ANO (30% in polls) lead a eurosceptic, pro-Russia coalition. ANO would likely rely on far-right SPD, left-wing Stačilo! or niche Motorists for Themselves to secure a minority government, risking clashes over migration, climate policy, EU green rules and Ukraine aid amid high inflation and living-cost woes. Centre-right Spolu, Stan and Pirates refuse alliances with ANO, SPD or Stačilo!, and President Pavel may veto ministers hostile to EU/Nato.

articles.title: Typhoon Bualoi death toll rises to at least 30 across Vietnam, Thailand and Philippines
articles.trailText: Vietnamese authorities say typhoon was the most devastating storm to hit the country this year
articles.summary: Typhoon Bualoi has killed at least 19 and left 21 missing in Vietnam, plus 11 dead in the Philippines and four fatalities in Thailand, bringing the regional toll above 30. The storm’s downpours and coastal swells triggered floods, landslides and flash-flood warnings after over 300mm fell in northern Vietnam and Hanoi. Thailand erected barriers to protect Ayutthaya’s Unesco temples. Now a tropical depression heading to Laos, Bualoi follows Ragasa, highlighting experts’ concerns that warming seas fuel stronger, wetter storms.

articles.title: Tuesday briefing: A roadmap for peace in Gaza – or an ultimatum?
articles.trailText: In today’s newsletter: The key details of a new proposal for peace, as Donald Trump and Benjamin Netanyahu meet in Washington
articles.summary: At a simultaneous Washington press event, Trump hailed a “peace plan” for Gaza promising “eternal peace,” while Netanyahu cast it as fulfilling Israel’s war aims without advancing a Palestinian state and preserving Israeli forces. Hamas and the Palestinian Authority were excluded. The US 21-point proposal, reportedly with Arab backing, calls for no Hamas role, phased Israeli withdrawal, hostages’ return, and reconstruction overseen by a transitional board including Tony Blair, with vague future statehood and deradicalization steps. Observers warn it resembles an ultimatum negotiated without Palestinian input, leaving governance details unresolved.

articles.title: South Korea raises cyber threat level after huge data centre fire sparks hacking fears
articles.trailText: National cyber security centre raises alert level to ‘caution’ as technicians race to restore government systems after battery fire sparked nationwide chaos
articles.summary: After a lithium-ion battery fire at the national information resources service datacentre in Daejeon on 27 Sep paralysed 647 government systems—email, intranet, mobile IDs, banking and student records—South Korea’s cybersecurity centre raised its alert from “attention” to “caution,” fearing hackers could exploit the disruption. The fire injured one worker, took 22 hours to extinguish and destroyed an estimated 96 systems; 89 have been restored. Full recovery via a Daegu backup will take four weeks, spanning the Chuseok holiday. President Lee Jae Myung condemned the lack of backups ahead of the APEC summit in Gyeongju. Politicians spar over responsibility. Despite post-Kakao fire laws mandating redundancy and battery spacing, failures expose gaps in South Korea’s digital infrastructure.

articles.title: Ukraine war briefing: Europe ‘no longer at peace’ with Russia, says German chancellor
articles.trailText: Germany ready to defend Baltic region, Berlin says while Hungarian PM claims Ukraine ‘not a sovereign country’. What we know on day 1,315
articles.summary: German chancellor Friedrich Merz declared Europe ‘not at war but no longer at peace’ with Russia, endorsing EU plans to unlock frozen Russian assets for Ukraine’s war effort over 3–5 years. Defence minister Boris Pistorius pledged to station 2,000 German troops in Lithuania by mid-2026 to protect the Baltics. Hungarian PM Viktor Orbán dismissed Ukraine’s sovereignty amid drone disputes. Zelenskiy proposed a joint Polish-Ukrainian air-defence shield after Russian drone incursions; allies will bolster Denmark’s anti-drone measures. Putin lauded Russia’s “righteous battle,” conscripted 135,000 and quit the anti-torture convention. A Russian strike killed a family in Sumy; Zaporizhzhia plant remains without external power.

articles.title: Shane Christie sustained multiple head injuries playing rugby. In death, he is still fighting for change
articles.trailText: The former All Blacks Sevens player suspected he had CTE, a disease associated with head impacts, and has donated his brain to science to help understand the condition
articles.summary: Former All Blacks Sevens star Shane Christie suffered years of debilitating neurological symptoms—headaches, mood swings, paranoia and hallucinations—suspected to be chronic traumatic encephalopathy (CTE), before dying by suicide at 40. After enduring multiple concussions in Super Rugby and Māori All Blacks, Christie campaigned for better concussion protocols and transparency from New Zealand Rugby and its players’ association, notably launching the Billy Guyton Foundation following his friend’s CTE-linked death. He donated his brain to Auckland’s human brain bank to advance CTE research. His case, now under coronial review, may drive reforms in player welfare, concussion management and recognition of CTE in rugby.

articles.title: China court sentences 11 people to death over alleged role in family-run Myanmar scam operations
articles.trailText: Another five people given suspended death sentences over alleged role in gang that operated scam centres and illegal gambling worth $1.4bn
articles.summary: A Wenzhou court has sentenced 11 members of the Kokang-based Ming family to death, five others to two-year suspended death sentences (typically commuted to life) and 12 more to 5–24 years behind bars for running a $1.4 billion cross-border fraud and illegal gambling syndicate in Myanmar. The court said they used armed force to operate multiple scam compounds, killing 14 people—including ten workers who tried to escape after armed gunfire in October 2023—and offering protection to financial backers. The verdict aligns with China’s regional crackdown on a UN-estimated $40 billion cyber-scam industry.

articles.title: What’s in Trump’s 20-point peace plan for Gaza?
articles.trailText: Plan calls for immediate end to war between Israel and Hamas but lacks detail on how key points will be executed
articles.summary: The 20-point Trump White House plan for Gaza proposes an immediate Israel-Hamas ceasefire, a 72-hour hostage exchange—Israel frees 250 Palestinians serving life sentences and 1,700 Gaza detainees for all Israeli hostages (with remains matched 1:15)—and freezes military operations without full Israeli withdrawal. Hamas is excluded from governance; members surrender weapons for amnesty or safe passage. Gaza would be de-radicalized, terror-free, aid restored via UN and Red Crescent. A technocratic interim Palestinian committee, overseen by an international “Board of Peace” led by Trump, would rebuild Gaza under a US-backed economic plan; future Palestinian statehood is left a long-term possibility via interfaith dialogue.

articles.title: Trump’s plan for Gaza is ambitious but peace is far from guaranteed
articles.trailText: The US president has won regional backing, but Hamas’s response and Israel’s intentions leave the outcome in doubt
articles.summary: President Trump’s 20-point Gaza peace plan, endorsed by key Arab states and Israeli PM Netanyahu, proposes Hamas disarmament, the creation of a technocratic ‘Council of Peace’ led by Trump, and UN/Red Crescent–managed aid access in exchange for hostages’ release within 72 hours. Major unknowns include Hamas’s willingness to surrender arms, vague commitments on Arab troop or funding support for demilitarisation, the absence of Palestinian statehood, and unclear Israeli withdrawal timelines. Netanyahu’s domestic ambitions and the threat of renewed US-backed Israeli military action highlight the fragile, sketch-like nature of the roadmap.

articles.title: Trump and Netanyahu to Hamas: accept Gaza peace plan or face consequences
articles.trailText: Pair say proposal represents new chapter but Israeli PM threatens to ‘finish the job’ if Hamas officials fail to agree
articles.summary: At a White House summit on 29 September, Donald Trump and Benjamin Netanyahu unveiled a 20-point Gaza peace blueprint, demanding Hamas accept ceasefire, hostages-for-prisoners swap, staged Israeli withdrawal, disarmament and a transitional international administration—else Israel will ‘finish the job’ of destroying Hamas with full U.S. backing. The plan, drafted without Hamas input and brokered via Qatari and Egyptian mediators, offers amnesty or safe passage to compliant militants, installs a Trump-led ‘Board of Peace’ with Tony Blair, and promises Gaza reconstruction if terms are met.

articles.title: Nicolás Maduro ready to declare state of emergency if US attacks Venezuela, says vice-president
articles.trailText: Delcy Rodríguez, one of Maduro’s closest allies, warns of ‘catastrophic’ consequences if onslaught materializes
articles.summary: Venezuela’s vice-president Delcy Rodríguez, a close ally of Nicolás Maduro, warns that Maduro will invoke emergency powers if the US attacks, mobilizing forces, sealing borders and controlling infrastructure. She brands recent US naval deployments and airstrikes, blamed on fighting drug cartels, a “big lie” masking an effort to seize Venezuela’s vast oil, gas and mineral reserves. At least 17 people have died in US strikes, which critics call unlawful extrajudicial killings. US plans under discussion include drone strikes, while analysts deem a full invasion unlikely.

articles.title: Madagascar’s president dissolves government amid youth-led protests
articles.trailText: Demonstrations over water and power cuts inspired by ‘gen-Z’ protests elsewhere have left at least 22 dead, says UN
articles.summary: Madagascar president Andry Rajoelina has dissolved his government after three days of youth-led demonstrations in Antananarivo over water and power cuts—protests inspired by Gen Z movements in Kenya and Nepal that left at least 22 dead and 100 injured, per the UN. Rajoelina apologized for service failures, invited applications for a new premier, and pledged dialogue and support for looted businesses. Security forces’ heavy response using teargas and rubber bullets drew UN criticism, while authorities disputed casualty figures. Protesters adopted Nepal’s flag and online tactics, demanding Rajoelina’s resignation amid the country’s chronic poverty and political unrest.

articles.title: Eleven arrested for placing pigs’ heads near French mosques and other hate crimes
articles.trailText: Serbian nationals also accused by Serbian police of defacing Jewish sites, as French officials investigate foreign interference
articles.summary: Serbian police arrested 11 Serbian nationals accused of inciting hatred in France and Germany by staging hate crimes—placing pigs’ heads at Paris-area mosques, defacing a French Holocaust memorial and three synagogues with green paint, and leaving concrete skeletons with hate messages at Berlin’s Brandenburg Gate. Between April and September 2025 they allegedly acted under instructions from a foreign intelligence‐linked suspect at large. French prosecutors, amid the Gaza war tensions, suspect Russia-backed interference after similar attacks by Eastern Europeans—green‐paint vandals, red‐hand spray painters and a pro-Russian Moldovan handler behind David‐star graffiti.

articles.title: Zelenskyy says Ukraine can help Europe counter Russian drone incursions
articles.trailText: Ukrainian leader offers to assist Poland and others and says some launches may have come from Baltic Sea
articles.summary: Speaking at a Warsaw security forum, Ukrainian president Volodymyr Zelenskiy offered Poland, Denmark, Romania and other European allies to co-develop a reliable air defence “shield” against Russian drones—some suspected of launching from tankers in the Baltic Sea. Drawing on Ukraine’s ability to neutralise over 90% of drones via integrated air defences, jets and jamming, he warned that stripping Russia’s aerial strike capacity could break its war machine. Recent incursions forced airport closures in Poland and Denmark, while Romania found new drone fragments near its border. The UK, France, Germany and Sweden have since deployed troops, radars, helicopters and counter-drone systems.

articles.title: Canada designates Indian gang linked to high-profile killings as terrorist entity
articles.trailText: Canadian government accuses the Lawrence Bishnoi gang of being involved in murder of prominent Sikh activist Hardeep Singh Nijjar near Vancouver
articles.summary: Canada’s federal government has designated the Indian Lawrence Bishnoi gang as a terrorist entity, alleging its involvement in the 2023 murder of Sikh activist Hardeep Singh Nijjar near Vancouver and a pattern of extortion, shootings and arson against diaspora communities. Public Safety Minister Gary Anandasangaree said the move enables seizure of any domestic assets and stronger tools to counter the gang’s transnational network. The designation follows RCMP findings tying Bishnoi operatives to high-profile killings, including rapper Sidhu Moose Wala and politician Baba Siddique, and alleged collusion with Indian government agents. Rights groups and the World Sikh Organization have welcomed the step while urging accountability for all those orchestrating the violence.

articles.title: Jack Spence obituary
articles.trailText: Authority on politics in South Africa whose advice helped guide the country from apartheid to democracy
articles.summary: Jack Spence, 94, was a leading scholar of diplomacy and South African politics whose research, policy advice and mediation helped steer South Africa’s transition from apartheid to democracy. A non-partisan voice under apartheid, during the 1990 transition and post-1994 rule, he taught at universities in South Africa and the UK, led Chatham House studies and shaped international affairs through major journals. Author of Ending Apartheid (2010) and other key works, co-founder of two journals, OBE (2002), he funded scholarships, mentored future leaders and advised governments. Born in Krugersdorp, he is survived by daughter Rachel.

articles.title: Wildfire in Namibia is contained, says PM, after criticism of response
articles.trailText: A third of Etosha national park has been burned despite efforts of volunteers, who say troops were sent in too late
articles.summary: Namibia’s government announced that wildfires in Etosha national park, which began on 22 September, have been contained after scorching over 775,000 hectares (one-third of the park) and 171,000 hectares beyond. Prime Minister Tjitunga Elijah Ngurare deployed 49 soldiers on Saturday and 500 on Sunday, blaming nearby charcoal production for igniting the fires. Volunteer rescue groups and private pilots criticised a five-day delay in army deployment and lack of coordination. Confirmed wildlife losses include nine antelopes; one pangolin was rescued. Etosha’s 80×30-mile salt pan, famed for flamingoes, is now slowly reopening to tourists.

articles.title: Investigation into Nicolas Sarkozy not due to ‘hatred’, his prosecutor says
articles.trailText: Jean-François Bohnert rejects claim by ex-French president, who has been sentenced to five years in jail for election funding conspiracy
articles.summary: France’s top financial crimes prosecutor Jean-François Bohnert has rejected ex-President Nicolas Sarkozy’s claim that his five-year jail sentence for criminal conspiracy over alleged Libyan campaign funds was driven by “hatred,” saying the probe is guided solely by the rule of law. Judge Nathalie Gavarino, citing the offences’ “exceptional gravity,” ordered Sarkozy, now 70, to begin serving his sentence pending appeal. Gavarino has faced death threats, prompting two investigations. President Macron and Justice Minister Darmanin condemned the intimidation. Sarkozy—acquitted on related charges—has appealed and decries the verdict.

articles.title: It’s goodnight Vienna as Paris sleeper train to Austria and Berlin hit by cuts
articles.trailText: Some Nightjet services suspended from mid-December after French withdrawal amid public budget crisis
articles.summary: From December 14 2025 ÖBB will suspend its Vienna-Paris and Berlin-Paris Nightjet sleeper services after France withdrew subsidies from 2026 amid public budget cuts. SNCF was informed by the Paris transport ministry that public service orders for both routes end in 2026. ÖBB will still run thrice-weekly Vienna-Brussels, Vienna-Amsterdam and Munich-Rome Nightjets, investing in 24 next-generation sleepers. Advocates say 66,000 travellers used Paris-Vienna/Berlin trains in 2024 and have gathered 43,000 petition signatures. Critics decry heavy air travel subsidies. A pyjama party protest took place at Paris Gare de l’Est.

articles.title: Moldova’s president Maia Sandu hails voters’ refusal to be ‘bought’ by Moscow
articles.trailText: Ruling party holds on to its majority in Sunday’s poll, which it says is ‘strong mandate for EU accession’
articles.summary: Pro-western President Maia Sandu hailed voters’ refusal to be “bought” by Moscow after her Action and Solidarity party won 50.03% of votes (55/101 seats), securing a clear parliamentary majority and EU accession mandate. Despite Kremlin-backed vote-buying, cyber-attacks and bomb threats, PAS outperformed polls, thwarting a Soviet-nostalgic alliance led by ex-president Igor Dodon. Ursula von der Leyen and Emmanuel Macron congratulated Moldova’s pro-European choice. Challenges remain: pending reforms, Transnistria’s Russian garrison, and stubborn economic woes under Sandu’s tenure.

articles.title: Postwar Gaza authority potentially led by Tony Blair ‘would sideline Palestinians’
articles.trailText: Draft plan’s critics say it hands power to international figures and splits Gaza from Palestinian Authority in West Bank
articles.summary: A leaked 21-page confidential US-backed proposal envisions a Gaza International Transitional Authority (Gita) led by international figures—potentially Tony Blair—with a seven- to ten-member council including global financiers and only one Palestinian. It splits Gaza from the West Bank PA, grants binding legislative and security powers to the chair, and promotes investor-driven reconstruction via public-private partnerships. Operating initially from El-Arish, it reports to the UN Security Council. Critics warn it sidelines Palestinian political leadership, creates an alternative jurisdiction undermining unity and sovereignty, and lacks democratic legitimacy, while supporters call it a temporary pathway back to PA control.

articles.title: Seven out of 10 women in creative industries experience bullying and harassment, survey finds
articles.trailText: Exclusive: Only half of victims report incidents – and of those who do, 42% say response was insufficient
articles.summary: Survey of 5,500+ women in non-performing creative roles by union Bectu found 69% experienced workplace bullying and harassment in past year (72% among disabled). Only 55% reported incidents; 42% deemed responses insufficient. 61% witnessed toxic behaviour widely tolerated, especially in unscripted TV (80%). Culture secretary Lisa Nandy and CIISA CEO Jen Smith urge stronger protections, robust cross-industry backing and long-term funding for the independent standards body. Industry power imbalances and NDA abuses remain barriers.

articles.title: The pro-European party won Moldova’s election but obstacles to join the EU remain
articles.trailText: Russia’s campaign to amplify societal distrust continues as membership talks have stalled
articles.summary: Maia Sandu’s pro-EU Action and Solidarity party secured 50.03% in Moldova’s Sept. 2025 parliamentary elections, outpacing the pro-Russian Patriotic bloc despite Russian meddling, refugee inflows and energy-price shocks. With a clear majority, Sandu aims to drive the political and economic reforms needed for EU accession by 2030, supported by €1.9 bn in EU funding and high-level EU visits. Yet accession talks remain blocked by Hungary’s Kremlin-aligned veto linking Ukraine and Moldova, requiring unanimity. EU Council chief António Costa proposes majorities for policy talks to sustain momentum amid ongoing Russian disinformation efforts.

articles.title: Cash is still king across Africa. Can a new payment platform transform business?
articles.trailText: Digital system that facilitates instant money transfers touted as potential game-changer for cross-border trade
articles.summary: Despite cash remaining dominant across Algeria and much of Africa due to trust deficits and fragmented exchange rates, cross-border transactions rely on costly third-party gateways or physical cash. The Pan-African Payment and Settlement System (Papss), launched 2022 by Afreximbank and the African Union within AfCFTA, promises seven-second local-currency transfers, lower fees and “financial sovereignty.” Piloted by banks in 18 countries, Papss faces hurdles including rural digital infrastructure gaps, currency volatility, FX controls and potential overlap with central bank projects. If widely adopted, it could streamline payments for 1.4bn Africans and boost intra-continental trade.

articles.title: Monday briefing: Can Labour’s crucial conference set the stage for a comeback?
articles.trailText: In today’s newsletter: With Reform surging and unrest within his party, the prime minister is relying on new pledges to steady his government and reset the agenda
articles.summary: Labour’s conference in Liverpool opens amid a surge in Reform UK support and internal tensions. Keir Starmer condemned Reform’s plan to revoke residency rights as 'racist' while home secretary Shabana Mahmood signals tougher settlement rules, and Rachel Reeves promises libraries for 1,700 primary schools. Outside, nationalist and pro-Palestine protests underscored divisions. Delegates recall no recent far-right demonstrations at Labour’s conference. With previous missteps - freebies scandal, benefit U-turns and rebel MPs - Labour faces a credibility test. Starmer’s three pillars - Palestinian recognition, digital ID and anti-Reform rhetoric - will decide if he can reset the agenda and stem Reform’s momentum.

articles.title: Moldova’s pro-European party retains majority in key election
articles.trailText: PAS garners 50.03% of vote after more than 99.5% of ballots counted in poll deciding whether country steers closer to EU or Russia
articles.summary: Moldova’s Action and Solidarity party (PAS) led by President Maia Sandu won 50.03% and retained its majority in the 101-seat parliament, defeating a pro-Russian bloc with 24.26%. The vote, seen as pivotal for Moldova’s EU accession path, was marred by alleged Russian cyber-attacks, fake bomb threats, and vote-buying. Strong diaspora turnout bolstered pro-Western forces. Opposition leader Igor Dodon accused irregularities and plans protests. Sandu’s win solidifies her reform agenda despite economic woes and regional divisions in Transnistria and Gagauzia.

articles.title: Dismay in New Zealand after government fails to recognise Palestinian statehood
articles.trailText: PM Christopher Luxon had suggested recognition was only a matter of time, prompting disappointment from opposition parties and activists
articles.summary: New Zealand’s coalition government refused to recognise Palestinian statehood at the UNGA despite PM Christopher Luxon’s prior comments that it was only a matter of time. Foreign Affairs Minister Winston Peters cited Gaza’s ongoing war, Hamas’s rule and risks to ceasefire efforts. The decision—coming after the UK, Canada and Australia formally recognised Palestine and amid a UN inquiry accusing Israel of genocide for 66,000+ Gaza deaths—sparked protests, including clergy chaining themselves to the Immigration Minister’s office. Former PM Helen Clark and opposition Greens, Labour and justice groups condemned the move, urging immediate recognition to advance a two-state solution.

articles.title: Threatened kārearea falcon wins New Zealand’s 2025 bird of the year
articles.trailText: The country’s fastest bird has taken out the top prize in a scandal-free year for the annual poll
articles.summary: The kārearea falcon, New Zealand’s only endemic raptor and capable of 200 km/h dives, has been named Bird of the Year 2025. With an estimated 5,000–8,000 individuals left, it faces threats from invasive mammals, habitat loss and collisions with structures. The scandal-free Forest & Bird poll, running two weeks since 2005, drew over 75,000 votes across 123 countries. A previous winner in 2012, the kārearea joins hoiho and kākāpō as dual champions. The kea finished second and the Chatham Island black robin third. Organizers stress that 80% of finalists are threatened, highlighting conservation challenges under climate change, habitat conversion and predation.

articles.title: ‘My kids are too scared to go outside’: Kurdish migrants face hostility as Japan wrestles with demographic crisis
articles.trailText: Antagonism toward migrant communities visible in the UK, Europe and the US appears to be spreading to Japan
articles.summary: More than a decade after fleeing Turkey, a Kurdish family in Kawaguchi faces rising hostility: children bullied, the younger son assaulted and told “Foreigners, go back!” Despite a record 3.8 million foreign residents, xenophobic media and far-right protests have stoked fears, spurred by 2023 immigration law changes and a post-pandemic migrant influx. Kurds in these commuter towns have become scapegoats, targeted with hate graffiti, secret‐camera smear campaigns and online death threats. As Japan’s ruling LDP debates capping new arrivals ahead of its leadership vote, refugee approvals remain near zero and applicants like Ali await decisions amid mounting intimidation. This backlash unfolds amid Japan’s demographic crisis and urgent labor shortages.

articles.title: Ukraine war briefing: Zelenskyy urges west to cut off Russia’s energy revenues, saying decisive action ‘long overdue’
articles.trailText: President’s plea comes after Russia bombards Kyiv and elsewhere in one of its most sustained attacks of the war. What we know on day 1,314
articles.summary: President Volodymyr Zelenskyy urged the United States, Europe, the G7 and G20 to cut off Russia’s energy revenues after one of Moscow’s fiercest raids—nearly 600 drones and over 40 cruise missiles—pounded Kyiv and six regions for 12 hours, killing four, wounding 67 and devastating Kyiv’s Petropavlivska Borshchahivka and Zaporizhzhia. Speaking as the UN General Assembly wrapped up, he condemned the “vile, cowardly” attack and called for supply of long-range Tomahawk missiles, pressing President Trump for approval. Vice-President Vance confirmed Trump will make the final decision, while Zelenskyy warned only the “harshest pressure” on Russia’s shadow fleet and energy sector can end its stalled offensive.

articles.title: Israel presses on with Gaza assault as Trump again claims ceasefire is close
articles.trailText: IDF launches 140 airstrikes in last 24 hours as tanks advance in Gaza City and death toll for same period is put at 77
articles.summary: Israel's military pressed its offensive in Gaza, launching 140 strikes in 24 hours as tanks advanced into central and western Gaza City. The Gaza health ministry reported 77 deaths over the same period. Hamas's Al-Qassam Brigades called for a 24-hour pause and withdrawal to rescue two Israeli hostages. Prime Minister Netanyahu, visiting Washington, said he and former president Trump are working on a yet-to-be-finalized ceasefire plan, echoing Trump's "greatness" claims and 21-point proposal. An international aid flotilla, including activists like Greta Thunberg, nears Gaza against Israel's blockade, while West Bank violence continues.

articles.title: Swiss voters back electronic identity cards in close vote
articles.trailText: Pollsters confounded by 50.4% support for e-IDs after forecasting stronger support for ‘yes’ vote
articles.summary: Swiss voters backed a state-issued electronic ID by 50.4% to 49.6% in a Sep 28 referendum with 49.55% turnout, surprising pollsters. Unlike a rejected 2021 plan, the free, optional e-ID—tied to a single smartphone and requiring re-registration after device changes—will supplement physical cards and introduce biometrics by end-2026. Supporters highlight easier access to online and in-person services; critics warn of data-privacy breaches, surveillance and digital exclusion. The vote aligns with UK digital-ID proposals, EU digital-wallet pilots and mature e-ID systems in Estonia and Ukraine.

articles.title: Zelenskyy condemns Russia’s ‘vile and cowardly’ 12-hour bombing of Ukraine
articles.trailText: Moscow targets Kyiv and other regions with about 600 drones and 40 missiles, killing at least four people
articles.summary: Russia unleashed nearly 600 drones and over 40 cruise missiles in a 12-hour bombardment of Kyiv and six regions, killing at least four civilians—including a 12-year-old girl—and wounding 70+, as homes and infrastructure were devastated. Zelensky condemned the attack as “vile and cowardly,” noting it coincided with UNGA week in New York after Trump’s reaffirmed support, and urged allies to ban Russian oil, impose harsher sanctions and vowed to strike back. International leaders, including the UK and Finland, decried the strikes, while Poland scrambled jets and closed border airspace in defence moves.

articles.title: Why Britain must not get taken in by Dubai’s skin-deep glitz | Letters
articles.trailText: Letters: Readers responding to Jonathan Liew’s article on Reform UK’s admiration for the emirate
articles.summary: Readers endorse Liew’s warning against the UK adopting Dubai’s model, recounting grim realities beneath the façade: systemic abuse of migrant workers forced into harsh 45°C labour; a heroin-fuelled leisure class; abandoned properties amid skyrocketing rents; strict social hierarchies policing women; segregated living and exploited hospital care for maids’ rape victims. Using David Harvey’s Marxist framework—spatial fix, accumulation by dispossession, reserve army of labour—the letter argues Dubai’s glittering megaprojects serve global capital, sideline democratic rights, and externalise social and ecological costs, revealing growth as mirage not model.

articles.title: Denmark bans drones ahead of European summits amid further sightings at military sites
articles.trailText: The ban on civilian unmanned flights will last until Friday and comes as heads of EU governments gather amid spate of drone incursions
articles.summary: Danish authorities, citing multiple overnight drone sightings at military sites, have imposed a civilian drone ban until Friday to secure an EU summit and a European Political Community meeting in Copenhagen. Violations risk fines or two-year jail terms. The measure follows recent incursions in Denmark, Poland, Romania and airspace violations by Russia, prompting NATO to deploy the German frigate FSG Hamburg under its Baltic Sentry mission and launch Eastern Sentry on the eastern flank. Norway extended drone restrictions near Bronnoysund Airport and Orland base amid similar reports. Ukrainian president Zelenskiy and NATO chiefs have vowed coordinated, proportionate responses while investigations continue.

articles.title: US private prisons operator to be paid $790m to hold 100 people on Nauru in quiet expansion of contract
articles.trailText: Exclusive: A sixteenfold increase in the original contract without public notification raises allegations of ‘gross mismanagement’ and a process ‘run out of control’
articles.summary: MTC Australia, a subsidiary of US-based Management & Training Corporation, secured a limited-tender contract in Sept 2022 for $47m over two months to run Nauru's asylum seeker reception and welfare. Successive extensions—quietly approved without public scrutiny—have inflated the two-year deal by $365m to $787m through 2027, about $157m annually to detain 105 men (~$1.5m each). Parliamentarians and integrity experts label this "gross mismanagement" and "run out of control". MTC's US record includes "gross negligence" lawsuits and a $5.2m bribery settlement. Greens and crossbenchers demand transparent procurement and reassessment of Australia's costly offshore processing regime.

articles.title: Child dies while reportedly trying to reach UK in small boat
articles.trailText: Body of teenager found on beach in northern France after three other people die in Channel crossings on Saturday
articles.summary: A teenage migrant’s body washed up on a beach at Saint-Étienne-au-Mont, northern France, after falling from an overcrowded dinghy carrying 49 people. It follows three deaths on Saturday—two Somali women crushed in a small boat and a man found in a Gravelines canal. On Saturday alone, 895 people crossed the Channel in 12 boats, bringing this year’s total to over 33,300. Since Friday, authorities have dealt with 41 maritime incidents and cared for 223 shipwrecked migrants. A Boulogne-sur-Mer investigation is ongoing. Under a new UK-France "one in, one out" deal, seven returnees have been sent back to France.

articles.title: Leaders of Mexican megachurch led a sprawling sex-trafficking enterprise, US prosecutors allege
articles.trailText: The family behind La Luz del Mundo Church allegedly facilitated sexual abuse of children and women for decades
articles.summary: Prosecutors allege La Luz del Mundo’s founding Joaquín family orchestrated decades of sex trafficking and child abuse within its global evangelical network. Founder Eusebio “Aaron” Joaquín allegedly set a pattern continued by son Samuel and grandson Naasón Joaquín—now the church’s self-styled “Apostle”—and matriarch Eva García. The indictment charges racketeering, grooming of minors under religious pretext, creation of sexual-abuse media and misuse of congregant donations (“love offerings”) to fund luxury lifestyles, abuse props and evidence destruction. Naasón, already jailed in California, pleaded not guilty in New York; Eva remains detained as a flight risk. Both face potential life sentences.

articles.title: At least 40 dead and 124 injured in crush at Vijay rally in India
articles.trailText: Victims include nine children at election campaign gathering in Tamil Nadu led by popular actor and politician
articles.summary: At least 40 people, including nine children, died and 124 were injured in a crowd crush at a Tamilaga Vettri Kazhagam rally led by actor-politician Vijay on September 27 in Karur, Tamil Nadu. Organizers had permission for 10,000 attendees but over 27,000 turned up under sweltering heat and Vijay’s hours-late arrival triggered the fatal surge. Police have filed a criminal case against three TVK leaders and a judicial commission will probe failures in crowd control. Vijay and Prime Minister Modi expressed deep sorrow.

articles.title: Is this the face of Nelson’s lover Lady Hamilton?
articles.trailText: Digital reconstruction from remains found in France bears ‘incredible’ resemblance to British naval hero’s mistress, says expert
articles.summary: French forensic pathologists exhumed a largely intact skeleton in Calais’s English cemetery, carbon-dated to around 1815 and aged 45–55, matching Emma Hamilton’s reported age at death. A scientific digital facial reconstruction yielded an “incredible” resemblance to Nelson’s mistress, though DNA tests and cause-of-death analyses remain inconclusive. Dental traces suggest alcohol abuse, and the absence of common period diseases aligns with her aristocratic lifestyle. Presumed to be Lady Hamilton, the remains were reinterred at Calais’s Notre Dame in a memorial ceremony, pending future advances to confirm her identity.

articles.title: Far-right Facebook groups are engine of radicalisation in UK, data investigation suggests
articles.trailText: Rioters were influenced by network that exposes hundreds of thousands of Britons to racist disinformation, Guardian research indicates
articles.summary: A Guardian investigation found a network of far-right Facebook groups run by ordinary, mostly older UK users has become an ‘engine of radicalisation’, exposing over half a million members to racist, anti-immigrant disinformation, conspiracy theories and extremist tropes. Analysis of 51,000 posts across three major public groups uncovered widespread use of slurs, white-nativist messaging and copied conspiracy narratives. Admins, scattered across England and Wales, moderate yet amplify hate content, fuelling events like last summer’s riots. Experts warn Facebook’s algorithms accelerate this toxic ecosystem amid inadequate content moderation.

articles.title: Reading the post-riot posts: how we traced far-right radicalisation across 51,000 Facebook messages
articles.trailText: Tracing profiles of those charged with online offences in summer 2024 helped us map a thriving social ecosystem trading far-right sentiment and political disillusionment
articles.summary: Analysis of Facebook posts by individuals charged for online offences in the UK’s summer 2024 riots - more than 1,100 charged, some prosecuted for stirring racial hatred - traced five profiles in three public groups, then mapped 13 linked communities. Researchers captured 123,000 text posts, categorizing 51,000 for far-right content via academic keyword lists and GPT-4.1, achieving 93% human–model agreement. They identified anti-immigrant, nativist, anti-establishment and conspiracy narratives thriving on mainstream platforms, sustained by institutional distrust. Classifier accuracy 94.7%, F1 82.6%. Findings reveal a growing radical ecosystem trading misinformation and political disillusionment.

articles.title: As my daughter got sicker and sicker, our quest for answers dragged on. How did we all miss the bacteria taking over her body?
articles.trailText: I write about nature, but when Milly got sick with a mystery illness, it never occurred to me that a long-forgotten tick bite could be the cause
articles.summary: As a nature writer’s daughter Milly fell chronically ill with fatigue, brain fog and pains after a countryside trip, NHS misdiagnosed her with ME/CFS/long Covid: standard Lyme tests were false-negative. A private T-spot test revealed high Borrelia burgdorferi levels plus babesia and bartonella co-infections. Under Dr. Sinclair’s prolonged antibiotic regimen, Milly’s borrelia count plunged from 430.5 to 6. The case spotlights UK under-reporting of complex Lyme, controversial ‘chronic Lyme disease’, diagnostic blind spots and urgent need for improved testing, combined antibiotic protocols and greater medical recognition.

articles.title: Ukraine war briefing: Ukraine discussing ‘mega’ arms deal with US, Zelenskyy says
articles.trailText: Zelenskyy says Ukraine also working on deal to sell drones to the US; Sergei Lavrov tells UN ‘any aggression’ against Russia will be met with ‘decisive response’.
articles.summary: President Zelenskyy says Ukraine has drafted a $90 billion list of US weapons for a “mega deal” and is negotiating to sell drones to Washington, with technical groups mobilizing. He also announced Israel’s US-made Patriot air defence is active in Ukraine, with two more due this fall. Kyiv endured its heaviest Russian bombardment since 2022, prompting Polish airspace closures and allied jets. Russian FM Lavrov warned any aggression against Moscow will be met with a “decisive response”. Meanwhile, the Zaporizhzhia nuclear plant remains without power and Moscow claims capture of three villages.

articles.title: K-cure: South Korea’s booming market for traditional (and novel) hangover remedies
articles.trailText: Hovenia dulcis - known in Korean as heotgae – has become the cornerstone of South Korea’s booming hangover cure industry
articles.summary: South Korea’s £190m hangover-cure market, built around hovenia dulcis (“heotgae”) extracts, jumped 10% to 350bn won in 2024. Sold as soups, drinks, jellies and tablets—often with ginseng or milk thistle—these remedies fuse traditional haejangguk rituals with on-the-go convenience. Despite per-capita alcohol use falling since 2015, young drinkers buy cures as social tokens. Animal studies hint at detox effects but human evidence is scarce; new January 2025 regulations force clinical trials by October or ban claims. The Korean Wave is fueling global demand.

articles.title: Nato to step up vigilance in Baltic Sea region after drones spotted over military bases
articles.trailText: Move comes after new drone sightings near major military installations in Denmark and Norway
articles.summary: NATO pledges to bolster its Baltic Sentry operation after Denmark reported unidentified drones near Karup airbase and other military sites, plus incursions at Copenhagen airport. Enhanced multi-domain assets—including ISR platforms and an air-defense frigate—will patrol the Baltic Sea. Norway and Germany logged flights near Ørland and Schleswig-Holstein; Berlin may authorize military shoot-downs. The alliance launched Eastern Sentry to secure its eastern flank amid Russian drone threats. EU ministers plan a “drone wall” and new detection systems. Denmark blames Russia for professional incursions targeting critical infrastructure.

articles.title: Calls for change after Qantas refuses to fly British woman with mobility scooter due to its battery
articles.trailText: As airlines toughen rules on lithium batteries due to fire danger, disability advocates want clearer accessibility standards
articles.summary: Dr Jurai Darongkamas, a 60-year-old UK clinical psychologist, was barred by Qantas from boarding her New Zealand flight with her Topmate ES33 mobility scooter (281 Wh lithium battery) despite removing the battery and its UN 38.3 certification. Qantas classified it as a “personal electronic device” under IATA rules, conflicting with its recognition as a mobility aid. After six months of complaints and a rejected apology/refund, disability advocates and People With Disabilities Australia say this inconsistency demands clear accessibility standards aligned with the federal aviation white paper.

articles.title: Yvette Cooper suggests international community on brink of Gaza peace deal
articles.trailText: Exclusive: Foreign secretary says world has ‘reached moment’ it wants to end war after Donald Trump signals plan within reach
articles.summary: UK foreign secretary Yvette Cooper told the Guardian that the international community is on the brink of a Gaza peace deal after US President Donald Trump signaled one was within reach. She urged Israel to shift away from its Gaza offensive toward an immediate ceasefire, restoration of humanitarian aid and the release of hostages. Cooper stopped short of accusing Israel of genocide, deferring to legal assessment, and highlighted a fragile yet growing consensus around a 21-point White House plan—including no mass displacement from Gaza, no role for Hamas and no West Bank annexation—and a proposed technocratic transition led by Tony Blair. She warned the process faces serious obstacles and stressed the need to harness fresh momentum to end the humanitarian crisis. Cooper also accused Vladimir Putin of deliberate provocations in Europe and called for stronger NATO sanctions on Russian oil and gas.

articles.title: Family of British couple held in Iran say their health is deteriorating in prison
articles.trailText: Son of Lindsay Foreman expresses ‘real concerns’ after mother put on drip and stepfather, Craig, ‘constantly ill’
articles.summary: British couple Lindsay and Craig Foreman, detained in Iran since January on espionage charges while touring by motorcycle, are suffering deteriorating health in custody. Their son, Joe Bennett, warns his mother was placed on a drip and Craig has endured repeated stomach bugs, flu and dental issues without proper care. With a court hearing imminent, the family decries the FCDO’s lack of updates. Authorities moved Lindsay to Qarchak women’s prison and Craig to Fashafouyeh central prison, both notorious for harsh conditions. The FCDO advises against Britons traveling to Iran and continues consular assistance.

articles.title: Putin preparing to attack another European country, Zelenskyy says
articles.trailText: Ukraine’s president says Kremlin checking Europe’s capacity to protect its skies following new drone sightings
articles.summary: Ukrainian president Volodymyr Zelenskyy warns Vladimir Putin is preparing to extend the war beyond Ukraine, citing recent Russian drone incursions over Denmark, Poland, Romania, and Estonian airspace as tests of NATO’s air defences. After meeting Donald Trump at the UN, Zelenskyy claimed Russia will open a new front in Europe and suggested EU states lack readiness to counter aerial threats. He announced plans to host foreign military representatives in Kyiv for anti-drone training and hinted at retaliatory blackouts in Moscow if Russia targets Ukrainian energy infrastructure this winter. Trump, Zelenskyy said, now has renewed confidence in Ukraine’s battlefield resilience.

articles.title: State department appoints official to handle case of American-Palestinian teen detained by Israel
articles.trailText: Moves marks escalation in diplomatic efforts in case of Mohammed Ibrahim, 16, who is being held in an Israeli military prison
articles.summary: The US state department has assigned a dedicated official to manage the case of Mohammed Ibrahim, a 16-year-old US-Palestinian held in Israel’s Ofer military prison for over seven months on rock-throwing charges. Ibrahim will meet the envoy next week, marking a diplomatic escalation amid his family’s Capitol Hill campaign, which secured bipartisan support from representatives and senators including Pramila Jayapal, Jeff Merkley and Chris Van Hollen. Arrested at 15, Ibrahim has suffered weight loss and scabies with limited consular access. Over 100 civil rights and faith groups, alongside Florida Rep. Kathy Castor, demand his release and fair treatment.

articles.title: ‘A big chance for the populists’: Estonian city alert to the threat of Moscow in its mayoral election
articles.trailText: Positioned on the border and with a 98% Russian-speaking population, Narva faces a test of its unity and resilience
articles.summary: Narva, Estonia’s border city of 53,000 where 98% are Russian-speaking, sees its October mayoral race become a proxy for East-West tensions. Following three MiG-31 overflights and cross-border drone incursions, NATO article 4 talks and a UN Security Council appeal, debate focused on a new Estonian military base. Local grievances—oil shale decline, Soviet memorial removals, Russian-language school phase-out and banned non-EU voters—are magnified by Kremlin propaganda, testing civic cohesion, fueling populist risks and challenging integration efforts.

articles.title: Polish climber makes history skiing down Everest without bottled oxygen
articles.trailText: Poland’s PM hails Andrzej Bargiel’s completion of the challenge after two previous failed attempts
