articles.summary: Andrzej Bargiel, 37-year-old Polish adventure skier, on 25 September 2025 became the first person to climb and ski down Mount Everest (8,849 m) without supplemental oxygen. On his third summit attempt—after aborting in 2019 and 2022—he spent almost 16 hours above 8,000 m in the death zone before tackling a continuous descent via the Khumbu Icefall guided partly by a drone flown by his brother, Bartek. Only about 200 climbers have ever summited Everest without oxygen, but none skied a full downhill. Poland’s PM Donald Tusk hailed it as a landmark in ski mountaineering. Bargiel previously skied K2 in 2018.

articles.title: Trump brags of ‘massive’ oil deal in Pakistan – but drilling has not found any
articles.trailText: Announcement of deal baffles experts and former ministers, who say there is no sign of any untapped reserves
articles.summary: Trump brags of “massive” oil deal in Pakistan after hosting PM Sharif and army chief Munir in the Oval Office, hailing an unexplored “massive” reserve. US granted Pakistan low 19% tariffs and invited bids for 71 onshore and offshore blocks. Experts, including former PPL MD Moin Raza Khan, call claims baseless, citing half-century of drilling that yielded only 65,000 barrels daily and no commercial finds. Major firms have left over costs and security risks in Khyber Pakhtunkhwa and Balochistan. Critics label the deal a political gimmick; auction set for October 31.

articles.title: Two women die trying to cross Channel from France
articles.trailText: French authorities say about 100 people were attempting to reach the UK on a makeshift boat
articles.summary: French authorities report two women died after suffering cardiac arrest during an attempt to cross the Channel in an overcrowded dinghy carrying about 100 migrants. The boat launched at 3.15am off Neufchâtel-Hardelot, drifted without power, and returned an hour later. Rescue teams found the women in cardiopulmonary arrest; a doctor pronounced them dead at 5am. A hypothermic child and both parents were hospitalized. Prosecutors launched an inquiry into the smuggling operation. Officials warn that traffickers are endangering lives amid a surge in crossings—25 fatalities this year—and highlight a bilateral UK–France return scheme.

articles.title: Israeli strikes and shootings kill 57 as assault in Gaza City intensifies
articles.trailText: Health officials say most deaths were in the strip’s largest city, where hundreds of thousands are trapped and starving
articles.summary: Health officials report at least 57 killed in Israeli strikes and gunfire across Gaza, predominantly in Gaza City, where hundreds of thousands remain besieged and starving. Two strikes on Nuseirat refugee camp homes killed nine family members and a further 13 civilians; another airstrike on a tent shelter claimed five lives. Tanks encircle Shifa hospital, restricting access to 159 patients, while Helou hospital’s neonatal unit is sealed amid drone overflights. Netanyahu told the UN Israel “must finish the job” as a UN genocide inquiry and recognition of Palestinian statehood by the UK, France, Canada and Australia coincide with a collapsing Gaza health sector and MSF suspending operations.

articles.title: Galápagos Islands, wildlife haven, faces a sexual violence epidemic: ‘Protection is nonexistent’
articles.trailText: While Ecuador’s islands are protected for its rich fauna, they are not a place of safety for many of its women and girls
articles.summary: Ecuador’s Galápagos Islands, a 33,000-strong UNESCO-protected wildlife reserve, is grappling with endemic sexual violence. On sparsely populated Isla Isabela, three 15-year-old girls were drugged and raped at El Mango viewpoint. Local authorities routinely dismiss or delay cases; only 5% of reported assaults lead to convictions. Grassroots group Magma and Our Rescue have supported over 100 cases and allege child trafficking rings. High official turnover, scarce shelters and forensics, and community backlash deter survivors from reporting.

articles.title: ‘Water off a duck’s back’: will Israel’s growing isolation make its leadership change course?
articles.trailText: For many Israelis, Netanyahu’s warning to get used to growing isolation confirmed what they already suspected of his priorities
articles.summary: Despite widespread international condemnation of its Gaza offensive and rising threats of cultural, sports and research boycotts, many Israelis—from Sderot residents like Moshe Abutbul to Netanyahu’s staunch right-wing base—remain unfazed. Netanyahu’s defiant UN speech condemned recent Palestinian state recognitions and framed isolation as inevitable. Europe’s concert cancellations, potential Eurovision ban and Horizon programme pull-outs signal eroding ties, yet polls show 59% fear cultural exclusion and half favour ending the war to free hostages. Analysts warn that isolation currently consolidates Netanyahu’s supporters more than sways them, though comparisons to South Africa’s apartheid era hint at possible long-term risks.

articles.title: Moldovan diaspora critical in elections as country battles Russian vote-buying, says former minister
articles.trailText: Watchdogs say Russia offering overseas voters cash for evidence of voter fraud in possible ploy to declare election rigged
articles.summary: In Moldova’s pivotal parliamentary elections on Sunday, the diaspora — which provided 19% of ballots in 2024 — faces a massive Russian-led vote-buying effort. Civilian watchdogs report offers of up to €500 for overseas observers plus bonuses of €30,000 for alleged fraud evidence, aimed at sowing doubt rather than swinging pro-Russian voters. Pro-European president Maia Sandu and former deputy PM Nicu Popescu warn of unprecedented cash campaigns via crypto and bank transfers. Authorities have arrested dozens over a Russia-backed plot to incite violence, while Serbia detained suspects organizing protest training. Experts fear the ploy could contest results, threatening Moldova’s EU bid and national independence.

articles.title: Safety fears as external power to Zaporizhzhia nuclear plant still out after three days
articles.trailText: Ukrainian officials among those concerned Russia is manufacturing crisis to keep hold of frontline plant
articles.summary: Over three days of external-power outage at Russia-held Zaporizhzhia nuclear plant have forced reliance on emergency generators for cooling, raising alarms from the IAEA’s Rafael Grossi. Ukraine and Western experts warn the Kremlin may be manufacturing an energy crisis to tighten control and press to connect the site to Russia’s grid and restart reactors—despite exceeding 72-hour safety stress-test limits. Satellite imagery shows new Russian power line works via Mariupol. Greenpeace urges IAEA to block any wartime reactor restart to avert potential meltdown.

articles.title: Will the EU’s new fingerprint entry system cause gridlock? The Guardian tried it out
articles.trailText: The scheme, which operators feared would cause chaos at airports, ports and railway stations, is finally coming into force
articles.summary: This article reports that from 12 October the EU’s biometric entry–exit system (EES) forces non-EU nationals, including post-Brexit UK travellers, to register faces and fingerprints at Schengen borders. Lacking a pre-registration app, Eurostar, Eurotunnel and the Port of Dover have installed kiosks, reconfigured lanes and staged phased rollouts to process thousands per hour. Trials at Folkestone showed about two minutes per person; on re-entry or subsequent trips facial recognition alone applies. A six-month introductory period with EU safeguards allows delays or suspensions if queues spike, as Germany staggers implementation and Sweden pilots a registration app.

articles.title: Moldova’s election is a choice between two paths: pro-Europe or pro-Russia
articles.trailText: Western-friendly ruling party faces fierce challenge from opposition amid reports of Kremlin interference
articles.summary: Moldova's upcoming parliamentary election pits pro-European Action and Solidarity party (PAS), led by President Maia Sandu, against the pro-Russian Patriotic Electoral Bloc under former president Igor Dodon. Polls suggest a tight race in which PAS may lose its majority, giving sway to smaller parties like the Alternative bloc—nominally pro-EU but seen as a Kremlin-backed spoiler. The outcome will define Moldova’s trajectory toward EU accession or renewed Russian alignment. Reports detail extensive Kremlin interference—funding, propaganda, clergy influence, alleged plots to foment unrest—and 1,500 troops in Transnistria. Economic woes and refugee influx strain services. Western capitals view the vote as a strategic litmus test for Europe’s eastern frontier.

articles.title: Barricades in Bari: why the city’s ‘pasta grannies’ are under scrutiny
articles.trailText: Sellers of fresh orecchiette in southern Italy are fighting back after being accused of tricking tourists with bought wares
articles.summary: Bari’s famed ‘pasta grannies’—a handful of women who craft and sell fresh orecchiette on Via dell’Arco Basso—have risen to global renown via tourists and celebrity endorsements. This summer, plainclothes officers seized pasta and equipment amid allegations that some sold industrial orecchiette as homemade, flouting safety and fiscal rules. Three women were fined €5,000 and they barricaded the alley in protest. A yearlong prosecutor probe, sparked by a legal complaint over discarded factory-pasta cartons, continues. City Council backs the tradition but demands compliance. Veteran maker Nunzia Caputo, unpenalised, vows to carry on.

articles.title: Ukraine war briefing: Russia’s latest offensives have failed, say Zelenskyy and his top commander
articles.trailText: Ukrainian president says heavy battlefield losses inflicted on Russia while Oleksandr Syrskyi says Kyiv has disrupted Moscow’s spring and summer campaign. What we know on day 1,312
articles.summary: Ukrainian president Volodymyr Zelenskyy and commander-in-chief Oleksandr Syrskyi say Russia’s spring and summer offensives have failed, inflicting heavy Russian casualties near Dobropillia, disrupting buffer-zone plans in Sumy, Kharkiv and Pokrovsk, and halting advances in Donetsk. Moscow’s “thousand cuts” infantry assaults have been routed, with Ukraine trapping forces at the Kazenyi Torets river and holding a 1,250 km front. Ukraine’s military intelligence accuses Russia of drone incursions into Poland to test NATO and erode Western support. In Brussels, EU ministers back a €140 bn loan to Kyiv and fast-track a drone-wall defence, while Belarus proposes a new nuclear plant to power occupied regions.

articles.title: World must deny Israel ‘tools of genocide’, says growing alliance of activist states
articles.trailText: New York meeting of Hague Group warns of shared responsibility to prevent genocide and proposes steps to isolate Israel
articles.summary: At a UNGA-side meeting in New York, Malaysian FM Mohamad Hasan convened the Hague Group—co-chaired by South Africa and Colombia—urging states to fulfill their legal duty to deny Israel “tools of genocide”. The alliance proposed halting arms and dual-use machinery transfers at ports and airports, blacklisting firms complicit in Israel’s occupation, and supporting Gaza aid flotillas. Brazil joined South Africa’s ICJ genocide case and called for an anti-apartheid-style international mission; Chile recalled its ambassador. Palestine’s UN envoy praised the group, while a UN experts’ report labels Israel’s Gaza operations genocidal, which PM Netanyahu denies.

articles.title: EU to move forward with plans for drone wall amid Russian incursions
articles.trailText: Ministers aim to bolster defences after spate of airspace violations, amid rising momentum for €140bn loan to Ukraine
articles.summary: After convening with 10 CEE ministers and Ukraine’s representatives, the EU will fast-track a “drone wall”—deploying radars, acoustic sensors and intercept systems—to defend its eastern flank after recent Russian drone incursions in Denmark, Poland, Romania and fighter-jet airspace violations over Estonia. The Commission highlights cost mismatches in shooting missiles at low-cost drones. Meanwhile, a leaked proposal outlines a €140bn interest-free loan to Ukraine, collateralized by frozen Russian central bank assets via Euroclear, using a legal workaround to bypass unanimity and Hungary’s veto. Germany’s chancellor Merz backs the plan ahead of an October summit.

articles.title: Canada postal workers strike after government orders end to door-to-door delivery
articles.trailText: Union says it’s ‘outraged and appalled’ by government’s order of sweeping changes to the national service
articles.summary: Canada Post workers launched a national strike after Ottawa declared an ‘existential crisis’ at the crown corporation, citing a record $407 m quarterly loss and ordering an end to door-to-door delivery within a decade, closure of post offices, and labour-cost cuts. The union, outraged at the government’s ‘attack’, halted all mail operations after 20 months of deadlocked talks. The government, sole shareholder, has 45 days for a restructuring plan; businesses warn of a C$1 bn holiday-season hit.

articles.title: Netanyahu vows to ‘finish job’ in Gaza during UN speech as delegates walk out
articles.trailText: Israeli prime minister said recognition of Palestinian state is ‘insane’ days after countries such as UK and France did so
articles.summary: At the UNGA, Israeli PM Benjamin Netanyahu vowed to “finish the job” in Gaza, dismissing Palestinian statehood as “insane” and a two-state solution “sheer madness,” prompting over 100 diplomats from 50+ countries to walk out. He compared statehood to granting al-Qaeda territory after 9/11, denied genocide allegations, and vowed to press on with an offensive on Gaza City despite more than 20 civilian deaths. With Trump pledging to block West Bank annexation, Netanyahu issued Hamas an ultimatum to free all hostages or face intensified operations, as thousands protested in New York.

articles.title: Nicolas Sarkozy’s lawyers will try to ensure time in prison is ‘as short as possible’
articles.trailText: Former French president sentenced to five years for criminal conspiracy over election campaign funds scheme with Gaddafi regime
articles.summary: After his five-year sentence for criminal conspiracy over Gaddafi campaign funds, former president Nicolas Sarkozy’s lawyers say they will seek the shortest possible jail term while his appeal proceeds. A special provision forces him to begin incarceration in the coming weeks, with a 13 October hearing to set his entry date and potential alternatives such as an electronic bracelet. Les Républicains voice support without urging a pardon. Reactions range from Le Figaro’s shock at the ruling to Le Monde’s praise of rule-of-law, and magistrates note most five-year sentences start immediately.

articles.title: Israeli loudspeakers broadcast Netanyahu’s speech to UN into Gaza
articles.trailText: Operation prompts outrage as Israeli PM criticises western countries for recognising Palestine as a state and pledges to continue war
articles.summary: In an unprecedented psy-ops operation at Prime Minister Netanyahu’s behest, Israeli Defense Forces placed truck-mounted loudspeakers along Gaza’s border—and alleged control of Gazan phone lines—to relay his UN General Assembly address into Gaza. He warned residents the war would end only after Hamas’s disarmament, the hostages’ release and Gaza’s demilitarisation, and denounced Western recognition of Palestine. The move sparked domestic outrage and dissenting military voices calling it a “crazy idea.” Meanwhile, Gaza’s civil defence reported 22 deaths in fresh strikes as UN experts warn of famine after 65,000 Palestinians killed and much of Gaza reduced to ruins.

articles.title: Ladakh statehood activist arrested days after violent crackdown by Modi
articles.trailText: Sonam Wangchuk, who has been agitating against the government, was on his way to speak at a press briefing
articles.summary: Renowned Ladakh environmentalist Sonam Wangchuk, inventor and education activist behind the ice stupa and inspiration for film 'Three Idiots', was arrested after a violent state crackdown on protests in Leh, where BJP offices were burned and four protesters killed by live fire. Wangchuk, leading a movement for Ladakh statehood and regional autonomy since Kashmir’s 2019 status change, was accused of inciting violence via references to the Arab Spring and Nepal anti-corruption protests—charges he denies. His NGO’s foreign funding registration has been revoked and his school faces a criminal probe, part of a wider suppression of dissent under PM Modi.

articles.title: Rover-tourism row: Italian province considers tax on visiting dogs
articles.trailText: Plan to charge €1.50-a-night ‘tourist tax’ for dogs to help cover costs of cleaning up waste is criticised as ‘madness’
articles.summary: Bolzano province in Italy’s Trentino-Alto Adige region has proposed a €1.50-per-night tourist tax on visiting dogs and €100-per-year fee for resident pets to fund street cleaning and new dog parks, following a failed DNA-testing scheme. Councillor Luis Walcher argues it shifts costs from taxpayers to dog owners, but animal rights group Aidaa and Enpa condemn it as “madness,” vowing civil disobedience, while Bolzano’s mayor warns it damages the region’s pet-friendly image amid Italy’s growing pro-dog initiatives.

articles.title: Drug traffickers livestream torture and killing of young Argentinian women and girl
articles.trailText: Brenda del Castillo, Morena Verdi and Lara Gutiérrez were lured with a promise of a $300 payment for a ‘sex party’
articles.summary: Brenda del Castillo (20), Morena Verdi (20) and 15-year-old Lara Gutiérrez were lured to a Buenos Aires house with a $300 promise for a “sex party”, then seized by suspected drug traffickers, tortured on a private Instagram livestream viewed by 45 people and killed. Officials link the murders to revenge after one victim allegedly stole cocaine from the Villa 1-11-14 gang. Two men and two women have been arrested, including an alleged cleanup crew. The killings prompted nationwide protests, highlighting rising narco violence, poverty-driven recruitment under President Milei and fears of expanding mafias in marginalized neighborhoods.

articles.title: ‘We were obedient our entire lives’: the nuns who broke back into their convent
articles.trailText: Three nuns fled a care home to return to the convent, defying church orders and gaining global support – but their future remains unknown
articles.summary: Three octogenarian Augustinian sisters - Bernadette (88), Regina (86) and Rita (82) - escaped a Salzburg care home on 4 September, breaching their vow of obedience to reoccupy Schloss Goldenstein, their 150-year-old convent. With help from former pupils, tradespeople and 200 volunteers, they restored utilities and built a 50,000-strong global fanbase via daily updates. They claim legal 'stabilitas loci' rights, accusing the provost of seizing recipes, letters, a stairlift and bank accounts; he insists the move was protective. Their fate now hinges on church negotiations and possible intervention by Pope Leo.

articles.title: Trump says he ‘will not allow’ Israel to annex West Bank after lobbying from allies
articles.trailText: British officials said they feared Trump would recognise Israeli control over the West Bank in retaliation for the UK, Australia, France and others recognising Palestine
articles.summary: Donald Trump told reporters he would block any Israeli annexation of the occupied West Bank, rejecting pressure from far-right Israeli factions amid speculation Benjamin Netanyahu might retaliate over recent UK, Australia, France and others’ recognition of Palestine. Speaking in the Oval Office before Netanyahu’s UN address, Trump said “It’s time to stop now.” Arab and European allies lobbied him to oppose settlement recognition. Israel’s options include full or partial annexation (notably the E1 project). Trump also previewed a 21-point US peace plan to end the Gaza war, secure hostages and restore regional stability.

articles.title: Ukraine war briefing: UN watchdog sounds warning after drone detonates near Ukraine nuclear plant
articles.trailText: IAEA chief says no damage to South Ukraine nuclear facility but ‘next time we may not be so lucky’; Russia accused of ‘arbitrary killings’ of PoWs. What we know on day 1,311
articles.summary: A drone detonated 800 m from South Ukraine nuclear plant, IAEA warned “next time we may not be so lucky,” noting no reactor damage despite close drone activity. Russia-held Zaporizhzhia has been offline 48 h after power lines fell, operating on backup diesel. An OSCE report accuses Russia of arbitrary killings, torture and unlawful prosecutions of Ukrainian PoWs. At the UN, Lavrov blamed NATO/EU for a “real war.” The US approved 400 air-to-air missiles for Germany; Merz proposed a €140 bn EU loan from frozen Russian assets to fund Ukraine. Russian strikes cut power to 70 000 in Chernihiv. Zelenskiy met US firms to expand drone exports and said he won’t seek reelection post-war.

articles.title: Civilian injuries in Gaza similar to those of soldiers in war zones, study finds
articles.trailText: Wounds such as burns or leg injuries are more common in Gaza than among US soldiers who fought in Iraq and Afghanistan
articles.summary: Civilians in Gaza are suffering combat-style wounds on a scale and severity comparable or worse than US soldiers in Iraq and Afghanistan, a BMJ study finds. Based on August 2024–February 2025 hospital data from 78 experts across 22 NGOs, nearly 24,000 trauma injuries were logged—two-thirds from explosions, 18% burns (over 10% fourth-degree), and 30% gunshots (almost 10% to the head). The research links indiscriminate aerial/heavy bombardment and malnutrition-exacerbated outcomes amid severe supply restrictions. Findings intensify scrutiny of Israel’s tactics in the two-year war following Hamas’s October 2023 attacks.

articles.title: Iran snapback sanctions loom as UN security council set to vote on nuclear programme
articles.trailText: Russian efforts to delay the return of sanctions is expected to fail during vote on Friday
articles.summary: On Friday the UN Security Council will vote on Russia’s bid to defer reinstating large-scale snapback sanctions on Iran by six months following European rejection of Tehran’s last-minute offer to grant IAEA inspectors limited access to one bombed site and to propose within 45 days a plan for its 400kg of highly enriched uranium in exchange for permanently lifting sanctions. Russia lacks the nine votes needed. The move signals a sharp Iran-West rift, criticism of IAEA’s Grossi, and raises risks of hardliner backlash in Tehran, potential NPT withdrawal and further Israeli strikes.

articles.title: Fighter jets purchase would put UK in breach of nuclear treaty, says CND
articles.trailText: Legal opinion for campaign group says deal amounts to reversal of UK’s commitment to nuclear disarmament
articles.summary: Legal opinion by LSE experts for CND warns Labour’s £1bn purchase of 12 F-35A jets—chosen for their dual conventional and nuclear capability to carry US B61-12 bombs—breaches Article VI of the NPT, reversing the UK’s 1998 disarmament commitment and reinstating the RAF’s nuclear role without parliamentary debate. CND accuses ministers of hypocrisy and illegal escalation, pointing to the recent 40% warhead cap increase for Trident. The MoD defends the deal as vital for security amid global nuclear rearmament in the US, Russia, and China.

articles.title: Is Trump’s new Palestine plan a breakthrough or diplomatic mirage?
articles.trailText: Washington’s roadmap aligns surprisingly closely with a UN-backed plan – but key differences could prove unworkable
articles.summary: Trump’s 21-point plan and the UN-backed New York declaration both endorse a two-state roadmap: no mass Gaza expulsions, Hamas weapon decommissioning, and a freeze on West Bank annexations. It envisions a transitional authority—potentially led by Tony Blair—for separate Gaza and West Bank governance, a phased Israeli withdrawal, border stabilization troops and foreign-trained Palestinian security units. Crucial differences persist over PA-led unity, benchmarks for PA reform, Unrwa’s reconstruction role and annexation definitions that shape Arab state buy-in.

articles.title: Washington backing plan for Tony Blair to head transitional Gaza authority
articles.trailText: Reported proposal for international body to oversee Gaza for up to five years counters UN-backed plan for faster transition to Palestinian rule
articles.summary: Washington supports a proposal for former UK PM Tony Blair to lead a five-year Gaza International Transitional Authority (Gita), initially outside Palestinian Authority control, modeled on Timor-Leste and Kosovo transitions. Based in el-Arish before deploying inside Gaza with a UN-endorsed Arab force, Gita would act as supreme political and legal authority via a seven-person board, 25-member secretariat and five commissioners overseeing humanitarian, reconstruction, legal, security and PA coordination. The interim plan lacks a clear PA handover timeline, prompting Palestinian, Arab and UN criticism amid a competing New York declaration for faster transition.

articles.title: Doug Ford to ban speed cameras in Ontario in populist appeal to suburban voters
articles.trailText: Canada premier’s move prompts criticism from road safety activists and is likely to cue new showdown with Toronto
articles.summary: Ontario premier Doug Ford plans to ban municipal speed cameras, denouncing them as revenue grabs. He previously authorized them in 2019 but now says only 37 of 444 municipalities back them. Critics, including Toronto mayor Olivia Chow and police chiefs, warn speed cameras reduce speeding and protect vulnerable road users; a study found camera zones cut speeding by 45% in downtown school areas. Ford pledges a new road-safety fund. Chow warns removal would endanger pedestrians after a recent youth fatality and urges enhanced signage and a one-ticket cap per camera per week.

articles.title: Sarkozy’s spectacular downfall marks turning point in France’s struggle against graft
articles.trailText: Experts say political legacy of former president convicted of criminal conspiracy now appears impossible to rebuild
articles.summary: Nicolas Sarkozy, France’s 2007–12 president, was handed a five-year prison term with a strict mandate to report to jail by February for criminal conspiracy over illicit Libyan campaign funds—making him the first modern ex-president ordered behind bars. Judges stressed the ‘exceptional gravity’ of undermining citizens’ trust; his appeal will not suspend detention. Once a law‐and‐order champion, Sarkozy’s political legacy now seems irreparable. His downfall follows two prior graft convictions and parallels recent rulings against Marine Le Pen, reflecting an assertive French judiciary determined to hold current and former leaders accountable and deter future political corruption.

articles.title: Sarkozy says he will ‘sleep in jail but with head held high’ after conviction
articles.trailText: Former French president receives five-year prison sentence for criminal conspiracy over pact with Gaddafi regime
articles.summary: Nicolas Sarkozy, France’s president from 2007–12, was sentenced to five years in prison—enforced even if he appeals—and fined €100,000 after Judge Nathalie Gavarino found him guilty of criminal conspiracy in a secret pact with Muammar Gaddafi’s regime to fund his 2007 campaign. He was acquitted of corruption and misuse of Libyan public funds. Sarkozy, who denies wrongdoing, says he will “sleep in jail with my head held high” and will appeal. Co-defendants Claude Guéant and Brice Hortefeux were also convicted of conspiracy while others were acquitted. His wife, Carla Bruni-Sarkozy, staged a protest outside court.

articles.title: Talks on European ‘drone wall’ after Danish airport incursions
articles.trailText: European ministers to hold talks on Friday on how to defend infrastructure after airports affected, including the closure of Copenhagen
articles.summary: Denmark reported coordinated drone incursions on four airports—Aalborg, Billund, Esbjerg, Sønderborg and Skrydstrup—hours after three drones closed Copenhagen on Sept 22–23, prompting officials to call it a ‘hybrid attack’. EU ministers from ten states, including Ukraine and the Baltics, will meet on Sept 25 to plan an EU-funded “drone wall” under the €150 bn Security Action for Europe scheme. Commission spokesperson Thomas Regnier highlighted detection and neutralisation challenges. Denmark’s defence minister signalled possible NATO Article 4 activation, and investigators are probing Russian vessels spotted offshore. Critics have pressed for stronger kinetic or legal measures to shoot down threatening drones.

articles.title: Palestinian statehood is more than just a mantra | Letters
articles.trailText: Letters: Critics who claim that recognising Palestine rewards terrorism are wrong, writes Lu’ayy Minwer Al-Rimawi. Plus letters from Jane Caplan and a Gaza resident caught up in the conflict
articles.summary: In letters responding to UK’s recognition of Palestine, Lu’ayy Al-Rimawi applauds the moves by UK, Australia and Canada, rejects claims that recognition “rewards” Hamas, condemns collective punishment of Palestinians and underscores the need for accountable, corruption-free Palestinian state institutions. A Gaza academic recounts 11 displacements in two years, dire humanitarian conditions and calls for international rights recognition. Historian Jane Caplan likens current Israeli proposals for Gaza’s remaking to Nazi ghettoisation, warning against ethnic cleansing. All letters stress peace, security and dignity for Arabs and Jews as the only path forward.

articles.title: ‘Inclusive’ Israel has always excluded the Palestinians | Letters
articles.trailText: Letters: Peter Prinsley missed a key point in his account of being barred from Israel, writes Dr Hilary Kilpatrick . Plus a letter from Owen Holland
articles.summary: In letters responding to MP Peter Prinsley’s barred-entry report, Dr Hilary Kilpatrick argues that Israel’s founding ethos of openness never extended to Palestinians, citing Elias Khoury’s Gate of the Sun which chronicles the 1948 expulsion and enduring exclusion. Seventy-seven years later, she warns, lasting peace is impossible without recognition and redress of Palestinian dispossession. Owen Holland adds a domestic parallel, likening Israel’s 'crass, authoritarian' tactics to the UK government’s proscription of Palestine Action, and urges Prinsley to condemn both.

articles.title: Activists outraged after Rio lawmakers approve ‘wild west bonus’ for police who kill ‘criminals’
articles.trailText: Similar legislation introduced in Rio in mid-1990s caused an explosion of extrajudicial killings in the city’s favelas
articles.summary: Rio de Janeiro’s parliament voted 47-15 to reinstate a “wild west bonus” paying civil police 10-150% extra for seizing high-caliber arms or “neutralizing criminals,” reviving a mid-1990s policy tied to surging extrajudicial killings in favelas. Backers, many aligned with Jair Bolsonaro’s allies, praised the measure as necessary to crush armed drug factions, evoking El Salvador’s crackdown under Nayib Bukele. Critics warn it incentivizes state violence, violates Brazil’s ban on the death penalty and disproportionately targets young Black men in low-income communities. Human rights activists, legal experts and opposition lawmakers decry the plan as unconstitutional, cruel and a return to past bloodshed, pending approval by Governor Cláudio Castro.

articles.title: Why are Moldova’s parliamentary elections on Sunday so important?
articles.trailText: The background, key players and likely outcome of a contest of crucial interest to both Europe and Russia
articles.summary: Moldova’s 25 Sep parliamentary vote will decide if the ex-Soviet republic, led by pro-EU president Maia Sandu and her PAS party, can secure a majority to continue EU integration and reforms. Sandu faces a strong challenge from the pro-Russian Patriotic bloc under ex-president Igor Dodon, with spoiler centrist Alternativa and populist Our Party also competing. Key factors include diaspora ballots and low turnout in Transnistria amid disinformation. Polls show PAS narrowly ahead but possibly short of a majority, risking deadlock or a pro-Russian coalition. Russian hybrid tactics—vote-buying, cyber-attacks and propaganda—threaten election integrity and Moldova’s Western trajectory.

articles.title: Netanyahu flies circuitous route to UN summit ‘to avoid arrest’ in Europe
articles.trailText: Wing of Zion followed Mediterranean Sea, tracking data shows, amid ICC arrest warrant
articles.summary: Benjamin Netanyahu rerouted his state jet, the Wing of Zion, along a longer Mediterranean path to avoid overflying European ICC member states obligated to arrest him under an International Criminal Court warrant for alleged starvation warfare. Tracking data shows it crossed Greece and Italy, then veered south via Gibraltar to the Atlantic, despite France approving its airspace. Israeli media say the detour prevented a forced landing. Critics note prior similar reroutes amid fears of emergency landings post-surgery. Netanyahu, who rejects ICC authority, is headed to the UN to meet President Trump.

articles.title: Abbas decries Israel’s ‘genocide’ and says Hamas will have no role in future Gaza government
articles.trailText: Palestinian Authority president speaks to UN by video about Israel’s ‘war crime’ after visa was revoked by the US
articles.summary: Addressing the UN remotely after a US visa ban, PA president Mahmoud Abbas condemned Israel’s “war of genocide” and settlement expansion, labeling the Gaza assault a documented war crime. He urged an immediate ceasefire, unhindered humanitarian aid, Israeli withdrawal, and release of hostages and prisoners, while calling for formal recognition of Palestinian statehood. Abbas denounced Hamas’s October 7 attack, vowed its disarmament and exclusion from any Gaza governance—offering the PA full security responsibility—warned against E1 settlement plans and annexation, and rejected equating pro-Palestine support with antisemitism.

articles.title: Microsoft blocks Israel’s use of its technology in mass surveillance of Palestinians
articles.trailText: Exclusive: Tech firm ends military unit’s access to AI and data services after Guardian reveals secret spy project
articles.summary: Microsoft has revoked Israel’s Unit 8200 access to Azure cloud storage and AI services after a Guardian-led investigation exposed a secret mass surveillance programme, launched after a 2021 Nadella–Sariel meeting, intercepting up to a million Palestinian phone calls per hour and storing some 8,000 TB of data in its European datacenter. Citing terms-of-service breaches, Microsoft disabled services following an external inquiry, amid employee and investor pressure and UN concerns over Gaza. Unit 8200 swiftly migrated data to AWS. This marks the first US tech cut-off of Israeli military services, raising questions about overseas hosting of sensitive intelligence.

articles.title: Labour faces legal scrutiny after allowing chickens to be carried by legs
articles.trailText: Practice was forbidden under EU law, but secondary legislation came into force in July permitting it in England, Wales and Scotland
articles.summary: Labour faces a high court challenge after a statutory instrument enacted on 22 July overturned an EU ban on carrying chickens (and turkeys under 5kg) by their legs in England, Wales and Scotland. The Animal Law Foundation, citing pain, fractures, suffocation risk and flawed consultation, argues the government should have enforced existing welfare rules rather than dilute them. Campaigners call it the first post-Brexit weakening of animal welfare regulations. Defra insists it remains committed to robust health and welfare standards despite permitting the contentious handling method.

articles.title: Is Trump right that Russia’s economy is on the brink of collapse?
articles.trailText: While VAT is going up to finance the war and fuel is in short supply, few expect Putin to adjust his war plans
articles.summary: Donald Trump declared Russia’s economy on the brink of collapse and predicted a Ukrainian victory, but economists argue collapse is unlikely despite Moscow’s tightest strain since 2022. GDP growth is forecast at under 1%, VAT rises to 22%, defence spending consumes 40% of the budget, and the deficit surges amid depleted reserves. Western sanctions have been partly evaded via shadow fleets, parallel imports and energy exports to China, India and Turkey. Ukraine’s drone strikes have disrupted refineries and fuel supplies, but analysts doubt economic pain or repressed public dissent will force Putin to alter his war strategy.

articles.title: Canada: order to cull over 400 ostriches sparks protests and death threats
articles.trailText: Activists and Trump supporters protest at Universal Ostrich Farms even after 69 birds succumbed to flu-like illness
articles.summary: In Edgewood, BC, Universal Ostrich Farms was ordered to cull over 400 birds after 69 died of suspected H5N1, prompting a Supreme Court stay and fierce protests from animal rights activists and Trump allies. Figures like RFK Jr, Mehmet Oz, Chris Sanders and John Catsimatidis lobbied to relocate the flock. Supporters have harassed local businesses and threatened inspection agencies. Farm owners, arrested for obstructing food inspectors, dispute testing and cite partial herd immunity. Public health authorities cite WHO guidance and a federal court ruling to justify the cull.

articles.title: Taiwan convicts four former ruling party officials of spying for China
articles.trailText: Huang Chu-jung, previously an assistant to a New Taipei city councillor, receives longest sentence of 10 years
articles.summary: Taiwan’s top court convicted four former Democratic Progressive Party aides, including a past vice-presidential and presidential aide to Lai Ching-te and a senior staffer to ex-foreign minister Joseph Wu, of spying for China. Huang Chu-jung, ex-assistant to a New Taipei councillor, received 10 years and NT$1 million fine for espionage and money laundering; ex-DPP Democracy Institute deputy head Chiu Shih-yuan got 6 years 2 months. Prosecutors may appeal for harsher sentences. Under President Lai’s tougher stance on pro-China sympathies, Taiwan has stepped up security measures against alleged “grey zone” infiltration, espionage and disinformation from Beijing.

articles.title: Weakened Super Typhoon Ragasa heads towards Vietnam after battering China and Hong Kong
articles.trailText: Huge clear-up efforts start after storm leaves trail of destruction, with 25 reported dead in Taiwan and the Philippines
articles.summary: Super Typhoon Ragasa, the strongest cyclone in 2025 with 165 mph winds, left 25 dead in Taiwan (14) and the Philippines (11) before battering Hong Kong and southern China. Guangdong evacuated over 2 million residents, saw 50,000 trees felled in Yangjiang and 56,000 households lose power; Zhuhai rescuers used inflatable boats to free stranded residents as first‐floor homes flooded. In Hong Kong, flights resumed under signal 3, schools remained closed and a hotel lobby was inundated. Now a weakened tropical storm heading to Vietnam, PM Phạm Minh Chính has mobilized dam and hospital protections, vessel security and rescue teams.

articles.title: DNA tests to determine if heart belongs to Australian man who died in Bali
articles.trailText: Australian officials demanded answers after the body of Byron Haddow was returned without his heart
articles.summary: Australian authorities are conducting DNA tests on a heart returned from Bali to verify it belongs to 23-year-old Byron Haddow, found dead in his villa's plunge pool in May. His body arrived in Australia four weeks later, but the heart was missing until two months after his death. Prof Ngoerah hospital in Bali denies organ theft, stating the heart underwent forensic examination at police request and was delayed by legal processing. Haddow’s family, distressed by unauthorised autopsy and extra repatriation fees, demand transparency, an independent investigation, and answers on the organ’s removal.

articles.title: Thursday briefing: Why Starmer’s fixer is back in the headlines
articles.trailText: In today’s newsletter: With Labour’s conference looming, Morgan McSweeney’s role in Labour Together donations threatens to engulf the party in another scandal
articles.summary: As Labour’s conference nears, Keir Starmer’s chief of staff Morgan McSweeney faces renewed scrutiny over undeclared £739,000 of Labour Together donations after a leaked 2021 email suggests he advised downplaying the breaches as administrative errors. First reported in 2021, the revelations have been revived by Tory and Daily Mail attacks to undermine Starmer’s judgment and question transparency in party funding. Critics say timing ahead of conference reveals political motive, while Labour dismisses it as old news and administrative oversight. The row revives concerns about secretive campaign vehicles, factional tactics and Starmer’s oversight within party ranks.

articles.title: Generational change or gender breakthrough, whoever Japan’s next PM is will have a mountain to climb
articles.trailText: Two candidates have emerged as favourites to head Japan’s Liberal Democratic Party, ahead of the party vote next week
articles.summary: Japan’s ruling Liberal Democratic Party will choose next leader from two front-runners: 44-year-old Shinjiro Koizumi, who could become the youngest postwar prime minister and has softened progressive stances on gender and migration to appeal to conservatives, and 64-year-old Sanae Takaichi, a right-wing hawk admiring Thatcher, critical of China, downplaying wartime guilt and campaigning hardline on immigration. They race to unite a party weakened by funding scandals, election defeats and cost-of-living pressures in a vote by 295 lawmakers and rank-and-file members ahead of parliament loss of majority.

articles.title: ‘Tunnel vision’: how Israel is using archaeology to win US support for goals
articles.trailText: Scientists say Netanyahu government and its US backers are trying to construct a history shorn of all complexity
articles.summary: During US Secretary of State Marco Rubio’s visit to Jerusalem, Prime Minister Netanyahu staged tours of excavations at the Western Wall and the “Pilgrimage Road” tunnel in the City of David park, accompanied by evangelical US ambassador Mike Huckabee, to underscore a purely Jewish narrative of Jerusalem and bolster GOP evangelical support for Israeli territorial claims. Independent archaeologists and a UN commission denounce these digs as politically driven “tunnel vision” that omits Palestinian and multi-era heritage. Meanwhile, Israeli bombing of Gaza’s main archaeological warehouse destroyed three decades of artifacts, drawing international condemnation.

articles.title: Paris court to rule on Nicolas Sarkozy corruption charge
articles.trailText: Former president and others accused of receiving millions of euros in illegal election funding from Libyan regime of Muammar Gaddafi
articles.summary: A Paris court will rule on whether Nicolas Sarkozy and 12 co-defendants received millions in illicit campaign funds from Muammar Gaddafi’s Libya in what prosecutors call a “corruption pact.” After a three-month trial, the state prosecutor has sought a seven-year sentence for the former president, who denies wrongdoing. Allegations focused on suitcase deliveries of cash to fund Sarkozy’s successful 2007 campaign in exchange for diplomatic and legal favors, including lifting the international warrant against Gaddafi’s spy chief. Thursday’s verdict follows emotional testimony from families of victims of a 1989 Libya-linked air disaster and the sudden Beirut death of key intermediary Ziad Takieddine.

articles.title: Yemen needs two-state solution as no prospect of ousting Houthis, says southern leader
articles.trailText: Aidarous al-Zubaidi says Houthis will not be dislodged by bombing and path to political settlement is blocked
articles.summary: STC president Aidarous al-Zubaidi told the Guardian at the UNGA that bombing alone cannot oust Iran-backed Houthis and that Yemen requires a formal two-state solution mirroring the de facto north/south split. He referenced the 1967–90 division and the 2014 Houthi takeover, plus failed Saudi, US and Israeli campaigns. Frustrated by the Saudi-UN unity council, the STC has made unilateral regional appointments. Southern services, oil exports and salaries suffer under Houthi maritime attacks. Zubaidi argues an independent south—with ports, refineries and banks—could stabilize Bab el-Mandeb, curb Iranian sway and counter al-Qaida.

articles.title: ‘Raring to go:’ the German remote-driving firm that hopes to make private car ownership redundant
articles.trailText: Europe has been slow to embrace robotaxis but Germany will allow remote-controlled rental cars from December
articles.summary: Vay, founded in Berlin in 2018, will roll out remote-driving rental EVs in December under new German legislation. Users hail a car via app; a qualified human controller operates steering, pedals and brakes remotely, then hands control to the passenger, who pays per minute at about half current car-share rates. CEO Thomas von der Ohe aims to reduce private ownership and boost urban sustainability. Vay recruited ex-Uber, taxi and truck drivers, trained with gaming skills and safety protocols. At a Berlin station drivers monitor feeds from rooftop cameras on three screens, use pedals and wheel and feel road bumps via sensors; an emergency red button halts the car instantly.

articles.title: Ukraine war briefing: Trump ‘growing incredibly impatient’ with Russia over war, warns Vance
articles.trailText: US vice-president says if Moscow doesn’t negotiate in good faith it will be ‘very, very bad for their country’ as Zelenskyy appeals to world leaders to stop Putin. What we know on day 1,310
articles.summary: US VP JD Vance warns President Trump is “incredibly impatient” with Russia’s stalled Ukraine war, threatening dire consequences if Moscow won’t negotiate. Sec State Rubio urges Russian FM Lavrov to end killings; Lavrov rejects Kyiv’s and EU plans. At the UN, Trump backs Zelenskyy’s vision to reclaim lost and even additional territory, prompting the Kremlin to dismiss Ukraine’s counteroffensive prospects. Zelenskyy appeals for global support against Putin’s drone and AI-driven escalation, warns of a catastrophic arms race, and cautions about NATO’s limits. Meanwhile Kyiv and Damascus restore diplomatic ties after Assad’s Syria recognized occupied Ukrainian regions.

articles.title: Wealthy investors from US, China and Hong Kong top applications for New Zealand’s ‘golden visa’ scheme
articles.trailText: Since new rules for the Active Investor Plus visa came into effect in April, applicant numbers have almost tripled
articles.summary: Since April New Zealand’s Active Investor Plus visa, now lowered thresholds, no English requirement and three-week residency, has attracted 308 applications (1,000 individuals) vs 116 in prior 2.5 years. US investors lead with 129 apps, followed by China 45, Hong Kong 38; Germany, Singapore, Taiwan, Japan, Vietnam, South Korea and Britain complete the top 10. 241 apps under $5m/3y ‘growth’, 67 under $10m/5y ‘balanced’; 39 approved, 197 in principle, representing NZ$248.8m. Reforms aim to revive the economy amid record emigration.

articles.title: Malawi’s 85-year-old ex-leader returns to power in presidential election
articles.trailText: Lazarus Chakwera, who presided over a multi-year economic crisis, concedes election after Peter Mutharika wins 56.8% of vote
articles.summary: Malawi’s 85-year-old ex-president Peter Mutharika captured 56.8% against incumbent Lazarus Chakwera’s 33% in the 16 September vote, with 76% turnout among two-thirds of nearly 11 million registered. His victory, marking the third straight power shift, follows Chakwera’s term beset by 20%+ inflation, chronic fuel, fertiliser and medicine shortages, climate shocks (Cyclone Freddy, drought) and steep aid cuts. Cleared of a 2018 kickback probe, Mutharika now inherits a sluggish economy, deep forex scarcity and strained IMF ties that analysts say could stall any swift recovery.

articles.title: Iran has hours to act or face UN nuclear sanctions snapback, says Macron
articles.trailText: France’s president says Islamic republic must reveal plan to allow inspectors back into country as he meets his Iranian counterpart, Masoud Pezeshkian
articles.summary: Emmanuel Macron warns that Iran has few hours to present a plan to let UN inspectors into its nuclear sites and disclose details of its 400kg highly enriched uranium stockpile or face automatic snapback of UN sanctions from the E3. After meeting President Masoud Pezeshkian at the UN, Macron said talks remain possible despite deadlock, a falling rial, and US envoy Steve Witkoff’s outreach. The E3 demand full IAEA access, resumed US-Iran nuclear talks, and oversight parity with Israel. Iran’s leadership insists its programme is peaceful and denounces Western bias.

articles.title: From al-Qaida to the Upper East Side: Syria’s new leader makes his debut on the world stage
articles.trailText: Ahmed al-Sharaa faces a tough task in reassuring the UN of his statesmanship while maintaining authority at home
articles.summary: Former al-Nusra Front leader Ahmed al-Sharaa (Abu Mohammed al-Jolani), who led last December’s lightning offensive to topple Bashar al-Assad, made his first appearance at the UN General Assembly since 1967. Feted by diplomats, he walked a tightrope: deflecting questions on his al-Qaida past, urging sanctions relief, and courting US support to prevent civil war, while preserving his hardline credentials. In New York he held a “fireside chat” at the Middle East Institute, met ex-CIA chief David Petraeus, and reiterated Syria’s unease with Israel amid Gaza and regional tensions.

articles.title: Israeli attempt to annex West Bank would be ‘red line’ for US, says Macron
articles.trailText: French president said Trump assured him that would also mean ‘end of Abraham accords’ on Arab-Israeli relations
articles.summary: French President Macron said any Israeli annexation of West Bank territory—including settlement expansions like the E1 corridor’s 3,400 new homes—would be a 'red line' for the US, threatening the Abraham Accords, per assurances from Donald Trump. He shared a three-page New York Declaration–based plan to exclude Hamas from Gaza and West Bank governance and called for a ceasefire and hostages’ release. Macron warned that US acquiescence in annexation would derail a two-state solution and undermine Israeli 'total war' strategy. He urged US pressure on Israel, threatened EU sanctions if fighting continues, and endorsed recognising Palestine to isolate Hamas and empower a reformed Palestinian Authority.

articles.title: WHO rejects Trump’s claims of link between Tylenol and autism
articles.trailText: Body says research has found ‘no consistent association’ and urges pregnant women to follow doctors’ advice
articles.summary: The WHO has rejected claims by the Trump administration and Robert F. Kennedy Jr. that acetaminophen use during pregnancy increases autism risk, citing large-scale studies over the past decade showing no consistent association. It urges pregnant women to follow medical advice on medication use and reiterates robust evidence that vaccines do not cause autism, highlighting 154 million lives saved by global immunization. The American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists called the acetaminophen warnings “irresponsible,” and the debate will be discussed at this week’s UN meeting on mental health.

articles.title: King Felipe pleads with Israel to ‘stop massacre and abhorrent acts’ in Gaza
articles.trailText: Spain’s monarch uses UN speech to attack Israel’s actions in Gaza saying ‘we can’t keep silent or look the other way’
articles.summary: At the UN General Assembly, Spain’s King Felipe delivered an unusually forceful appeal for Israel to “stop the massacre” and end “abhorrent acts” in Gaza, denouncing the bombing of hospitals, schools and shelters, famine and mass displacement. He avoided the term “genocide” but echoed PM Sánchez’s charge that Israel is “exterminating a defenseless people,” cited Spain’s Sephardic Jewish legacy and 2015 citizenship law, and noted Madrid’s arms embargo and deteriorating ties. Felipe called for a ceasefire, unfettered humanitarian aid, Hamas to free hostages, strict adherence to international humanitarian law and renewed pursuit of a two-state solution, affirming faith in the UN and the non-negotiable dignity of every human being.

articles.title: Irish presidential election candidates confirmed as three-way race begins
articles.trailText: Fine Gael’s Heather Humphreys, Fianna Fáil’s Jim Gavin and leftwing independent Catherine Connolly in running for job
articles.summary: On 24 September the nomination window closed, confirming a three-way 24 October presidential contest in Ireland: Heather Humphreys (Fine Gael ex-cabinet minister), Jim Gavin (Fianna Fáil ex-Dublin GAA manager) and left-wing independent Catherine Connolly (backed by Sinn Féin and small parties). Outsiders like Michael Flatley, Bob Geldof and Conor McGregor failed to secure the four councils or 20 legislators required. Polls put Humphreys at 22%, Gavin at 18% and Connolly at 17%. Controversies include Connolly’s 2018 Syria trip and pro-Hamas remarks, Gavin’s fight against online misinformation, and Humphreys’s lack of Irish language ability and Orange Order family ties.

articles.title: At least 20 people reported injured after drone strike on Israeli city of Eilat
articles.trailText: Two people seriously injured, says national ambulance service as military says drone was launched from Yemen
articles.summary: At least 20 people were injured, two seriously, when a drone launched from Yemen struck the center of Eilat on September 24, damaging hotel rooms and tourist areas. Israel’s military said interception attempts failed; no group claimed responsibility but the Houthi militia, backed by Iran, has repeatedly targeted Israel in solidarity with Palestinians. The attack on Rosh Hashanah prompted Eilat’s mayor to demand harsh retaliation against the Houthis. Previous Houthi strikes forced port disruptions and vessel attacks in the Red Sea, while Israel has bombed Houthi-held areas, including Hodeidah. The incident adds to regional tensions amid Israel’s ongoing Gaza offensive following Hamas’s October 2023 attacks.

articles.title: ‘Most destructive arms race in human history’: Zelenskyy appeals at UN for intervention to stop Russia
articles.trailText: Ukrainian president tells world leaders that combination of drone technology and AI would end in catastrophe
articles.summary: At the UN General Assembly, Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy warned that Russia’s integration of cheap drones and future AI marks “the most destructive arms race in human history.” He urged Western and non-Western powers—including China—to intervene now, arguing prevention is cheaper than building bunkers or rebuilding after wider conflict. Citing recent Russian drone incursions into Poland, he appealed for sustained support for Ukraine and neighboring Moldova against Kremlin influence. His dire warning stood in stark contrast to Donald Trump’s recent “paper tiger” assessment of Russia’s military, a shift Moscow dismissed as Zelenskyy’s influence following their UN meeting.

articles.title: Cry over spilt soy: Canada sushi shop refuses to dole out extra sauce for patrons
articles.trailText: Philip Kim of Sushi J is firm on his rule, saying on a Facebook post it would be the ‘last time we debate this’
articles.summary: At Sushi J in Kitimat, B.C., owner Philip Kim enforces a strict 'no extra soy sauce' policy—advertised on a sign forbidding requests even for $1,000 and banning rude or intoxicated patrons—arguing that over-saucing masks the delicate flavors of his sushi, honed over years of rice training. After posting on Facebook to settle the debate, he faced backlash labeling him arrogant, but says repeat diners never return after drowning bites in sauce. Satirists imagined underground 'soy sauce speakeasies', yet Kim alone defends his craft. He argues that patrons who request extra never become loyal, and says other chefs privately share his stance but avoid public backlash.

articles.title: A US fascism expert warns: Australia is not immune and undoing the damage is ‘very, very hard’
articles.trailText: The US’s slide towards authoritarianism is part of a global trend, says professor and fascism expert Jason Stanley
articles.summary: Yale professor and fascism expert Jason Stanley argues the US is sliding toward authoritarianism—evident in the weaponisation of Charlie Kirk’s campus killing, widespread doxxing and firings of dissenters, and federal speech policing under Trump. He draws parallels to Kristallnacht and ICE militarisation, warning this global trend threatens democracies everywhere. Australia, with its White Australia policy legacy, harsh asylum seeker treatment and anti-woke politics, is especially vulnerable. Stanley stresses fascism disguises itself in democratic processes, that undoing it is ‘very, very hard’, and a US descent normalises ultranationalism worldwide.

articles.title: Viktor Orbán faces toughest challenge in years – but can Hungary’s strongman be unseated?
articles.trailText: Orbánism offered Trump and the international populist right a blueprint, but its leader is under pressure at home from economic woes, falling support and Péter Magyar’s rise
articles.summary: Budapest’s long-dominant prime minister Viktor Orbán, architect of an “informational autocracy” and inspirer of global populists, faces an unprecedented threat from Péter Magyar’s pro-western Tisza movement ahead of April elections. Economic stagnation, high living costs and ‘Orbán fatigue’ have narrowed Fidesz’s previously unchallenged lead, while EU peers worry Hungary’s outcome will shape Brussels’ unity and democratic norms. Orbán’s arsenal—state-funded giveaways, media suppression, culture-war narratives and geopolitical contortions between Washington, Moscow and Beijing—will be deployed to reclaim support. Defeating him demands an opposition coalition capable of breaking Fidesz’s grip on the narrative.

articles.title: Renowned ‘sponge city’ architect Kongjian Yu dies in Brazil plane crash
articles.trailText: The 62-year-old Chinese landscape architect was killed with three others while filming in the Pantanal wetlands
articles.summary: Kongjian Yu, 62, the Chinese landscape architect renowned for pioneering the “sponge city” concept of urban flood resilience, died alongside two Brazilian filmmakers and their pilot when their Cessna crashed in Brazil’s Pantanal wetlands on 24 September. The group was en route to Fazenda Barra Mansa to film a documentary, Planeta Esponja, on Yu’s rainwater‐management designs that conserve and reuse runoff, slow flows and mitigate extreme weather. Founder of Turenscape, Yu led award‐winning projects from Beijing riverbanks to Jiangxi’s “floating forest.” His death prompted statements from Brazil’s president and global architecture bodies mourning the loss of a leading voice in sustainable urban water systems.

articles.title: Italy’s far-right government revives holiday for saint at ‘core of our nation’s identity’
articles.trailText: Millions of Italian workers expected to get day off every 4 October in honour of Saint Francis of Assisi
articles.summary: Italy’s far-right government under PM Giorgia Meloni has revived 4 October as a public holiday in honour of Saint Francis of Assisi, granting millions of workers a day off and stressing its link to national identity, Catholic tradition and values of peace, brotherhood and environmental stewardship. The lower house approved the bill overwhelmingly, sending it to the senate, despite cost concerns. The feast day was first granted in 1958, removed in 1977, and is backed by Meloni’s Brothers of Italy party as a tribute to civil and religious heritage ahead of the 800th anniversary of the saint’s death.

articles.title: Vanuatu working toward UN vote aimed at fighting fossil-fuel industry influence
articles.trailText: Ralph Regenvanu, minister of climate change for the Pacific island nation, says step taken on ‘behalf of everybody’
articles.summary: Vanuatu’s climate minister Ralph Regenvanu is spearheading a UN resolution to turn the ICJ’s unanimous July advisory opinion—declaring states legally bound to cut emissions, limit warming to 1.5°C, and curb fossil-fuel industry influence—into binding action. Bypassing stalled COP talks, the island nation aims for a majority vote in the UNGA after COP30 in Brazil, pressing states to comply under international law or face reparations claims. Vanuatu, on the frontline of climate threats, has long championed loss-and-damage funds, ecocide recognition and a fossil fuel non-proliferation treaty amid US climate denial and industry lobbying.

articles.title: Horror film digitally altered in China to make gay couple straight
articles.trailText: Viewers outraged after same-sex wedding scene changed in Together, starring Dave Franco and Alison Brie
articles.summary: Australian horror film Together, starring Dave Franco and Alison Brie, was altered for mainland China on 12 Sept, using AI face-swapping to transform a same-sex wedding into a heterosexual one. Cinema-goers spotted the change via side-by-side screenshots on social media, triggering outrage over covert censorship. Despite being legal, homosexuality remains stigmatized under China’s “neither support nor oppose” policy, though surveys show rising acceptance. China’s import approval often cuts “sensitive” content, but digital alteration is a new, stealthy tactic against LGBTQ representation. After online backlash, the film’s Chinese distributor halted its 19 Sept release. Past edits include Bohemian Rhapsody’s gay references and deleted Friends LGBT content.

articles.title: Super Typhoon Ragasa: 17 killed in Taiwan and Hong Kong battered as storm hits China
articles.trailText: Chinese businesses and schools shut and residents in high-rises ordered to evacuate as storm makes landfall on Guangdong coast
articles.summary: Super Typhoon Ragasa struck southern China after causing a barrier collapse in Taiwan that killed 14 and injured 18, with at least two more dead in the Philippines. Hong Kong endured hurricane-force winds, 3m storm surges that shattered hotel glass doors, flooded residential estates, downed trees, suspended MTR lines and flights, and sheltered over 760 evacuees. Guangdong’s coast between Zhuhai and Zhanjiang braces for landfall under the first red marine warning this year, closing schools and businesses in 10 cities and ordering high-rise evacuations for tens of millions.

articles.title: Trudeau made headlines with free birth control. Why didn’t Canada follow through?
articles.trailText: Nearly a year after a historic law promised free contraception, most provinces still haven’t signed on
articles.summary: Nearly a year after Canada’s Pharmacare Act made contraception free under Justin Trudeau’s 2024 historic law, only four jurisdictions—British Columbia, Manitoba, Prince Edward Island and the Yukon—have signed deals with Ottawa. Provinces control healthcare delivery and many, led by fiscally wary or Conservative premiers, fear runaway costs. Under Mark Carney’s new Liberal leadership, federal-provincial negotiations have stalled, leaving most Canadians paying up to $300 annually for oral contraceptives. Advocates warn cost barriers spur unplanned pregnancies (about $320 million/yr) and health inequities, undermining the promise of universal prescription coverage.

articles.title: Wednesday briefing: What Russia wants with Nato airspace – and what options it leaves the west
articles.trailText: In today’s newsletter: Intentional or not, recent incursions by drones and fighters jets are testament to Moscow’s increasingly cavalier attitude, and pose difficult questions of the alliance
articles.summary: Over two weeks, Russian drones and MiG-31 fighters have repeatedly penetrated NATO airspace—Poland, Romania, Estonia and the Baltic Sea—testing allies’ resolve. While Moscow denies intent, experts like Dr David Jordan see deliberate “accidental-on-purpose” incursions aimed at exposing divisions over defending Ukraine. In response, NATO launched Operation Eastern Sentry, deployed extra jets from France, Germany, Denmark and the UK, and vowed to shoot down any further violations. Allies also plan a multi-national “drone wall” to shore up counter-drone defenses. Though shooting down jets risks escalation, NATO signals unity: it will defend every inch of allied territory, keeping Article 5 protections intact.

articles.title: ‘Children thrive down here’: the secret play centre hidden under Ukraine’s most dangerous city
articles.trailText: Kherson’s children have missed nearly four years of school, living in isolation or underground to hide from drones
articles.summary: In Kherson, one of Ukraine’s most besieged cities, children have lost nearly four years of education, forced into online classes or hiding underground amid Russia’s “human safari” drone campaign. A clandestine basement play centre—set up by resident leader Oleh Turchynskyi—provides art, games and psychological support, countering trauma-driven lags in literacy, speech, and social skills. With thousands of child casualties and frequent blackouts, families ration errands to dodge strikes. Teachers drown out blasts with claps and music; some kids haven’t learned to read, and one boy regained speech after months of therapy. Save the Children warns many pupils are 1–2 years behind academically.

articles.title: ‘It goes beyond getting a cash refund for slavery’: Lenny Henry and Marcus Ryder on the case for reparations
articles.trailText: With their new book, Henry and Ryder are determined to start a discussion about compensation for the descendants of slaves. But how would any scheme work? And why is it yet to happen?
articles.summary: Entertainer Lenny Henry and diversity campaigner Marcus Ryder, in their new book The Big Payback, contend that reparations for slavery should extend beyond cash to social, psychological and institutional reforms. They highlight Britain’s 2015 payoff to slave owners, draw on Caricom’s ten-point plan and precedents like Holocaust and Mau Mau compensation, argue financial feasibility via long-term borrowing, and frame reparations as moral redress and societal healing to combat structural racism and foster equitable global relations, urging to start the dialogue despite political resistance.

articles.title: ‘A gift from heaven’: the TikTok traders of Mauritania’s meteorites
articles.trailText: Growing desertification is putting traditional livelihoods at risk in western Africa and encouraging the search for rare stones
articles.summary: In Bir Moghrein, hospital guard Lamine Hanoun scavenges Saharan desert by day, selling meteorites via TikTok and Facebook. Desertification has displaced goatherds into informal meteorite hunting—using animals as scouts or camping dunes for days—to meet global collector demand. Since the Tissint discovery in 2011, Mauritania’s 300+ classified falls rank it among Africa’s top finds. Low-value chondrites fetch around €50 locally but can command $1,000 per gram in the US. Unregulated and hampered by patchy connectivity and no national framework, the trade—prone to deceitful tactics like wetting stones and filters—enriches brokers while prompting calls for legal oversight. As locals say, ‘you don’t find the meteorite; it finds you.’

articles.title: ‘We are at our limit’: Gaza’s last hospitals overwhelmed as thousands flee south
articles.trailText: ‘Not enough of anything’, says surgeon, as Israel’s assault forces injured, sick and hungry people to leave Gaza City
articles.summary: Remaining hospitals and field clinics in central and southern Gaza—especially Nasser complex in Khan Younis and the al-Muwasi field hospital—are overwhelmed by patients fleeing Israel’s northern offensive. Medics report a “tsunami” of blast and bullet injuries, infected wounds and severe malnutrition, with 160 arrivals overnight and 600 clinic visits at one 90-bed facility. Some 320,000 people have been displaced southwards after northern hospitals closed or were ordered evacuated. Staff face critical shortages of beds, antibiotics, fuel and oxygen. Limited aid has trickled in via ICRC and Unicef, but medics warn the crisis is spiraling out of control.

articles.title: Trump’s UN speech makes it clear: the world can no longer look to the US for strong leadership
articles.trailText: US president’s speech made a mockery of UN values and highlights the need for strong anti-Trumpian alliances
articles.summary: Trump’s 58-minute UN address assailed open borders, sharia law, UN failings and the ‘climate hoax,’ signaling a retreat from multilateral values. Indonesian President Prabowo Subianto and Turkish President Erdoğan condemned bullying and injustice, while Brazil’s Lula warned of rising authoritarianism, veto tyranny and democracy’s decline. UN Secretary-General Guterres cautioned that multipolarity without effective institutions courts chaos. Europe’s double standards over Ukraine and Gaza have hampered a cohesive response, but Spanish PM Sánchez, Lula and Chile’s Boric are crafting an “In Defence of Democracy” alliance to reinforce multilateralism, the rule of law and counter extremism. Coalitions remain nascent amid concerns nations may still yield to Trump’s shakedown diplomacy.

articles.title: ‘A symbol of liberation’: how the One Piece manga flag became the symbol of Asia’s gen Z protest movement
articles.trailText: Carried by a band of pirates that stand up to corrupt and repressive rulers, the meaning of the One Piece flag has resonated across borders
articles.summary: Gen Z protesters across Asia have adopted the Straw Hat pirates’ Jolly Roger from Eiichiro Oda’s One Piece as a unifying emblem of defiance. Hung on homes and vehicles in Indonesia, draped over Nepal’s palace gates and flown at Manila’s Luneta Park, the flag signals anger at corruption—ranging from lavish political perks to siphoned flood-relief funds. Authorities have threatened treason charges and targeted flag-bearers, prompting Amnesty International to warn of free-speech violations. Its viral spread on social media underscores the potency of familiar pop-culture symbols in political activism.

articles.title: Italian prime minister condemns drone attacks on Gaza aid flotilla boats
articles.trailText: Despite condemnation Giorgia Meloni also criticised The Global Sumud Flotilla mission as ‘dangerous and irresponsible’
articles.summary: Italian PM Giorgia Meloni condemned overnight drone attacks on the Global Sumud Flotilla’s 50-vessel humanitarian convoy, which includes Greta Thunberg, off Greece but also labeled the mission “dangerous and irresponsible” and aimed at destabilizing her government. Italy dispatched the multipurpose frigate Fasan—without orders to use force—to assist and proposed diverting aid to Cyprus and the Latin Patriarchate of Jerusalem. Activists reported multiple drones dropping devices, jamming radios, and causing boat damage but no injuries. This marks the third assault this month, as Israel continues to bar the flotilla from reaching Gaza, accusing it of colluding with Hamas.

articles.title: Ukraine war briefing: Zelenskyy says Trump can change Xi Jinping’s stance on Russia’s war
articles.trailText: Ukraine’s president lauds ‘big shift’ after Trump says Ukraine can regain all land lost in war. What we know on day 1,309
articles.summary: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy praised Donald Trump’s pledge that Ukraine could reclaim all territory lost to Russia and suggested Trump might persuade Xi Jinping to pressure Moscow to end its invasion. On Fox News after their UNGA meeting, he said China’s energy purchases fuel the war and, if compelled, could halt it. Zelenskyy also cited Trump’s claim on Truth Social that Russia faces severe economic trouble. He warned Russia is probing NATO defences with long-range drones, while a UN report details widespread torture of Ukrainian civilian detainees. Kyiv urged decisive action to restore power at the occupied Zaporizhzhia nuclear plant.

articles.title: Is Copenhagen drone incursion further evidence of Russian interest in allied airspace?
articles.trailText: Sudden boldness of Kremlin is new territory for Nato, which is enhancing air policing over Eastern Europe with extra fighter jets
articles.summary: Three large drones forced Copenhagen airport to close for four hours after approaching runways in a coordinated incursion, highlighting the vulnerability of NATO airspace to ‘capable actors’. Danish police and experts note the craft’s green lights and multi-directional approach resemble Russian Gerbera or Shahed drones, which can reach Copenhagen from Kaliningrad or be launched at sea. The incident follows decoy-drone overflights in Poland and Estonia, prompting NATO’s Operation Eastern Sentry and extra fighter jets in Eastern Europe. With parallel ransomware attacks on European hubs, the pattern suggests Kremlin attempts to test and raise the cost of alliance air defenses.

articles.title: My Christian duty to Palestinians | Letter
articles.trailText: Letters: Rev Canon Lesley McCormack on wrestling with her conscience about whether join a protest against the ban on Palestine Action
articles.summary: Rev Canon Lesley McCormack, a Church of England priest, debates joining a silent protest in Parliament Square against the ban on Palestine Action, citing Gaza’s UN-declared genocide and West Bank suffering. After writing to her MP, donating, and preaching on God’s compassion, she feels powerless. Facing potential arrest and loss of her licence, she fears becoming like Simon the Pharisee by following rules over radical love. She urges Christians to boldly uphold Christ’s call to serve the oppressed.

articles.title: Brazil’s president says in UN speech that democracy can prevail over ‘would-be autocrats’
articles.trailText: South American leftist Lula takes indirect swipes at Trump in speech and warns that global threat of ‘anti-democratic forces’ persists
articles.summary: At the UN general assembly, Brazil’s President Lula (79) defended his democracy, citing ex-president Bolsonaro’s 27-year sentence for plotting a coup as proof that ‘would-be autocrats’ can be held accountable. He warned of global anti-democratic forces, condemned US 50% tariffs and Magnitsky sanctions on Brazilian judges over Bolsonaro’s trial, and criticized US strikes on Venezuelan boats. Trump accused Brazil of ‘censorship’ but signaled possible reconciliation after a brief meeting. Lula’s defiance has spurred pro-democracy protests, boosted his approval, and strengthened his bid for a fourth term.

articles.title: Quebec’s police watchdog to investigate killing of 15-year-old boy by officers
articles.trailText: Police responded to a report of a group of masked teens before shooting within seconds, according to a resident
articles.summary: Quebec's Office of Independent Investigations will probe the fatal shooting of 15-year-old Nooran Rezayi by police in Longueuil after officers responded to a 911 call reporting masked, allegedly armed teens. Watchdog chief Brigitte Bishop said the only gun recovered at the scene belonged to police; a baseball bat and ski masks were also seized. Eyewitnesses claim police fired seconds after warning youths to stop. Rezayi’s Afghan immigrant family demands answers, criticizing delayed communication. Bishop urges public to share evidence and refrain from private inquiries.

articles.title: Danish PM: airport drone incursion a ‘serious attack’ on critical infrastructure
articles.trailText: Russia denies involvement after Copenhagen and Oslo airports forced to close after drone sightings
articles.summary: Denmark and Norway closed their main airports after large drones, flown by a “capable operator,” appeared near Copenhagen and Oslo, grounding flights for hours and stranding tens of thousands. Danish PM Mette Frederiksen labeled the incursion the “most serious attack on Danish critical infrastructure to date,” hinting at Russian involvement, which Moscow denies. Authorities suspect hybrid tactics—fixed-wing drones, possibly launched from “shadow fleet” ships—and are investigating with security services, military and international partners. Norwegian PM Jonas Gahr Støre cites recent Russian airspace violations. EU and NATO officials are monitoring the unfolding probe.

articles.title: ‘Guess what?’ Macron phones Trump after US president’s motorcade blocks his car
articles.trailText: Bemused French president forced to take unscheduled 30-minute trek through the streets of New York
articles.summary: After urging the UN to recognise Palestine and proposing a UN-mandated stabilisation force for Gaza, President Emmanuel Macron found his car halted in New York as police cleared the street for Donald Trump’s motorcade. Footage by Brut captures Macron apologising to officers, then calling Trump—“Guess what? I’m waiting in the street because everything is frozen for you”—before striding 30 minutes on foot to the French consulate. Along the way he paused for selfies and even posed with a man who kissed him on the forehead.

articles.title: David Hirst obituary
articles.trailText: The Guardian’s Middle East correspondent for four decades whose articles were key to understanding the region’s turmoil
articles.summary: David Hirst, who died aged 89 of cancer, was The Guardian’s authoritative Middle East correspondent from 1964 to 2001. His seminal 1977 book The Gun and the Olive Branch and fearless dispatches—from the 1967 Six-Day War to Gaza 1994 and Hama’s 1982 gas massacre—shaped Western understanding of regional turmoil. Periodically barred by Arab regimes, he produced piercing profiles of Arafat and Saddam. Known for meticulous research, he escaped kidnappings in 1980s Beirut. Fluent in Arabic, educated at Oxford and AUB, he married Egyptian anthropologist Amina, spent his final years in France, continued contributing until 2013 and regretted not completing an updated edition of his landmark study before his death.

articles.title: Allan ‘Skill’ Cole obituary
articles.trailText: Jamaican footballer, close friend of Bob Marley and manager of the Wailers
articles.summary: Allan ‘Skill’ Cole (1950–2025), Jamaican football prodigy turned music manager, died aged 74. Spotted at 15 for Jamaica’s national side, he starred for NASL’s Atlanta Chiefs and Brazil’s Náutico (leaving rather than trim his dreadlocks). A Trenchtown friend of Bob Marley, he co-founded Tuff Gong, managed the Wailers, co-wrote “War,” and ran Marley’s tours until his 1980 death. Cole survived a 1976 assassination attempt tied to an abortive race-fixing plot, fled to coach Ethiopia’s national team, later returned to Jamaican football, faced a 2002 cannabis conviction and was developing a Marley biopic.
