articles.title: West Africans deported by the US were denied their rights, says lawyer
articles.trailText: Men were sent on from Ghana despite ‘risk of torture, persecution or inhumane treatment’
articles.summary: Under Trump’s expansion of expulsions, the US deported 14 West African migrants to Ghana, then on to home countries despite fears of torture or persecution. Eleven were held in dire conditions at a Ghanaian military camp and sued for release, but most—six to Togo, one freed in Ghana—were deported before their case could proceed. Lawyers report shacklings, straitjacketing on flights and a bisexual man forced back to the Gambia into hiding. Separately, Jamaica repatriated a deportee from Eswatini with UN’s help; other detainees remain.

articles.title: Rodrigo Duterte, former Philippines president, charged with crimes against humanity at ICC
articles.trailText: Three charges against Duterte stem from his years-long campaign against drug users and dealers that rights groups say killed thousands
articles.summary: ICC prosecutors have formally charged former Philippine president Rodrigo Duterte with three counts of crimes against humanity over his "war on drugs", accusing him of orchestrating death squads under his mayorship in Davao City (2011–2016) and extending the policy nationwide as president (2016–2019). The indictment cites 76 specific murders but alleges thousands more killings of alleged drug users and dealers, facilitated through weapons supply, incentives, immunity and public vows to "neutralise" suspects. Duterte has been detained in The Hague since March; his trial is pending a fitness assessment after lawyers cited cognitive impairment.

articles.title: Footloose moose moved to reserve after chaotic summer in Austria went viral
articles.trailText: The public took a shine to 800kg Emil, despite his escapades halting traffic and almost endangering motorists
articles.summary: Three-year-old Emil, an 800 kg moose likely from Poland or Czechia, was tranquillised and relocated by Austrian authorities to the Šumava national park after a viral summer of road and rail disruptions. His fence-jumping near the A1 autobahn and four-hour standstill on a busy railway prompted a Soko Elch taskforce using drones and thermal cameras. Transported in a straw-lined trailer and fitted with a GPS ear tag, Emil—dubbed ‘Problem-Elch’—amassed 26,000 Facebook fans through images of him grazing, swimming in the Danube and halting traffic. Experts say his trek was heat-driven; now he can roam among 30 moose in his new reserve.

articles.title: British officials fear Trump could recognise Israeli West Bank settlements
articles.trailText: Government insiders say move would be a serious blow to prospect of a two-state solution
articles.summary: UK officials fear Trump may recognise Israeli West Bank settlements in retaliation for UK, France and others recognising Palestine, undermining the two-state solution. Arab and European leaders lobby to block recognition as some US allies (eg Huckabee) pressure Trump to endorse settlement sovereignty. Starmer and Macron praised recent Palestinian recognition at the UN. Israel plans E1 settlement; far-right minister Smotrich seeks to bury any Palestinian state. Netanyahu, under cabinet annexation pressure, awaits his White House meeting with Trump. Kushner advocates preserving two-state prospects. UAE’s Gargash warns annexation would breach a red line and jeopardise the Abraham accords.

articles.title: Trinidadian fishers fear getting caught in the crossfire amid Trump’s Caribbean ‘war on drugs’
articles.trailText: Caribbean governments divided on US warship diplomacy as local fishers worry they could become collateral damage
articles.summary: Fishers in Trinidad’s Gulf of Paria fear being caught in the US “war on drugs” after Trump dispatched eight warships and a submarine, destroying three speedboats and killing 17 alleged traffickers. Venezuela-aligned ALBA governments denounce the strikes as extrajudicial, while allies like the Dominican Republic, Guyana and Trinidad’s prime minister back the mission. Fishermen are rerouting boats closer to shore, driving fish prices up 9.5%, threatening rural livelihoods (TT$83.6m in exports) and raising alarms over broader economic and social fallout if fishing slows.

articles.title: Letters found on eBay cast light on UK families who benefited from slavery
articles.trailText: Researcher Malik Al Nasir bought historical documents while investigating his family history – and began building an archive
articles.summary: Cambridge PhD researcher Malik Al Nasir bought a cache of 19th-century Sandbach, Tinne & Co letters on eBay, uncovering how Lancashire dynasties—Sandbach, Tinne and the Gladstones (relations of PM William Gladstone)—amassed fortunes from enslaved labour and sugar, cotton trade, receiving vast 1833 post-abolition compensation. Now digitised in Cambridge Digital Library alongside Newton and Darwin, the archive details plantation finance, Industrial Revolution ties, Jack Gladstone’s 1823 Demerara rebellion strategy and Rev. John Smith’s brutal testimonies that galvanized British abolition. Al Nasir’s work traces his own Guyanese-Lancashire ancestry.

articles.title: Tuesday briefing: The online origins of ‘Boriswave’, the right’s favourite new phrase
articles.trailText: In today’s newsletter: How a term created by the extremely online right made it into the mainstream press – and a major speech by Nigel Farage
articles.summary: In a Reform Party speech, Nigel Farage invoked “Boriswave”—a term originally coined among the “extremely online right” to demonize post-Brexit non-EU migrants—as justification to revoke existing indefinite leave to remain. Dr Robert Topinka charts its evolution: born in far-right memes on X and 4chan, laundered via Wikipedia, right-wing outlets and Twitter, then adopted uncritically by mainstream newspapers. This case exemplifies how digital extremist jargon (“posting to policy”) seeps into parliamentary debate, reshaping discourse on UK immigration policy.

articles.title: British-Egyptian activist Alaa Abd el-Fattah freed from prison
articles.trailText: Writer, who has served six years for sharing a Facebook post, was given a presidential pardon
articles.summary: British-Egyptian writer and pro-Arab Spring activist Alaa Abd el-Fattah, jailed in 2019 at Wadi Natron prison for sharing a Facebook post, was released under a presidential pardon by Abdel Fattah al-Sisi. His six-year sentence, including pretrial detention, ended after intense lobbying by UK PM Keir Starmer, Foreign Secretary Yvette Cooper and Egypt’s state-funded National Council for Human Rights. His mother Laila Soueif and sister Mona led international hunger strikes and vigils in London, while Amnesty and fellow ex-prisoner Peter Greste welcomed the overdue justice milestone. He’s now home in Cairo and will return to the UK.

articles.title: Hungary refuses to stop buying Russian oil despite Trump’s Nato demand
articles.trailText: Foreign minister says getting energy supplies elsewhere is a ‘nice dream’ while describing western European officials as ‘fanatics’
articles.summary: Hungary’s foreign minister Péter Szijjártó said at the UN that Hungary cannot secure its energy needs without Russian oil and gas, dismissing calls including from ex-president Donald Trump for NATO allies to halt imports. Hungary’s MOL Group imports 5m tonnes via the Druzhba pipeline, also supplying Slovakia. Prime Minister Orbán, a Trump ally who criticizes Ukraine, supports continued buying; Brussels pressure has failed. The EU may impose trade restrictions without unanimity. US Republicans like Lindsey Graham and Polish FM Sikorski urge Hungary to diversify. Szijjártó termed western Europeans ‘fanatics’ but praised US ties under Trump.

articles.title: Trump is waging culture war on Europe by promoting rightwing allies, report finds
articles.trailText: Study finds US president seeks to interfere in elections and ‘move the ideological centre of gravity’ in European politics
articles.summary: A joint ECFR/European Cultural Foundation report finds Trump’s administration is waging a culture war on Europe—promoting MAGA-aligned allies, interfering in EU elections, humiliating Brussels via tariff threats, Ukraine exclusion and free-speech clashes, and boosting figures like Orbán, Meloni and Fico. Eurobarometer polls show record trust (highest since 2007) and majority support for defence autonomy. The study urges EU leaders to recognize this assault on Europe’s dignity, abandon appeasement, deploy the Digital Services Act and trade instruments, and fortify a shared European narrative against scripted crises.

articles.title: Unification Church leader arrested in South Korea over bribery allegations linked to former first lady
articles.trailText: Han Hak-ja, aged 82, is detained after Seoul court hearing over claims she told church officials to bribe wife of then president Yoon Suk Yeol
articles.summary: Unification Church leader Han Hak-ja, 82, was arrested after a Seoul court granted investigators’ request for a warrant amid allegations she ordered bribes to former first lady Kim Keon-Hee and conservative lawmaker Kweon Seong-dong. Han denies directing payments; prosecutors cited risk of evidence tampering. The detention follows probes into President Yoon Suk Yeol’s tenure, including his wife’s alleged misconduct, and mirrors Japan’s recent dissolution order of the church after the Abe assassination. Opposition lawmakers demand dissolving the People Power Party over alleged mass recruitment by church members to influence its 2023 leadership race.

articles.title: Mother in New Zealand’s ‘suitcase murders’ found guilty of killing her two children
articles.trailText: The bodies of Hakyung Lee��s children were discovered inside suitcases bought at a storage unit auction in Auckland in August 2022
articles.summary: Hakyung Lee, 45, was found guilty in Auckland of murdering her children, Yuna (8) and Minu (6), whose bodies were discovered in suitcases bought at a storage unit auction in August 2022. Believed dead for three to four years, the siblings had been given the antidepressant nortriptyline by Lee, who admitted concealing their remains but pleaded insanity after her husband died of cancer in 2017. After a three-week trial where Lee remained silent, a jury convicted her in two hours. She now faces life imprisonment with a minimum decade-long non-parole term.

articles.title: Ukraine war briefing: Zelenskyy heads to the UN as US envoy vows to defend Nato territory
articles.trailText: Ukrainian president is expected to meet Trump on the sidelines of the UN general assembly in New York; Washington’s new UN envoy convenes emergency meeting. What we know on day 1,308
articles.summary: President Volodymyr Zelenskyy arrived in New York for UNGA with two dozen meetings scheduled—including with Donald Trump—aiming to rally support for a US-led peace plan and spotlight the Coalition for the Return of Ukrainian Children amid 35,000 minors missing in Russian-held areas. US UN ambassador Michael Waltz convened an emergency session after three Russian MiG-31 jets breached Estonian airspace and pledged to defend every inch of NATO. Allies discuss an EU-Ukraine “drone wall” to seal eastern borders. Moscow’s claimed seizure of Kalynivske is denied by Kyiv, which reports counterattacks in Donetsk. Putin offers one-year New START extension, while IMF secures a $65bn Ukraine funding forecast.

articles.title: New Zealand loosens residency restrictions as record number of citizens leave
articles.trailText: Minister for economic growth says visas for skilled and experienced migrants could help plug gaps in the workforce
articles.summary: New Zealand will introduce two new mid-2026 residency pathways to attract skilled and trades migrants, amid record emigration and shrinking GDP. Economic Growth Minister Nicola Willis and Immigration Minister Erica Stanford said the schemes will fill workforce gaps, retaining foreign talent already contributing to the economy. The first targets roles meeting experience and salary thresholds; the second covers trades and technical workers with qualification, work experience and wage criteria. Between July 2024–25, 73,400 citizens left vs 25,800 returning. Earlier this year visitor visas for digital nomads and relaxed investor visas were also eased. While Business NZ lauds the move, coalition partner NZ First opposed it, warning of brain drain to Australia.

articles.title: France recognises Palestine and calls for UN force in Gaza
articles.trailText: Macron sets out plan for international stabilisation mission as Arab and Muslim leaders prepare to meet Trump in New York
articles.summary: France formally recognised Palestine covering Gaza, West Bank and East Jerusalem and proposed a UN‐mandated stabilisation force to disarm Hamas and support a PA police, winning backing from Spain, UK, Canada and Australia but facing US and Israeli rejection. Monaco, Belgium, Malta and Luxembourg also recognised Palestine, bringing three‐quarters of UN membership. Arab and Muslim leaders will meet Trump in New York to discuss their Gaza plan and two‐state roadmap amid Israel’s intensified Gaza assault. PA Abbas addressed virtually, urging Hamas disarmament.

articles.title: Iran’s foreign minister meets with UN nuclear watchdog in bid to avert sanctions
articles.trailText: Abbas Araghchi will likely also meet with European officials, as window for reaching an agreement narrows
articles.summary: In New York, Iran’s foreign minister Abbas Araghchi met IAEA chief Rafael Grossi to avert the snapback of six UN nuclear sanctions due Saturday night—when the UK, France and Germany could still delay them. With EU’s Kaja Kallas warning time is short and Israel’s PM Netanyahu vowing to “destroy” Iran’s nuclear axis, the Europeans insist on full IAEA access to bombed sites, a full accounting of 400kg of enriched uranium and renewed US talks. Iran warns it will cease cooperation if sanctions return. Domestically, hardliners demand nuclear armament, eye a rare Trump meeting, as the rial plunges.

articles.title: Netanyahu may struggle to find response that matches rhetoric on Palestine recognition
articles.trailText: Israeli PM has threatened bilateral action and annexation of occupied Palestinian land but there are risks in either
articles.summary: After Britain, France and other historic allies recognised a Palestinian state, Netanyahu angrily vowed bilateral retaliation and West Bank annexation but finds his options constrained. Annexing territory would fracture the Abraham Accords with the UAE—his key backer—and risk isolating Israel. Past ambassadorship withdrawals against Ireland, Norway and Spain show limits of tit-for-tat diplomacy when recognition is widespread. Excluding far-right hardliners from security discussions, Netanyahu has delayed a concrete response while balancing US ties, economic fallout and his election and corruption-trial pressures.

articles.title: Denmark plans payout for Greenlandic women affected by forced IUD scandal
articles.trailText: Mette Frederiksen announces ‘reconciliation fund’ plan on same day decision to remove Greenlandic woman’s baby is reversed
articles.summary: Denmark plans a reconciliation fund to compensate up to 4,500 Greenlandic women coerced into anonymous IUD insertions between 1966–70 and others discriminated against for being Greenlanders, announced PM Mette Frederiksen ahead of an apology ceremony in Nuuk. The initiative follows Copenhagen’s formal apology in August and U.S. Arctic pressure. On the same day, Denmark’s social appeals board overturned the removal of Ivana Nikoline Brønlund’s newborn after racially biased “parenting competence” tests. Campaigners and victims, including those suing for 45m DKK, call it a step toward responsibility, though some question the timing and sincerity.

articles.title: UK and Poland vow to confront Russian aircraft violating Nato airspace
articles.trailText: Russia shrugs off criticism as Poland and Estonia speak about incursions at emergency meeting of UN security council
articles.summary: At a UN security council emergency session called by Estonia, Poland and the UK vowed to shoot down any Russian aircraft or drones violating Nato airspace unilaterally, warning Moscow against protests over wreckage. Poland’s FM Radosław Sikorski and PM Donald Tusk issued stark threats after recent breaches by MiG-31 jets over Estonia and drone swarms over Poland and Romania. European ministers, including Denmark’s Lars Løkke Rasmussen and UK’s Yvette Cooper, condemned Russia’s reckless incursions. US envoy Mike Waltz pledged full US defence commitments. Moscow denied Estonia’s radar evidence; Putin accused West of escalation while claiming Russia’s right to counter threats.

articles.title: IDF may launch new offensives after Gaza City, says ex-general
articles.trailText: Yaakov Amidror says ‘central camps’ could be next target, as aid workers there say they have been warned of attacks
articles.summary: Former national security adviser Yaakov Amidror warns the IDF will focus on Gaza City’s “hardcore” Hamas before targeting central camps (Nuseirat, Bureij), densely packed with hundreds of thousands of displaced Palestinians. Aid agencies report Israeli officials have cautioned against new infrastructure there. Amidror forecasts three months of intensive fighting plus six months clearing Gaza City, then a southward offensive into central camps, risking a deeper humanitarian catastrophe amid famine, mass displacement and soaring civilian casualties in Israel’s retaliation to Hamas’s October 2023 attack.

articles.title: Disruption across Italy as tens of thousands protest against Gaza war
articles.trailText: Schools and stations closed and ports blocked in one of Europe’s biggest demonstrations opposing Israel’s offensive
articles.summary: Tens of thousands across 75 Italian cities shut schools, block ports and rail lines in a 24-hour general strike called by grassroots unions to protest Israel’s Gaza offensive and urge suspension of military and commercial ties. Around 50,000 demonstrated in Milan and over 10,000 in Bologna, where clashes with police drew water cannon and pepper spray; dozens arrested and officers injured. Protesters demand recognition of Palestinian statehood, back an international aid flotilla and criticize PM Meloni’s cautious stance.

articles.title: Israeli politicians react bitterly to international recognitions of Palestinian state
articles.trailText: Experts say move by nations including UK and Australia won’t change government policy and could strengthen its grip on power
articles.summary: Following formal recognitions of a Palestinian state by the UK, Portugal, Australia and Canada (with France expected to follow), Israeli leaders from Netanyahu to centrist opposition condemned the moves as a “reward for terror” and diplomatic absurdity. Analysts warn this united front may bolster Netanyahu’s far-right coalition despite having little impact on policy. Many Israelis view recognition as zero-sum, fearing further isolation. Polls show latent support for partition, yet a two-state label is toxic. Israel plans diplomatic retaliation, including expulsions, and signals accelerated West Bank settlement growth pending US consultations.

articles.title: UN and rights groups condemn reported jailing of Wuhan Covid citizen journalist
articles.trailText: Zhang Zhan sentenced to four years for second time on charge often used by China to target government critics
articles.summary: UN human rights office, RSF and HRW have condemned the four-year sentence imposed on citizen journalist Zhang Zhan by a Shanghai court on charges of “picking quarrels and provoking trouble,” often used to silence government critics. Zhang, 42, who reported independently from Wuhan during the Covid-19 outbreak, had already served four years for the same charge before her release in 2023. Denounced by the UN as “deeply disturbing” and hailed by RSF as an “information hero,” Zhang’s jailing underscores China’s media crackdown—China ranks 178th of 180 in the 2025 RSF index with at least 124 journalists imprisoned.

articles.title: Flight delays continue across Europe after weekend cyber-attack
articles.trailText: Software provider Collins Aerospace completing updates after Heathrow, Brussels and Berlin hit by problems
articles.summary: A ransomware attack on Collins Aerospace’s Muse software on Friday has left Heathrow, Brussels, Dublin and Berlin airports struggling with disrupted check-in and boarding systems. With kiosks and bag-drops offline, staff have processed passengers manually, leading to cancellations (40 of 277 departures and 23 arrivals at Brussels) and slightly longer queues at Heathrow. Collins, a subsidiary of RTX, says software updates are in final stages; the EU cybersecurity agency confirms a ransomware breach. Experts warn state-sponsored or sophisticated private hackers could be behind the incident. Airline stocks (IAG –1.2%, easyJet –1.4%, Wizz Air –1.1%) dipped as the EU Commission monitors for broader impact.

articles.title: Arc’teryx fireworks display in Tibet prompts environmental outcry
articles.trailText: Outdoor brand says the Rising Dragon promotional event was out of line with its values after public criticism
articles.summary: Arc’teryx apologised after its Rising Dragon fireworks and coloured smoke show over Himalayan ridges in Tibet’s Shigatse region triggered an online environmental backlash. Partnering with artist Cai Guo-Qiang and partly owned by Anta Group, the brand claimed use of biodegradable pyrotechnics, wildlife relocation measures and compliance with Olympic-level pollution standards. Critics accused the $800-jacket retailer of betraying its eco-ethos, urging boycotts. Arc’teryx and Cai issued apologies, pledging humility and cleanup; local officials noted prior approvals and no visible damage, though Shigatse authorities and the China Advertising Association have launched investigations into the marketing’s environmental and ethical impact.

articles.title: Mass grave reveals scale of unlawful killings by Egyptian army in Sinai, say campaigners
articles.trailText: Human rights group says hundreds of skeletons found exposed or buried just below ground during research into killings of civilians
articles.summary: The Sinai Foundation for Human Rights uncovered a concealed grave south of al-Arish near heavy military fortifications, exposing hundreds of civilian skeletons—some on the surface, others buried just 30 cm deep. SFHR’s on-site survey and satellite analysis by Forensic Architecture confirmed at least 36 skulls; researchers estimate over 300 bodies. The victims—ranging from newly detained suspects to long-held prisoners—were executed without due process during the 2013-22 Sinai conflict. Egypt denies civilian casualties or forced displacement, though over 150,000 residents were uprooted. Families remain trapped in fear with no official acknowledgment.

articles.title: Why are more countries recognising Palestinian statehood and what does it mean practically?
articles.trailText: Coordinated action is largely symbolic and aimed at preserving and nurturing the vision of a two-state solution
articles.summary: After Australia, Canada, Portugal and the UK formally recognised Palestinian statehood, France and Saudi Arabia summoned global leaders in New York to shore up the two-state solution. With 151 of 193 UN members now recognising Palestine per Montevideo criteria—population, territory, government, diplomatic capacity—this largely symbolic move enables treaties and full ambassadorial exchanges but won’t change Gaza’s status. Proponents see it as a rebuke to Israeli annexation plans; critics dismiss it as rewarding Hamas, highlighting PA’s flaws and treating the two-state framework as empty rhetoric absent tangible enforcement or negotiations.

articles.title: ‘Afraid of our talent’: India hits back against Trump’s H-1B visa fee hike
articles.trailText: India has been one of the largest beneficiaries of H-1B visas, accounting for 71% of approved visas in 2024
articles.summary: US president Donald Trump imposed a $100,000 surcharge on new H-1B visas—a 60-fold increase—drawing an Indian government rebuke of “humanitarian consequences” and a minister’s jab that the US is “afraid of our talent.” India, which secured 71% of H-1Bs in 2024, warned the hike would disrupt families and undermine bilateral skill exchange. Effective immediately, the fee spooked major IT firms—Infosys, TCS—and sent their stock prices tumbling. Industry body Nasscom cautioned of ripple effects on US innovation, while immigration lawyers and visa holders reported panic and reconsideration of US career plans amid policy chaos.

articles.title: Monday briefing: What the UK’s recognition of Palestine means for the war, its future – and its people
articles.trailText: In today’s newsletter: the coordinated action, taken alongside six UN allies, is a significant rebuke to Israel and the United States, but peace remains a distant hope
articles.summary: On 21 Sept 2025 the UK joined Canada, Portugal and Australia in formally recognising Palestine alongside 147 UN members. The move symbolically rebukes Israel’s Gaza campaign and West Bank annexation while endorsing a two-state solution, but falls short of creating sovereign institutions or defined borders. Recognition may elevate Palestine’s mission in London but cannot override a US veto at the UN or alter realities of occupation. Critics deem it empty theatre without a ceasefire or enforceable post-war plan. Advocates hope it pressures Israel and sustains momentum for durable statehood once hostilities end.

articles.title: ‘Same magic’: ancient Irish road bowling has been revived by TikTok, drones and Bill Murray
articles.trailText: Once in decline, the King and Queen of the Roads – the sport’s ‘Wimbledon’ – draws competitors and crowds from across Europe
articles.summary: The King and Queen of the Roads, a 2km road bowling tournament in Ballincurrig, County Cork, has revived its centuries-old rules by leveraging TikTok, Instagram, drone footage and livestreams to attract global audiences and European champions from Germany, Italy and the Netherlands. Hosted during COVID when restrictions were minimal, the three-day festival draws hundreds of spectators on-site and thousands online (via a Facebook group with 129,000 followers), and features celebrity visitors such as Bill Murray. Though still amateur, modern betting stakes can reach tens of thousands of euros. Core traditions – from underarm throws and “road showers” acting as caddies to the 794g iron bowl – remain unchanged.

articles.title: ‘These killings will go on for years’: murder of Ukrainian MP highlights shadow war of assassinations
articles.trailText: Death of Andriy Parubiy in Lviv seen as part of a covert campaign of hits and car bombs waged by Moscow and Kyiv
articles.summary: Andriy Parubiy, veteran Ukrainian nationalist MP and former security council secretary, was shot dead near his Lviv home by a fake delivery courier. His killing on 30 August is the latest in a covert campaign of execution-style shootings, car bombs and exploding scooters waged by Russian and Ukrainian services since 2014. Parubiy, who led Maidan self-defence units and championed independence from Moscow, had no personal security despite being on a Russian “kill list.” Analysts say the FSB and allied agencies coordinate high-profile hits and warn these shadow-war assassinations will persist even if frontline fighting ends.

articles.title: Ukraine war briefing: UN security council to hold emergency meeting over Russia’s ‘brazen’ airspace violation
articles.trailText: Donald Trump joins condemnation of Estonian airspace incursion and says he would help defend EU countries if Russia intensifies hostilities. What we know on day 1,307
articles.summary: Estonia has convened an emergency UN Security Council meeting after three Russian MiG-31 fighters violated its airspace over the Gulf of Finland; Germany also scrambled Eurofighters to intercept an Il-20M plane flying with transponders off above the Baltic Sea. NATO’s North Atlantic Council will meet Tuesday. Former US president Donald Trump condemned the breach and vowed to defend Baltic and EU allies if Russia escalates. In Ukraine, Russian strikes on Zaporizhzhia and Kostiantynivka killed four and injured several; Zelenskiy reported over 1,500 strike drones and urged tougher EU and US sanctions. Moscow-installed officials claim a Ukrainian drone strike in Crimea killed three.

articles.title: Kim Jong-un open to nuclear talks with US, saying he has ‘fond memories’ of previous Trump meeting
articles.trailText: Comments from North Korea’s leader come as South Korea’s Lee Jae Myung says he could accept a deal that sees the North retain its nuclear weapons
articles.summary: In a Supreme People’s Assembly address, Kim Jong-un said he retains “fond memories” of his three meetings with Donald Trump and would resume talks if the US drops its “absurd obsession” with denuclearisation and opts for “genuine peaceful coexistence.” He referenced stalled 2019 negotiations and strengthened ties with Russia and China. South Korea’s new liberal president, Lee Jae Myung, called for a freeze – rather than elimination – of Kim’s arsenal, noting Pyongyang produces 15–20 warheads annually as a realistic interim step.

articles.title: Latest recognitions of Palestinian state will deepen global diplomatic rifts
articles.trailText: Israel threatens retaliatory West Bank annexations while announcements by UK, Canada and Australia increase tensions with US
articles.summary: After UK, Canada and Australia recognized a Palestinian state, Israel threatens West Bank annexations, risking standoffs with Europe, rifts with Arab states and straining Five Eyes ties as the Trump administration supports Netanyahu. Washington warned allies of symbolic retaliation that could imperil the Abraham Accords. Rightwing ministers propose annexing up to 82% of the West Bank ("Judea and Samaria") or making a symbolic declaration at the UNGA. UAE and other Arab partners see annexation as a red line, risking diplomatic downgrades and EU sanctions. US arms deals ($6bn) add pressure. Starmer cites a two-state solution; Netanyahu categorically rejects it.

articles.title: At least 40 killed in Gaza and five in Lebanon in Israeli strikes
articles.trailText: Military steps up Gaza City takeover campaign as high-rise towers targeted and residents ordered to leave
articles.summary: Israeli air and drone strikes killed at least 40 Palestinians—including 19 women and children—in Gaza (14 in a southern Gaza City residential block, eight in Bureij refugee camp) and five people, including three children, in Bint Jbeil, Lebanon. President Joseph Aoun condemned the raids as ceasefire violations amid over 4,500 strikes on Lebanon since last November. Israel has accelerated its Gaza City takeover, targeting high-rise towers, ordering one million residents to evacuate and displacing over 500,000, while aid restrictions fuel famine fears. Australia, Canada and the UK formally recognized Palestinian statehood; PM Benjamin Netanyahu denounced them, and tens of thousands protested in Israel against the Gaza campaign.

articles.title: Brazilians protest in their thousands against granting Bolsonaro amnesty
articles.trailText: Huge crowds pack the streets to oppose endeavours to help ex-president escape jail
articles.summary: Tens of thousands of Brazilians rallied in Rio’s Copacabana beach, São Paulo, Brasília and abroad to protest efforts to grant ex-president Jair Bolsonaro amnesty after his 27-year prison sentence for plotting a coup post-2022 election. Far-right pop musicians Caetano Veloso, Chico Buarque and Gilberto Gil led chants of “Sem anistia” as crowds decried the lower house’s “Bandit’s Bill” shielding politicians. Celebrities like Wagner Moura and Fernanda Takai joined calls to uphold democracy, echoing fears of impunity reminiscent of Brazil’s 1979 amnesty. Pro-democracy marches also spanned London, Berlin and Lisbon, demanding Bolsonaro’s jailing.

articles.title: What role has Britain played in the history of Israel and Palestine?
articles.trailText: British politicians were heavily involved in region in early to mid 1900s, as Israel was established and Palestinians displaced
articles.summary: From 1914 Britain declared Egypt a protectorate, cut Sykes-Picot deals and backed an Arab revolt before General Allenby seized Ottoman Palestine. In 1917’s Balfour Declaration it pledged a Jewish homeland, later codified in the 1922 League of Nations mandate. Rising Arab unrest prompted the 1937 Peel partition plan and 1939 White Paper. Worn out by WWII, Britain handed Palestine to the UN in 1947; Israel’s 1948 founding triggered mass Palestinian displacement and shifted Middle East influence to the US.

articles.title: Kenya’s arrest warrant is milestone in Agnes Wanjiru case but lengthy UK process awaits
articles.trailText: After 13 years, warrant has been issued for UK suspect, but Robert James Purkiss would need to be extradited to face charges
articles.summary: Kenyan authorities have issued an arrest warrant for former British soldier Robert James Purkiss over the 2012 murder of Agnes Wanjiru, a 21-year-old mother whose body was found in a septic tank at the Batuk army base hotel. After 13 years of family campaigning and joint UK–Kenya investigations, Kenya must now request Purkiss’s extradition from the UK via the Home Office and Westminster magistrates’ court. If granted, Purkiss can contest at an extradition hearing before facing judge-led criminal proceedings in Nairobi, with the next mention set for 21 October.

articles.title: Netanyahu calls UK’s Palestine recognition ‘absurd prize for terrorism’
articles.trailText: Opposition leader Yair Golan blames government’s political recklessness and refusal to end the war in Gaza
articles.summary: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu condemned the UK’s recognition of Palestine as an “absurd prize for terrorism”, claiming it rewards the October 7 Hamas attack and fuels anti-Israel propaganda. Israel’s foreign ministry echoed this on X, warning it incentivizes jihadist violence. Ex-security adviser Yaakov Amidror warned it empowers Hamas’s narrative that only violence yields statehood. Domestic polls show Israelis seek a negotiated end to the Gaza war. Opposition leader Yair Golan blamed Netanyahu’s recklessness, while far-right ministers Smotrich and Ben-Gvir call for West Bank annexation. Israel’s response awaits Netanyahu’s Washington trip.

articles.title: German jets scrambled after Russian military plane flies over Baltic Sea
articles.trailText: Russian Il-20M reconnaissance plane ignored requests to make contact, in latest of what are seen as provocative acts by Kremlin
articles.summary: Germany scrambled two Eurofighters when a Russian Il-20M reconnaissance plane flew over the Baltic with its transponder off and ignored contact calls. Estonia, after recent MiG-31 incursions into Estonian, Polish and Romanian airspace and a Polish forager’s discovery of decoy drone debris, will convene an emergency UN Security Council meeting under NATO Article 4. President Trump vowed to defend EU allies. Baltic and Polish leaders decry Putin’s incremental provocations. Moscow denies violations, reports a Ukrainian drone strike killed civilians in Crimea, and rejects Western pressure. Zelenskiy signals readiness for talks, but Russia demands Ukraine’s surrender.

articles.title: Protesters flood streets of Philippines over state corruption
articles.trailText: Dozens of police officers injured as anger explodes over billions allegedly spent on bogus relief projects
articles.summary: Tens of thousands of Filipinos, from students and church groups to celebrities, flooded Manila and other cities on 21 September to protest alleged state corruption in flood-relief contracts that cost taxpayers up to £1.48 bn—or an estimated £13 bn according to Greenpeace. Demonstrations were largely peaceful but led to 72 arrests and dozens of police injuries. Protesters demand the return of misappropriated funds and jail terms for implicated officials. President Marcos Jr has backed inquiries, formed an independent commission and called for accountability.

articles.title: Christians should stand firm against the far right | Letters
articles.trailText: Letters: Anne Dobbing , the Rev Dr Jonathan Hustler and Andrew Copson respond to an editorial about the use of Christian symbols by far‑right activists
articles.summary: Three letter writers respond to a Guardian editorial on far-right exploitation of Christian symbols. Anne Dobbing, a Catholic, decries the racist distortion of Christianity’s justice, peace, reconciliation and compassion, and urges bishops to publicly challenge the weaponisation of the cross. Rev Dr Jonathan Hustler highlights churches’ practical witness—welcoming asylum seekers, anti-racism training, warm spaces, food banks and policy advocacy—as the true enactment of Christ’s message. Andrew Copson argues that all people of goodwill, religious or not, should unite around shared values of freedom, justice and human rights, rather than debating theological ‘truths’ that deepen divisions.

articles.title: Labour should draw strength from the principled majority | Letters
articles.trailText: Letter: Jake Lynch says extra-parliamentary mobilisation on the left has always been far stronger
articles.summary: Jake Lynch, responding to rising right-wing extra-parliamentary mobilisation, argues that left-wing street movements have historically been far larger—citing anti-apartheid (1985), Iraq war (2003) and 2019 EU referendum protests. He contends that Keir Starmer’s government has alienated this progressive base by opposing initiatives on Israeli apartheid, U.S.-led military interventions and EU reintegration. Lynch calls for a new progressive administration to embrace these causes and harness the principled majority’s strength.

articles.title: ‘Not enough in itself’: wary welcome in West Bank over recognition of Palestine
articles.trailText: People in territory call for symbolism of imminent move by UK and others to be translated into practical measures
articles.summary: Residents of Ramallah’s al-Am’ari camp greeted recent UK, French, Portuguese and Canadian recognition of a Palestinian state as overdue symbolism but demanded concrete follow-through. Barbers, librarians and technicians called for clear borders, arms embargos, sanctions, diplomatic breaks—citing decades of broken promises since 1948. Analysts and former negotiators warned that mere acknowledgement risks distraction without political will to end the occupation, halt West Bank settlements or relieve Gaza’s siege. Many compared international censure to South Africa’s apartheid sanctions as the only path to real change.

articles.title: Venice police fine parents of children who played football in public square
articles.trailText: Murano resident reported children, aged between 12 and 13, to the police
articles.summary: Venice police fined parents €50 each after a resident complained about 14 children (12–13) playing football in Pino Signoretto square in Murano, citing 2019 regulations banning ball games outside designated areas (only San Bernardo permitted). Parents note Pino Signoretto wasn’t in the ban list as it was created after local redevelopment. Fines rise to €500 if unpaid; parents vow to appeal. Critics, including councillor Marco Gasparinetti and ex-footballer Paolo Poggi, decried the move as disproportionate, arguing for common-sense intervention and defending children’s right to outdoor play amid overtourism and a dwindling local population.

articles.title: UK, Canada and Australia announce formal recognition of Palestine, with wave of Israel’s allies to follow
articles.trailText: Partly symbolic move by up to 10 states comes amid fears Israel could respond by annexing parts of West Bank
articles.summary: States including UK, Canada, Australia and Portugal—first G7 members—recognised Palestine formally, part of a coordinated push led by France ahead of a UN conference reviving the two-state solution. Up to ten Western allies (Belgium, France, Luxembourg, Malta, New Zealand, Liechtenstein) will follow, aiming to pressure Israel against West Bank annexation and isolate Hamas. The US labeled the move “performative,” while Arab and European ministers tie recognition to a reformed PA, a disarmed Hamas, and an eventual ceasefire. Domestic backlash from Israel and hostage families may spur further sanctions. Macron warns that new settlements threaten peace imminently.

articles.title: ‘Scary’ and ‘I loved it’: readers share polarised views about ‘unite the kingdom’ rally
articles.trailText: ‘We are sleepwalking to fascism’– views about Tommy Robinson’s London rally reveal fears of a new era of division
articles.summary: Tommy Robinson’s “Unite the Kingdom” London march drew an estimated 110,000 supporters and 5,000 counter-protesters, prompting hundreds of polarised reader reflections. Critics warned of “sleepwalking to fascism” and US-style misinformation filling a cohesion vacuum, while supporters—from self-styled defenders of free speech to ordinary citizens upset by austerity—framed it as a patriotic defence of British values. Responses ranged from a London lecturer unsettled by ubiquitous flags, a disabled free-speech advocate, and calls for proportional representation, to counter-demonstrators decrying anti-immigrant sentiment and urging a renewed social cohesion narrative.

articles.title: Owner of Georgian broadcaster called country’s ‘propaganda megaphone’ is based in London
articles.trailText: Imedi TV owner denies criticism by EU disinformation monitor and says it is editorially independent
articles.summary: Imedi TV, Georgia’s top-rated broadcaster, is ultimately owned by London-based Hunnewell Partners, which rejects the EU’s disinformation monitor branding it a “propaganda megaphone” for the Georgian Dream government. Hunnewell insists Imedi retains full editorial independence; the channel denies pro-Kremlin or anti-Western bias. Critics highlight its pro-government slant amid EU accession stalling, a new “family values” law, and opposition leader prosecutions. UK MPs are pressing for sanctions on Hunnewell directors and oligarch Bidzina Ivanishvili as Georgia approaches pivotal municipal elections under growing authoritarian pressure.

articles.title: ‘I was terrified of dying’: how one man survived 40 hours adrift in the sea
articles.trailText: Rafie Nadi, 23, was rescued off Spain’s coast after nearly two days floating with only an inflatable ring and flippers
articles.summary: Egyptian migrant Rafie Nadi, 23, survived 40 hours adrift in the Mediterranean after attempting to swim from Fnideq, Morocco to Ceuta with only an inflatable ring and flippers. Separated from his friend after eight hours, he drifted over 100 km, dehydrated, sunburned and ignored by several passing vessels. Near exhaustion, he was finally plucked from the sea by a family yacht 13 nm south of Benalmádena and handed to Spanish rescue services. Nadi, who left Minya five years ago to support his parents and eight siblings, now faces a lengthy asylum process in Spain.

articles.title: Ukraine war briefing: Shoot down trespassing Russian jets if necessary – Czech president
articles.trailText: Britain’s Typhoon warplanes join Poland patrols; major Russian oil facilities hit in Samara region. What we know on day 1,306
articles.summary: Czech president Petr Pavel warned NATO must deter Russian airspace incursions, even by shooting down jets; Finland’s Alexander Stubb backed binding security guarantees for Ukraine. Two RAF Typhoons began NATO patrols over Poland. Ukrainian drones struck key Samara oil facilities, halting up to 2.5% of Russian refining capacity and killing four. Russia captured Berezove; fierce fighting rages near Kupiansk; both sides made limited advances in Sumy and Kharkiv oblasts. Zelenskyy will press Trump at the UN for sanctions. Russia’s overnight drone and missile attacks killed at least three. A UN report exposed systemic torture by Russian authorities, urging universal jurisdiction prosecutions.

articles.title: UK set to recognise Palestinian state on Sunday
articles.trailText: Keir Starmer expected to confirm move after concluding the situation has worsened significantly in recent weeks
articles.summary: PM Keir Starmer will formally recognise a Palestinian state on Sunday after Israel failed to meet July conditions and Gaza’s humanitarian crisis worsened. The move, taken despite US objections and appeals from families of hostages held by Hamas, is meant to preserve prospects for a two-state solution amid expanding West Bank settlements. Labour insists recognition isn’t a reward for Hamas and won’t affect Gaza governance; sanctions on Hamas will be tightened and calls for hostage releases intensified. Deputy PM David Lammy warns settlement growth threatens peace. Israel’s offensive in Gaza continues, drawing protests and UN scrutiny.

articles.title: Security guarantees for Ukraine require readiness to fight Russia, says Finland’s president
articles.trailText: Exclusive: Alexander Stubb says a plausible deterrent and ‘American backstop’ are needed in the event of a future peace deal
articles.summary: Finland’s president Alexander Stubb argues that post-peace security guarantees for Ukraine must obligate European signatories to militarily defend against any new Russian aggression. He insists such guarantees—backed by an “American backstop” and clear strategic communication—must be strong and plausible, with no Russian veto. Despite 26 nations pledging a “reassurance force,” concrete commitments remain undecided. Stubb, leveraging his close rapport with Donald Trump, says Western capitals must shift from mere reassurances to real force, and he remains confident Ukraine can sustain a prolonged war until a negotiated settlement.

articles.title: Zelenskyy accuses allies of ‘wasting time’ as he prepares for Trump meeting
articles.trailText: Ukrainian president will urge his US counterpart to impose more sanctions on Russia when they meet next week
articles.summary: Ukrainian president Volodymyr Zelenskyy will press Donald Trump at next week’s UN meeting to impose fresh sanctions on Russia if Vladimir Putin refuses talks or a ceasefire, accusing US and EU allies, especially Hungary and Slovakia, of “wasting time” by maintaining energy ties with Moscow. He urged leverage of European pressure, clearer US security guarantees and touted Ukraine’s growing use of long-range drones on Russian energy sites. Amid lethal Russian drone and missile strikes on civilian areas, Zelenskyy reiterated openness to meeting Putin and called for stronger Western sanctions, air defences and arms supplies.

articles.title: UN security council fails to prevent ‘snapback’ nuclear sanctions on Iran
articles.trailText: Iranian foreign ministry urges further diplomacy and says return to pre-2015 measures are unlawful and unfounded
articles.summary: On Friday the UN Security Council failed to muster the nine votes needed to block the reimposition of “snapback” sanctions on Iran under the 2015 nuclear deal, with only China, Russia, Pakistan and Algeria backing South Korea’s draft resolution. Absent a new extension, punitive measures including an arms embargo, asset freezes and travel bans will resume at month’s end, following France, Germany and the UK triggering the mechanism over Iran’s limited IAEA cooperation. Despite intense European-led diplomacy and the UK’s continued openness to talks, Tehran dismisses the sanctions renewal as “unlawful, unfounded and proactive” while maintaining its nuclear program is civilian.

articles.title: ‘Insane journeys’: inside the narco-subs that cross oceans carrying hundreds of millions of pounds of cocaine
articles.trailText: Poorly paid crews risk their lives on voyages in ‘propeller-driven coffins’ to smuggle drugs from Brazil to Europe
articles.summary: Brazilian federal police seized a 60ft handmade semi-submersible narco-sub on Marajó island, days from a 6,000km Atlantic voyage carrying up to 6 tonnes of cocaine destined for Europe. These fiberglass “propeller-driven coffins” offer sailors minimal pay (£4,000–£7,000) and deadly risks—drowning, asphyxiation, heat exhaustion—in a claustrophobic, greenhouse-like hull. Originating in 1980s Colombia, narco-subs now launch from Pará’s secret shipyards to Portugal, Spain and beyond. Rising alerts in summer 2025 and recent interceptions en route to Australia, New Zealand and Sierra Leone signal an expanding global drug-smuggling network.

articles.title: Norway finds place in spotlight during ‘golden age’ of film-making
articles.trailText: Distinctive and critically acclaimed films and drama series from ‘a big hub of talent’ are appealing to audiences around the world
articles.summary: Norway’s film industry is experiencing a golden age, with festival trophies for Dreams (Berlin) and Sentimental Value (Cannes), Oscar buzz for The Worst Person in the World, and Netflix success for Pernille. Emerging directors like Halfdan Ullmann Tøndel, Emilie Blichfeldt and Thea Hvistendal embrace bold, distinct visual voices, supported by free film schools and long-term state funding (670m NOK) via the NFI. Renate Reinsve’s performances anchor this wave. While Norway leads its Nordic peers in original storytelling, producers warn rising production costs and streamers’ shifting priorities threaten future financing.

articles.title: Parliament vulnerable to ‘foreign actors’ after China spying charges dropped, Commons speaker says
articles.trailText: Lindsay Hoyle says decision by prosecutors to drop case ‘leaves the door open’ to spies
articles.summary: Commons Speaker Lindsay Hoyle warns parliament is exposed to foreign espionage after prosecutors dropped Official Secrets Act charges against Christopher Cash and Christopher Berry—accused of passing state-sensitive material between December 2021 and February 2023—citing an evidential failure. Hoyle says the decision hands Beijing a ‘licence to operate’ in Westminster and urges urgent security reviews. The CPS insists no outside pressure influenced its ruling, while officials note the National Security Act 2023 now broadens espionage powers.

articles.title: ‘I can’t survive in a house’: Petra’s Bedouin resist moves to evict them from ancient cave homes
articles.trailText: Plans to improve the world heritage site for tourists put its living culture at risk, say locals and campaigners
articles.summary: Bedouin families of the Bdoul community have inhabited Petra’s 2,400-year-old cave dwellings for around 200 years, but a major tourism-led redevelopment programme by Jordanian authorities is forcing dozens out, deeming them illegal occupants whose homes harm the world heritage site. Locals like Mohammed Feras and 85-year-old Rayya Hussein reject small government-built houses, fines and jail threat, arguing they are stewards of the ruins and cannot adapt to village life. Human rights groups warn the evictions risk erasing Petra’s living culture even as visitor revenues slump amid regional conflicts.

articles.title: Ukraine war briefing: Drones blast Russia’s Saratov refinery for second time in a week
articles.trailText: Ukrainian leadership continues to talk up recapture of territory in counteroffensive; EU moves to phase out Russian gas faster. What we know on day 1,305
articles.summary: Early Saturday Ukrainian drones struck Russia’s Saratov refinery—600 km east of Ukraine’s front—igniting large fires in a second hit this week, officials confirmed. Russia retaliated with strikes in Dnipropetrovsk, around Kyiv and Mykolaiv, killing one and wounding 13. On the ground, Kyiv’s counteroffensive pressed near Pokrovsk and Kupiansk, with Zelenskiy claiming recapture of seven villages and 160 sq km. Outgoing MI6 chief Moore condemned Putin’s war costs. NATO jets intercepted three MiG-31s over Estonia. The EU plans to ban Russian gas by January 2027 and tighten sanctions on oil traders, tankers and crypto networks.

articles.title: IDF warns aid workers only hospitals are protected sites in northern Gaza
articles.trailText: Israeli military says aid infrastructure could be targeted after order to ‘all Gaza residents and inhabitants’ to leave
articles.summary: The Israel Defense Forces, after ordering all Gaza City residents to evacuate, told humanitarian groups that only hospitals qualify as protected sites in northern Gaza, warning other aid facilities could be targeted. As IDF operations intensify in Gaza City—now largely emptied and in ruins—hundreds of thousands face dire prospects and high transport costs to flee south. Israel is establishing a “humanitarian zone” in al-Mawasi and new aid hubs near Egypt, but severe checkpoints, limited convoys (~250 trucks/day) and selective sites run by the Gaza Humanitarian Foundation leave much of the enclave under siege. Observers argue the offensive serves political aims to depopulate north Gaza and prolong war to bolster Netanyahu’s coalition.

articles.title: ‘This is their attempt to silence him’: Umar Khalid reaches five years in Indian jail without trial
articles.trailText: Held since 2020, India’s most prominent political prisoner has become a symbol of repression under the Modi regime
articles.summary: Umar Khalid, a Muslim leftwing activist and former JNU student, has spent five years in Tihar jail without trial after his 2020 arrest under India’s draconian anti-terror law over alleged involvement in the February 2020 Delhi riots. Bail pleas have been denied by the Delhi High Court and delayed in the Supreme Court, despite evidence resting on uncorroborated witnesses and WhatsApp group membership. His prolonged detention, condemned by Amnesty and other rights groups, has made him a potent symbol of the Modi government’s repression of dissent and Muslim voices.

articles.title: Nato intercepts Russian fighter jets on ‘reckless’ violation of Estonian airspace
articles.trailText: Russia denies what EU calls ‘dangerous provocation’ after Italian air force heads off three MiG-31s over Gulf of Finland
articles.summary: Nato scrambled Italian F-35s to intercept three Russian MiG-31s that entered Estonian airspace near Vaindloo island over the Baltic Sea for 12 minutes on Sept 19, in a ‘brazen’ incursion condemned by Estonia’s prime minister and foreign minister. EU leaders including von der Leyen and Kallas called it a dangerous provocation and urged tougher sanctions. Russia denied any violation, claiming its jets flew over neutral waters. NATO invoked Article 4 consultations; Zelenskiy and Western officials warned the incident underscores Moscow’s escalating threats.

articles.title: UN votes to allow Palestinian president to address annual gathering via video link
articles.trailText: Trump had refused to grant visas for Palestinian delegation due to attend conference and UN general assembly
articles.summary: UNGA approved 145–5 (6 abstentions) allowing President Mahmoud Abbas to address the assembly via video link after the US refused visas for him and up to 90 delegates. Canada, France, the UK, Belgium and Australia will formally recognise Palestine, with the UK announcement expected Sunday. Abbas will thank supporters and outline a vision for a Hamas-free Palestinian state. France, Britain and Germany threatened to reimpose UN sanctions on Iran after talks broke down, with an eight-day deadline on Tehran and warnings of possible Israeli or US military action. Israeli PM Netanyahu will speak Friday and meet Trump in Washington.

articles.title: Civilians made up 15 of every 16 people killed by Israel in Gaza since March, data suggests
articles.trailText: Report from independent conflict tracker Acled indicates one of the highest civilian death rates since start of war
articles.summary: Civilians accounted for 15 of every 16 Palestinians killed by Israel in Gaza since March, ACLED data indicates, marking one of the conflict’s highest civilian death rates. ACLED tracked reports and found ~1,100 operatives killed versus Israel’s claimed 2,100; over 16,000 deaths recorded post-ceasefire. Building demolitions jumped from 698 in 15 months to 500 in six months. Israeli forces, citing “unprecedented force,” have advanced on Gaza City, urging evacuation. Airstrikes killed 40+ Hamas commanders; Hamas is now largely confined to Gaza City and Deir al-Balah, resorting to IEDs. Aid distribution chaos and looting surged. ACLED warns Israel’s long-term policy aims to degrade Hamas, block governance and render Gaza unliveable.

articles.title: Israel boycott aims are misunderstood | Letter
articles.trailText: Letters: The boycott targets institutions, not academics or the flow of ideas, writes Jonathan Rosenhead
articles.summary: Jonathan Rosenhead contends that the global academic boycott of Israeli universities, launched 21 years ago, is routinely mischaracterised by bodies like the Royal Society and Universities UK as a ‘blanket’ ban on Israeli scientists and an infringement of academic freedom. He clarifies that the boycott specifically targets institutions deemed complicit in apartheid, human rights abuses and genocide—prohibiting funding, journal publishing, appointment references and hosting conferences—while explicitly permitting individual collaborations. Rosenhead argues that this focused institutional embargo disrupts complicity without hindering the free circulation of ideas or academic exchange among scholars.

articles.title: Scores killed by RSF drone strike on mosque in besieged Sudanese city
articles.trailText: First responders say 75 worshippers dead as paramilitaries push to capture last foothold of Sudanese army in Darfur
articles.summary: In El Fasher, the last Sudanese army-held capital in North Darfur under siege for over a year, a Rapid Support Forces drone strike on the al-Daraja neighbourhood mosque killed 75 worshippers, many displaced from Abu Shouk camp, volunteers said. RSF forces are encircling the city with earthen walls in their Darfur offensive. Satellite images show RSF advances around camps and the former Unamid base. UN rights data record over 3,300 civilian deaths in Darfur from January to June, largely from artillery and air strikes. Aid groups warn of intensifying famine, blackouts and ethnically targeted violence, urging international action.

articles.title: Amsterdam’s answer to its rubbish crisis? Remove some of the litter bins
articles.trailText: Problems have arisen in Dutch capital since introduction of a deposit scheme for small bottles and cans
articles.summary: After a bottle and can deposit scheme prompted a spike in street litter—25% of residents called their neighbourhood dirty, rising to 40% downtown—Amsterdam finance chief Hester van Buren is trialling removal of select bins out of the city’s 12,000, especially in shopping streets, take-away areas and near underground containers, to curb bin-tampering. The city is testing self-closing or deposit-slot bins, shifting cleaning duties to mandated businesses and mobilising 9,099 volunteers for community clean-ups.

articles.title: Family tell of ‘immense joy’ at release of British couple detained in Afghanistan
articles.trailText: Peter and Barbie Reynolds were arrested and held without charge for eight months, raising fears for their health
articles.summary: Peter and Barbie Reynolds, 80 and 76, were released by the Taliban after eight months’ detention in Afghanistan without charge, prompting “immense joy” from their family. Freed in Kabul, they flew to Doha and were reunited with daughter Sarah Entwistle. Long-time residents of Bamyan province, the couple ran a training and education organisation. The family thanked Qatar for negotiations. UK leaders, including Keir Starmer, also welcomed their release. Though planning a long recovery, Barbie Reynolds said she might return to Afghanistan “if we can.”

articles.title: Outgoing MI6 chief says Putin has ‘bitten off more than he can chew’ in Ukraine
articles.trailText: Richard Moore said Russia was unlikely to win on battlefield, as his agency launched call to recruit spies
articles.summary: Outgoing MI6 chief Richard Moore, in a farewell speech in Istanbul, declared that Putin has “bitten off more than he can chew” in Ukraine, warning Russia is unlikely to secure victory and suffers over a million casualties—a quarter poorly trained conscripts. Moore used the platform to launch Silent Courier, a secure dark-web portal to recruit spies within Russia and globally, targeting disillusioned Russians and visitors via Turkey’s nexus. He also warned of Iran, China and North Korea propping up Putin and urged recruits to help bring peace to Europe.

articles.title: ‘Everything came crashing down’: students admitted to US universities are stuck in Gaza amid Trump visa ban
articles.trailText: Dozens of students from Gaza hoped to travel to US to resume studies interrupted by war – Trump’s visa ban crushed their plans
articles.summary: Since the October 2023 Gaza war and the Trump administration’s suspension of nearly all nonimmigrant visas for Palestinian Authority passport holders, over two dozen Gaza students—including physics graduate Maryam (University of Maryland admit) and engineering transfer Leila—are trapped in territory where universities lie in rubble. Unable to start funded US programs, they face deferred admissions, closed Rafah crossing, and embassy interviews canceled. The State Department cites national security vetting; advocates including the Student Justice Network warn of lost scholarships and urge relocation to Europe or Canada.

articles.title: China, India and Belarus line up for Russia’s rival version of Eurovision
articles.trailText: Intervision promises to be lighter on sequins and heavier on patriotic ballads than its European counterpart
articles.summary: Russia is reviving its Soviet-era Intervision song contest in Moscow with 23 countries, mainly BRICS members (China, India, Brazil, South Africa) and post-Soviet allies like Belarus and Central Asian states. Banned from Eurovision since 2022, the Kremlin promises patriotic ballads, “traditional values” and a Russian entry by pro-war singer Shaman. Hosted by China’s Lay and India’s Stefy Patel, the show replaces sequins with state-approved anthems. Launched under Brezhnev and last held in the 1980s, the comeback was marred by US singer Brandon Howard’s withdrawal and reports of paid extras filling sparsely attended seats.

articles.title: Americans are ‘deer in the headlights’ in face of Trump assault on free speech, Maria Ressa tells Jon Stewart
articles.trailText: Nobel prize winner says US institutions have collapsed much quicker than expected under the Trump administration
articles.summary: On The Daily Show, live once weekly since his 2024 return, Jon Stewart hosted Nobel laureate Maria Ressa, who warned that Americans are “deer in the headlights” as US institutions and free speech erode under the Trump administration. She cited Jimmy Kimmel’s ABC suspension after his comments on the MAGA reaction to Charlie Kirk’s killing and FCC threats to revoke affiliates’ licenses. Comparing Trump’s tactics to Duterte’s Philippines “dictator’s playbook,” Ressa urged journalists and citizens to persistently report and mobilize to protect rights before they disappear.

articles.title: For comedians around the world, the laughs often end as democracy fades
articles.trailText: Silencing of Jimmy Kimmel sets US on course similar to that charted by authoritarian regimes from Egypt to India
articles.summary: Under President Trump’s pressure, Jimmy Kimmel’s ABC show was suspended, mirroring global satirical crackdowns from Egypt under al-Sisi—where Bassem Youssef fled in 2013—to India under Modi with arrests over anti-Hindu jokes, Russia detaining comedians, and Turkey’s legal pursuit of Jan Böhmermann. Critics warn America’s free speech is eroding towards authoritarian standards. Figures like Bernie Sanders compare US moves to Russia and Saudi Arabia. Across democracies in retreat, political satire faces criminalization, silencing performers who challenge leaders through humor.

articles.title: Friday briefing: Special relationships, unlikely ‘friendships’ – Trump’s state visit beyond the cliches
articles.trailText: In today’s newsletter: Never has so much flattery been bestowed upon a US president. But will the efforts of the prime minister and the king make a difference to the UK?
articles.summary: Donald Trump’s second UK state visit saw King Charles and PM Keir Starmer lavish praise and grandeur—from Windsor banquets with vintage port and gold cutlery to a Chequers press conference where Trump dodged contentious issues and even suggested using the military against migrant boats. Starmer hailed a £150bn US investment boost, though skeptics question its timing. The state banquet emphasised the special relationship cliché, sidelining climate, Gaza and domestic dissent. Week’s five top briefs: Gaza displacement, BoE rates hold, Channel migrant deportation, Corbyn–Sultana party split and Trump’s threats to TV networks. Protests were minimized or arrested.

articles.title: China issues warning to Papua New Guinea over defence deal with Australia
articles.trailText: Beijing’s comments come as leading military figures in PNG express concern over a potential defence treaty with Australia
articles.summary: Beijing cautioned PNG via its embassy’s Facebook statement against signing an exclusive defence treaty with Australia that could restrict PNG’s cooperation with third parties or undermine sovereignty. Days after PM Anthony Albanese left Port Moresby without ratifying the Pukpuk defence pact—whose text is agreed but pending cabinet approval—PNG opposition leader Douglas Tomuriesa and ex-military figures warn the deal may breach constitutional non-alignment and erode self-reliance. Framing it as superpower rivalry in the Pacific, Beijing warns PNG against becoming a 'playground' for big-power competition. Analysts call for safeguards, review mechanisms and alternative approaches to strengthen PNG’s defence without ceding autonomy.

articles.title: Ukraine war briefing: Zelenskyy claims ‘important success’ as troops push back on Russian advances
articles.trailText: President says Ukrainian forces in east have reclaimed 160 sq km of land and cleared another 170 sq km as counteroffensive ‘achieving results’. What we know on day 1,304
articles.summary: Ukrainian president Zelenskyy on day 1,304 touted an ‘important success’ in the east, claiming recapture of 160 sq km around Dobropillia and clearance of another 170 sq km, inflicting ‘thousands’ of losses on Russian forces (unverified). A Russian airstrike killed five near Kostiantynivka, while Kyiv struck a Bashkortostan oil refinery. US President Trump blasted Putin for derailing a peace deal. Putin says 700,000 troops are deployed. A Yale report identifies 210 sites used in Russia’s forced re-education of over 19,500 deported Ukrainian children, which Moscow denies. 1,000 Ukrainian soldier bodies were recently exchanged.

articles.title: Bali to block new hotels and restaurants after deadly flooding raises questions about mass tourism
articles.trailText: Bali governor says new instructions issued to stop hotels and restaurants being built on productive land, especially rice fields
articles.summary: After flash floods triggered by record rainfall killed at least 18 people and prompted a state of emergency on 10 September, Bali governor Wayan Koster, citing state news agency Antara, ordered a ban on new hotel and restaurant permits on productive land—especially rice fields—from 2025 onward. Aligning with the island’s 100-year plan and following warnings of an extreme rainy season from Indonesia’s meteorology agency, the regulation, due by end-2025, aims to curb mass tourism-driven overdevelopment, mitigate flood risks worsened by climate change, deforestation and waste, and heed decades of environmentalists’ warnings.

articles.title: ‘Cricket diplomacy’ collapses as India-Pakistan hostility enters field of play
articles.trailText: Indian players refuse to shake hands with Pakistani counterparts after Asia Cup match, in sign that traditional onfield camaraderie is eroding
articles.summary: In the Asia Cup match on Sep 19, India beat Pakistan but Indian players refused the customary handshake, dedicating the victory to forces involved in Operation Sindoor and victims of the Pahalgam terror attack. Pakistan’s captain, Salman Ali Agha, and coach Mike Hesson criticized the breach of sportsmanship, and PCB chair Mohsin Naqvi lodged an ICC complaint. Referee Andy Pycroft later apologized. Observers say this marks the end of ‘cricket diplomacy’—once exemplified by 1987 Zia-ul-Haq’s peace initiative—and reflects deepened Indo-Pak tensions under recent nationalist politics.

articles.title: ‘Japanese first’: the mini-Trump on the rise as population crisis bites
articles.trailText: The nationalist policies of Sohei Kamiya’s party, Sanseito, are drawing a mix of youth voters, disaffected conservatives and conspiracy theorists
articles.summary: Sohei Kamiya, 47, leads Sanseito – a self-styled “Japanese first” ultranationalist party inspired by Trump – from fringe to 15 upper house seats in July. Pitched to youth, disaffected conservatives and conspiracy theorists with anti-immigration rhetoric, anti-globalism, “deep state” tropes, with echoes of Reform UK and Germany’s AfD, and traditional gender roles, he blamed foreign capital, migrants and liberal elites for Japan’s population crisis. Sanseito opposes LGBTQ+ rights, calls for nuclear armament and reverence for pre-war values. Critics warn its rise reflects widening nationalist populism amid Japan’s demographic decline.

articles.title: Mass protest expected in Philippines capital amid public fury over alleged corruption in government projects
articles.trailText: Sunday’s demonstration in Manila to coincide with anniversary of 1972 martial law declaration as president backs rally in bid to placate anger
articles.summary: Thousands of Filipinos are set to join the “Trillion Peso March” in Manila on September 21—marking the 1972 martial law anniversary—to protest an alleged $17.6 bn embezzlement from flood-control and climate projects. President Ferdinand “Bongbong” Marcos Jr. voiced support, pledging solidarity with demonstrators enraged by ghost infrastructure corruption. Backed by civil society and church groups, the rally mirrors regional youth uprisings in Nepal, Indonesia and East Timor over elite privileges. In response, House Speaker Martin Romualdez, a cousin of the president, resigned to clear the way for an independent probe led by former justice Andres Reyes into a decade of flood-control schemes.

articles.title: From small-town New Zealand to Mont Blanc: how ultrarunner Ruth Croft made history
articles.trailText: Croft’s recent win the 174km Ultra Trail du Mont Blanc made her the first woman to take out the triple series crown in the prestigious event
articles.summary: New Zealander Ruth Croft, raised in Stillwater among her family's transport business, channeled a rigorous West Coast work ethic into trail running. Last month she won the 174 km Ultra-Trail du Mont Blanc, becoming the first woman to claim the UTMB World Series Triple Crown (OCC, CCC and UTMB) after surging past rival Courtney Dauwalter at 100 km. Humble and off social media, Croft credits her upbringing and seasonal balance—summer racing in Europe, winter rest in New Zealand—for her resilience. A former national youth champion and University of Portland scholarship athlete, she overcame injuries and redefined running as one season in her life, not her identity.

articles.title: Anna Friel tells court of ordeal as stalker given 15-year restraining order
articles.trailText: Phil Appleton, 71, made subject to order preventing him contacting actor and banning him from certain areas
articles.summary: Anna Friel told a Reading court that former pilot-actor Phil Appleton, 71, stalked her for three years—sending explicit messages, appearing at her home uninvited with a ring and claiming she’d be his “perfect wife.” Although he was warned in 2022, Appleton persisted, prompting Friel to report him again after multiple sightings at her Windsor residence. A judge has now imposed a 15-year restraining order banning contact and access to her usual haunts, plus a 24-month community order with 10 rehab days. Friel said the ordeal has caused anxiety and disrupted her work and family life.

articles.title: More than 250,000 displaced from Gaza City in past month, UN figures show
articles.trailText: Tens of thousands more forced to flee makeshift homes and shelters daily in face of new Israeli offensive
articles.summary: UN reports over 250,000 displaced from Gaza City in past month amid a new Israeli offensive using artillery, tanks and warplanes. Tens of thousands flee daily along Gaza’s coastal road toward a southern “humanitarian zone,” facing overcrowded dunes, scarce food, medicine and shelter. Israeli forces control eastern suburbs and advance into western districts, estimating 450,000 evacuees under orders. Gaza City is largely reduced to ruins. Aid agencies warn of famine and dire humanitarian needs. Fierce Hamas resistance persists.

articles.title: Zhang Zhan: who is the Chinese citizen journalist facing a second trial?
articles.trailText: Former lawyer has been accused of ‘provoking trouble”, a catch-all term used to target government critics
articles.summary: Zhang Zhan, 42, former Shaanxi lawyer-turned-citizen journalist, is set for a second trial in Shanghai’s Pudong court on charges of “picking quarrels and provoking trouble” after exposing China’s Covid-19 response from Wuhan in 2020. Sentenced to four years in prison for her frontline reports, released in May 2024 under tight surveillance, she was detained again in August and formally charged in November. NGOs warn her prosecution exemplifies Beijing’s crackdown on dissent and control of pandemic narratives. During her imprisonment she staged hunger strikes and won a 2021 Reporters Without Borders press freedom award.

articles.title: UK preparing to recognise Palestinian state as early as Friday
articles.trailText: Move comes after Israel fails to meet UK conditions that would have postponed step
articles.summary: The UK will recognise the state of Palestine as early as Friday after Israel failed to meet UK-set conditions—ceasefire in Gaza, resumed humanitarian aid, no further West Bank annexations and a sustained peace process. Keir Starmer insists Hamas must be disarmed, barred from government and that Palestinian Authority leaders face elections within a year. US President Trump, though critical of Netanyahu’s refusal to cease hostilities, dismissed London’s move as largely symbolic and unhelpful. Following Macron’s July 25 announcement, Britain opted for early recognition amid growing anger over Israel’s conduct and rising Labour calls for tougher measures. The Palestinian flag will be raised at the new London embassy, a change that legal advisers say creates no extra UK obligations despite Montevideo criteria objections.

articles.title: UN faces $500m budget cut and 20% job losses after big drop in US funding
articles.trailText: Core budget to fall to $3.2bn next year and initial minimum 3,000 job cuts expected amid streamlining process
articles.summary: Trump administration's funding cuts will slash the UN's core budget from $3.7bn to $3.2bn in 2026 - a $500m cut forcing at least 3,000 (20%) of 35,000 staff layoffs. As the US supplies 22% of regular, 25% of peacekeeping and 40% of humanitarian budgets, its contribution could plunge from $1.5bn to $300m. Secretary-General Guterres and under-Secretary Ryder's UN80/Mandates UN reviews aim to streamline 140 agencies into three pillars (security, rights, development), consolidate admin hubs, relocate staff and merge overlapping mandates. Major programmes (WFP, UNHCR, OCHA, UNICEF) face sharp funding shortfalls, endangering millions.

articles.title: Strike action across France as hundreds of thousands join protests
articles.trailText: Disruption seen across country as PM Sébastien Lecornu urged to rethink budget cuts
articles.summary: Hundreds of thousands of public sector workers, students and union members staged one-day strikes and 250+ demos across France, disrupting transport, hospitals, pharmacies, schools and canteens to pressure newly appointed PM Sébastien Lecornu to scrap planned austerity measures on wages, pensions and welfare. The action, backed by CGT, CFDT and FSU unions, follows a political crisis marked by three premiers in a year and a fragmented parliament. Interior ministry put turnout at 600,000–900,000; clashes and 140 arrests reported. Protesters blame Macron’s tax breaks and demand social and tax justice.

articles.title: Abortion pill providers targeted by new Texas law refuse ‘anticipatory obedience’
articles.trailText: Greg Abbott’s latest move fuels clash between US red states and blue-state shield laws protecting abortion care
articles.summary: Texas Governor Greg Abbott’s new law, effective December 4, empowers private citizens to sue anyone who manufactures, distributes or mails abortion pills into the state, with minimum penalties of $100,000. Under fire are telemedicine providers like MAP and Aid Access, which vow “no anticipatory obedience” and rely on blue-state shield laws—untested in court—to continue shipping. Texas AG Ken Paxton has already sent cease-and-desist letters and sued out-of-state providers. Critics warn this unprecedented fight will chill telehealth abortions, even as one in four US abortions now occur via telemedicine and nearly 4,000 Texans used mail-order pills in late 2024.

articles.title: Videos appear to show people smuggling by state-linked Libyan militia in Mediterranean
articles.trailText: Sea rescue NGO says clips and images provide evidence that smugglers ‘are part of Tripoli’s official military apparatus’
articles.summary: Video and photos obtained by Mediterranean NGO Mediterranea Saving Humans for the first time document members of Libya’s state-linked 80th Special Operations Battalion, part of deputy defence minister Abdul Salam Al-Zoubi’s 111th Brigade, forcibly removing Kurdish refugees from detention camps and kicking them into the Mediterranean near Tripoli. A second nocturnal clip shows Iraqi-Kurdish migrants thrown overboard from a black-and-white patrol boat. Witnesses allege four others were killed resisting. The NGO has sent evidence to Sicilian prosecutors and the ICC, accusing Italy-funded militias operating under a 2017 Tripoli-Rome migrant deal. IOM data show 867,055 migrants in Libya; a recent boat fire off Tobruk killed at least 50 Sudanese refugees.

articles.title: Bishop calls on Christians to reclaim England flag from ‘toxic tide of racism’
articles.trailText: Arun Arora, bishop of Kirkstall, says Christians should not be ‘neutral in the face of violence and injustice’
articles.summary: In a Leeds sermon, Bishop Arun Arora urged Christians to reclaim England’s flag and their faith from rightwing activists who, he said, desecrate both with racism and division. Speaking days after a 110,000-strong London march led by Tommy Robinson, where protesters invoked ‘Christian values’ against perceived Islamic threats, Arora condemned neutrality in the face of violence and injustice.
