He joined other Church of England bishops in denouncing the ‘toxic tide of racism’, flag protests targeting asylum seekers, and the appropriation of patriotism and faith to stoke hate.

articles.title: Macrons to submit scientific evidence to US court to prove Brigitte was not born a man
articles.trailText: French president and wife allege rightwing influencer Candace Owens is using defamatory attacks against them to boost media profile
articles.summary: President Emmanuel Macron and his wife Brigitte will submit scientific expert testimony in a US defamation lawsuit against influencer Candace Owens to refute her false claim that Brigitte was born male as “Jean-Michel Trogneux.” Owens has promoted the allegation in an eight-part podcast to boost her media platform. The Macrons’ lawyer, Tom Clare, says they will present photos of Brigitte pregnant and raising her children and demonstrate that her brother Jean-Michel attended both of Macron’s inaugurations. The suit argues Owens ignored credible evidence; her lawyers have moved to dismiss, questioning the court’s jurisdiction.

articles.title: Italy first in EU to pass comprehensive law regulating use of AI
articles.trailText: Legislation limits child access and imposes prison terms for damaging use of artificial intelligence
articles.summary: Italy is the first EU country to enact a comprehensive AI law aligned with the EU AI Act, imposing 1–5 year prison terms for harmful uses (deepfakes, fraud, identity theft) and stricter penalties for crime. It enforces transparency and human oversight across healthcare, education, justice and sports; bars under-14s from AI without parental consent; protects AI-assisted works only if backed by genuine human effort; limits text and data mining to non-copyrighted or authorised research; tasks the Agency for Digital Italy and National Cybersecurity Agency with enforcement; and earmarks €1bn in venture funding for AI, cybersecurity and telecom.

articles.title: France braces for day of strikes amid political crisis
articles.trailText: About 800,000 people to demonstrate against budget plans, putting pressure on new prime minister
articles.summary: Teachers, transport, hospital and other public sector unions stage France’s largest strike in years, mobilizing ~800,000 demonstrators across 250 marches, blockading bus depots and high schools, to press new PM Sébastien Lecornu to revise austerity cuts, enhance wages, pensions and services. Macron’s third premier in 12 months, Lecornu inherits a hung parliament from June snap elections, a €44 bn budget hole, EU deficit breaches and a recent Fitch downgrade. Under police deployment of 80,000 officers, he must win over Socialists, centrists and even far-right to avoid a no-confidence vote and prove his “profound break” from past policies.

articles.title: People in France: share your views of Thursday’s nationwide strike
articles.trailText: We’d like to hear from people across France about how they view Thursday’s strikes
articles.summary: French trade unions across education, transport and other sectors are mobilising for a nationwide strike and marches on Thursday to oppose unpopular budget plans, with some 800,000 participants expected. This will be the biggest demonstration since the 2023 protests against President Macron’s use of executive powers to raise the pension age to 64 without parliamentary vote. Citizens are being asked to share whether they’re taking part, why and how they view these strikes.

articles.title: Thursday briefing: As Israel defies warnings on Gaza, could EU pressure start to bite?
articles.trailText: In today’s newsletter: Brussels edges towards suspending trade deal after UN calls Israel’s actions genocide
articles.summary: After the UN’s genocide ruling amid Israel’s ground offensive in Gaza City, Brussels edges toward unprecedented suspension of its €42.6 bn trade deal over human-rights breaches; while the US and UK focus on Trump’s state visit. Guardian correspondent Julian Borger outlines the EU’s two-stage vote, with Germany and Italy as key holdouts, and how linking sanctions to the human-rights clause could bite economically—tanking the shekel and Tel Aviv stocks—fueling centrist backlash and anti-war protests, pressuring Netanyahu’s fragile coalition.

articles.title: China’s ‘temple economy’ in the spotlight as scandals rock influential religious leaders
articles.trailText: Powerful Buddhist monks who have previously escaped punishment are the latest target of the government’s crackdown on excess wealth and alleged corruption
articles.summary: China’s crackdown on its temple economy has escalated following high-profile scandals at major Buddhist institutions. In July the head abbot of Shaolin, Shi Yongxin, was stripped of his monkhood over alleged embezzlement, mistresses and illegitimate children – accusations he evaded in 2015. Similar probes ensnared monk Wu Bing for fraud involving donations, while viral footage of Lingyin Temple monks counting cash ignited public outrage. Under President Xi Jinping, the state is reversing prior support for temple commercialization, enforcing frugality and political obedience through new religious-affairs regulations. Temples must navigate booming tourism income against tighter party oversight to curb religious excesses.

articles.title: Ukraine war briefing: Europe-funded weapons shipments begin under ‘Purl’ scheme
articles.trailText: Zelenskyy says Patriot and Himars included in Prioritised Ukraine Requirements List; drones threaten Volgograd oil refineries. What we know on day 1,303
articles.summary: Europe’s Purl scheme delivered initial US$500m batches of Patriot defence missiles and Himars launchers, part of $2bn funded, $3.5bn expected by October, says Zelenskyy. NATO’s Patrick Turner confirms four packages under way. Russia’s Volgograd region raised oil refinery alert after 10–15 explosions from suspected Ukrainian drones. In Poland, authorities downed a Russian drone that hit a house; PM Tusk vows probe. Denmark will acquire long-range precision weapons, marking a defence shift to deter Russia. Ukraine’s air force reports 172 drone/missile attacks, downing 136. Lithuania charges 15 over Russia-backed parcel bomb plots. US DFC and Ukraine commit $150m to a mineral reconstruction fund.
